PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Harry Jenkins) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will be aware that the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings is currently inquiring into the televising and radio broadcasting of proceedings of both Houses of Parliament and their committees. As part of its inquiry, the Committee is considering the current presentation of the broadcasts, including the commentary from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's announcers in the sound control booths. The ABC commentators operate within rules concerning announcements from the control booths stipulated by the Committee, and steps have been taken recently to make the commentary more meaningful.

INTERJECT.PARA: As the sound relay of proceedings delivered into members' rooms is by means of the House monitoring system, members would not normally have the opportunity to listen to the ABC presentation of proceedings. Accordingly, it has been arranged that for today and tomorrow, days on the which the proceedings of the House of Representatives are broadcast, the ABC presentation will be relayed through the House sound monitoring sytem to enable members to experience the program being broadcast by the ABC.

Mr Sinclair-Mr Speaker, on a point of procedure, you did intimate to me that it would be necessary prior to the rising of the House this year to have a resolution regarding excerpts of parliamentary broadcasts and their use in broadcasting outside this place. I wonder whether you could give to the House an indication of your intentions in that matter. In so doing, could you also address the question of whether there is an inclination towards broadcasting the parliamentary adjournment debate?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess one has to be careful how precisely one states this.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Sinclair-I am prepared to treat it as being on notice.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am prepared to answer the question. I think it would be proper to do so. There was a meeting of the Joint Committee last night. As you know, we have received responses from most party leaders. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has responded but we as yet have not heard from the Leader of the House (Mr Young) or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). A recommen- dation has been made to the Leader of the House that a motion to continue the excerpting should be moved, provided there is agreement at that level. I do not know whether the Leader of the House can indicate whether that is proposed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Young-We will not have any difficulty in facilitating that before the House gets up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that answers the question. The request has been made and that will occur. As to the adjournment debate, that is part of the consideration of the whole report which is expected to be presented early next year. As I see it, there seems to be general agreement that we should continue the broadcast until midnight.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS UNDERTAKINGS (PENALTIES) AMENDMENT BILL 1985[COGNATE BILLS:CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985SALES TAX ASSESSMENT BILL (No. 11) 1985SALES TAX BILL (No. 11A) 1985SALES TAX BILL (No. 11B) 1985]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 November, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are seven Bills before the House in this debate on the Customs Undertakings (Penalties) Amendment Bill 1985 and cognate Bills. While these Bills cover a wide range of customs and sales matters in terms of Government policy, probably the most important of the Bills is the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 and its associated sales tax Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal Bill, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), contains two measures which put into effect decisions taken by the Government in two main areas. The first of those is a most important decision in that it facilitates the introduction of inwards duty free shopping. In other words, it provides for the exemption of excise, customs and sales tax on goods purchased at international airports in Australia following overseas trips. This legislation restricts the new initiative to the purchase of cigarettes, liquor and perfume. However, it is of course an important initiative taken by this Government. The second measure proposed in the legislation is another very important measure and it will benefit primary producers throughout Australia. I refer to the Government's decision to provide a full rebate of the excise on diesel fuel which is used by eligible primary producers. That is a decision which will have a cost to the Budget of $24m in 1985-86 and a full year cost of $35m. The beneficiaries of the decision are, of course, Australian primary producers.

I want to say a few words about each of the two measures. We heard some interesting debate on these two measures last night. It is a matter of concern to me that the Opposition has decided to oppose the Government's decision to allow travellers returning from overseas to purchase duty free cigarettes, liquor and perfume at Australian international airports. The decision goes back to September 1984. The Government announced at that stage its intention to introduce limited duty free shopping at international airports in Australia. Those shops will be located somewhere between the point of disembarkation at the airport and the Australian Customs Service barrier. This proposal would enable people coming back from overseas, as I have said, to buy such goods duty free; that is, free of excise, customs and sales tax.

As I have indicated, the Opposition opposes this measure. In the debate last night very few Opposition speakers came up with any cogent reasons as to why the Opposition was opposing this measure. There were some suggestions to the effect that the purchase of those things by Australians at Australian airports might lead to security or drug problems. The Government does not think those problems are likely to occur. The benefits to Australia resulting from the extension of this concession allowing people returning from overseas to purchase these things at Australian airports far outweigh any disadvantages.

Some of the benefits of this decision were mentioned last night. One of the first benefits is that we expect an additional $5m in revenue to be produced at airports because more Australians will buy their spirits, cigarettes or perfume in Australia at those airports rather than buy them overseas and carry them back. In anybody's language, $5m is a significant amount of revenue. Also, the point was made that these items, in particular spirits, constitute a small but nevertheless significant component of freight on international carriers.

Qantas Airways Ltd, in information put to the Government, estimated that over a year it would save more than $6m simply in fuel costs because of the nature of the change that we are making. In other words, it was saying that because many hundreds of thousands of passengers returning to Australia each year will not be carrying as much spirits, liquor, perfume or cigarettes, the total weight carried by those planes will be considerably less. This will amount to an astounding saving of about $6m by Qantas alone. That is a good thing. Those flights can be more cost efficient and of course not as much petroleum will be used to carry the same level of passengers.

The other very important benefit of this legislation is that it will make travel arrangements and duty free purchase arrangements much more convenient for Australian passengers returning from overseas. That is an important consideration in any area of government activity. A third important area is obvious; that is, in this legislation we are saying that we would prefer Australians travelling overseas, or visitors coming to Australia, to purchase these goods in Australia instead of overseas. I have to say that I find it remarkable that the Opposition in effect is advocating that Australians who travel overseas should be patronising shops in Hong Kong, Singapore, London or Jamaica at the expense of retailers and duty free shops in Australia. We on this side of the House believe that any support that we can give to Australian industry and Australian retailers is good for business, is good for the economy, and means jobs. That is precisely what this legislation is putting into effect.

The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) last night made a very powerful and convincing argument for the introduction of this inwards duty free shopping. He pointed out some most interesting statistics. He said that last year there were some two million international arrivals in Australia. Of those, 1.2 million were Australians returning from short term visits overseas. Clearly, many of those Australians would prefer to wait until they got back to Tullamarine or Sydney-instead of lugging around a litre of Glenfiddich whisky or a carton of cigarettes or cigars-to buy those things from an Australian airport terminal thus providing jobs and giving a benefit to Australian retailers. Again, what we are trying to do with this legislation is to make arrangements more convenient for Australian tourists returning and to establish a market in Australia. I think that is a commendable objective.

I repeat what the Opposition is saying in opposing this legislation: It is better for those 1.2 million Australians who travel overseas every year to buy goods in Hong Kong, or Singapore than to buy in Australia. It is really saying that it supports retailers overseas at the expense of retailers in Australia. We on the Government side simply reject that argument. We encourage, through this legislation, the maximum possible benefits to Australian producers and retailers who are located at international airports because that brings benefits to Australians and Australian employment levels.

Just briefly, another important item here is the item dealing with our decision to rebate in full the diesel fuel excise for farming, fishing and forestry uses which are currently eligible for the part rebate. In fact, this legislation gives effect to that full rebate from 1 November. It means that primary producers throughout Australia-there are some 170,000 to 200,000-will now be rebated the full 10c a litre of diesel excise rather than 7.6c a litre which they were receiving only a few weeks ago. That means, as I have said, that it is a cost to the Government this year of $24m. That full rebate is a full year cost to the Government of $35m. It means to an average farmer who might use 15,000 litres of fuel per year that he will be saving about $350 effectively per year in tax which he will no longer be required to pay to this Government because he will be getting the full rebate from this Government.

I have mentioned before in this House that fuel costs for farmers throughout Australia constitute about 10 per cent of their total costs. That figure, of course, is lower in the pastoral or livestock industries and is higher in the grain and fishing industries. However, this decision we have made means that a farmer using 15,000 litres of diesel a year will be saving some $350. It is part of this overall effort by the Government to reduce farm cost increases that do face our primary producers. We realise that they are having a very difficult time at present, particularly with the corrupt international trading practices of the European Economic Community which are costing Australian farmers more than a billion dollars a year in lost revenue and lost markets. It is important that the Government take every measure that is possible to reduce that rate of farm cost increases.

It is interesting-I am sure you are aware of this, Mr Speaker-that under the previous Government, farm costs rose by an annual rate of more than 12 per cent. This Government has managed to reduce that to a rate of slightly in excess of 6 per cent per annum. We have halved the rate of farm cost increases. We have the fundamental right and, of course, we will be looking to take whatever measures we can in the future to reduce further the rate of farm cost increases to our farmers. One of the associated measures that we took in the Budget was to replace the tariff on harvesters with a bounty. That, again, will effectively knock 15 per cent off the price of those harvesters and it will save our primary producers about $14m a year in costs. They were the two most important things that the National Farmers Federation put to this Government as things that were concerning primary producers. We introduced them and announced them in the last Budget. This legislation which, I am delighted to know, will be passed in this House today provides for the full rebating at 10c a litre of diesel to farmers.

In conclusion, I just repeat that the primary function of this legislation is to provide for and facilitate the introduction of inward duty free shopping. I fully support that. Frankly, it is simply not right that in the past, in effect, we encouraged people to buy duty free goods overseas. We have proposed under this legislation to allow the purchase of a limited range of goods duty free by Australians returning to international airports in Australia.

I must say for my own part that I would like to see the Government look at the whole question of duty free shopping. I particularly would like the Government to look at the feasibility of whether there should be any duty free shopping at all overseas or in Australia. It is a concession which is extended to people simply because they have been overseas. The ticket to purchase goods duty free is an international air ticket. It does cost the Australian economy when people buy goods overseas. I understand that if those duty free concessions were removed, in effect there would be a revenue gain to the Government of around $150m per annum. I would like to see the Government examine that proposition. In the meantime, we have done the next best thing, which is to extend the concession so that people can buy in Australia that limited range of goods. It is good for Australians, it is good for the airlines because they will save on freight and because of the resultant reduced security problems, and it is also good for employment in Australia. I have pleasure in supporting this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my speech by picking up some of the points that were made by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) in relation to the diesel fuel excise rebate which the Government is reintroducing at a level of 100 per cent in the package of legislation that is before us. Of course, I welcome the Government's decision to do this. Indeed, I was most disappointed when, back in, I think, 1983, the Government, soon after being elected to office, decided to abandon the full rebate. Over a period that rebate fell to some 76 per cent of the total cost of the excise to primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bendigo likewise applauded this decision, although he did not point out that this is a reversal of government policy which was brought about by pressure from the Opposition and, indeed, the National Farmers Federation. The honourable member for Bendigo also failed to point out in his discussion of this issue that, although farm costs have fallen to some extent over the last two or three years, farm incomes have fallen to a very much greater degree. Any primary producer or any businessman has to be aware, and obviously is aware, of the fact that his livelihood depends on his income being greater than his costs and his future livelihood is dependent on that income growing at a greater rate than his costs. If income is growing at a lower rate than costs, clearly the primary producer is heading towards bankruptcy, and that is what has happened over the last two years during the administration of the Labor Government.

In the time available to me I want to touch on a couple of issues in respect of the seven Bills that are before the House this morning, even though the Bills raise a large number of other issues as well. I am worried that particular parts of the package of legislation have been ill considered and drafted and put together in a hasty way. Indeed, it seems to me only reasonable to ask some questions about the motivation behind these pieces of legislation.

The first piece of legislation to which I refer is the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985, which imposes a new duty on imports of metal working machine tools. Only last week we had a debate in this place on the extension of the bounty on the production of metal working machine tools. It will be recalled that the Opposition supported the extension of that bounty. One of the reasons why we on this side of the House supported that bounty was that we have a preference for bounties over tariffs, largely because bounties minimise the effect of assistance on the costs of local producers and, indeed, on downstream users. Also, in view of a submission by the Department of Defence, we thought there was a good defence case for continuing the bounty for the industry so that at least some nucleus of the industry could continue to exist. There is no doubt, for example, that the submarine contract, which is being hotly debated now in the context of the South Australian election, is one part of the defence industry that could benefit from this bounty.

What the Government has done in the legislation now before the House is very surprising because, although it showed last week that it was in favour of the introduction of a bounty, this week it is proposing to impose an enormous increase in the tariff and the duty on imports of parts and accessories for the metal working machine tool industry. Indeed, the duty is to be increased from 2 per cent to 25 per cent under this legislation. Let me point out that this is something that has been opposed by the Australian Machine Tool Association, which has said again and again to the Government, which apparently has not been listening, that these accessories cannot be produced in Australia partly because most of the overseas countries involved will not license manufacturers in Australia. It seems to me a little unusual, when we cannot produce these accessories and parts in Australia, that the Government should impose an enormous increase in the costs of industry by increasing the tariff from 2 per cent to 25 per cent. Obviously, the increased tariff will impose further costs on, and affect the competitiveness of, Australian industry. Indeed, it will disadvantage companies which are trying to introduce new technologies. In other words, this particular measure is in direct contradiction to what the Government did last week; it is ill-considered. I am surprised that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) should support this sort of legislation because it is irrational, contradictory and damaging to that sector of Australian manufacturing industry, and by no means helpful.

The other aspect of these Bills, which has been debated at some length in the House in the last couple of days, is the question of inward duty free shopping. As I have pointed out, a large number of Labor members have supported this proposal, while Opposition members have expressed some reservations about the efficacy and wisdom of this measure. Once again, as with the measure on metal working machine tools, the Government appears not to have considered the whole range of implications of introducing inward duty free shopping as fully as it clearly should have done. The whole subject of inward duty free shopping has a rather curious history, and it is important that that history is understood and considered by the House before any passage of legislation takes place.

Back in 1979 Qantas Airways Ltd started to advocate the introduction of inward duty free shopping, possibly because that airline thought it might be a direct beneficiary from this measure. I cannot blame Qantas for promoting its own self-interest-any good company would do that. In response to Qantas's representations, the then Fraser Government established an inter- departmental committee. That committee reported in February 1982. It will interest the House, and indeed it might even interest the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), to know that the Fraser Government's interdepartmental committee rejected the proposal to introduce inward duty free shopping. Not long after, just a year later, the Mahony Review of Customs Administration and Procedures in New South Wales reported. That inquiry into the workings of the New South Wales Customs Service once more offered no support for the concept of inward duty free shopping, having been subject to strong representations that inward duty free shopping should be resisted.

By the Labor Party's policy speech in 1983 the Party was committed to the introduction of such shopping-goodness knows why-and as a result of that commitment, on its election the Labor Government established yet another interdepartmental committee. Something rather strange happened on that committee. Although the committee was first established under the chairmanship of the Department of Industry and Commerce, in the course of the hearings of the committee that Department was dismissed from the chair and replaced by the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. I think that was strange, particularly when one bears in mind-and I am glad that the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism is here, because he will be able to explain this to us later-that Senator Button and his Department were opposed to inward duty free shopping. That was the general tenor of the committee's considerations until the dismissal of Industry and Commerce from the chair.

Even the Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism was opposed. But the Minister supported the proposal. There is something a little curious about the way the interdepartmental committee has been handled. But there is something a little more curious, because when that committee finally finished its considerations, not only was the committee, I understand, opposed to the introduction of inward duty free shopping, but it was not requested to report to the Government. The Government said that it would rather not receive a report. We all know why it did not want to receive a report from that committee-the Minister supported the measure and no one else did. I would like to hear from the Minister later in the day why he supported the measure when his colleagues and his own Department opposed it.

The Industries Assistance Commission sub- sequent to this interdepartmental committee has also considered the question of inward duty free shopping. Nobody is saying that that Commission by definition is always right, but it confirmed the advice of the Mahony Committee, of the Fraser Government's interdepartmental committee, and of the Labor Government's interdepartmental committee. That is not very surprising. One of the points made by the Industries Assistance Commission and by a number of other people is the resistance to inward duty free shopping in a large number of countries. The very small range of countries that have inward duty free shopping-there are only seven or eight-are countries such as Iceland, Egypt and Iraq. Countries such as the United States of America, Great Britain and France have not introduced this measure and, as I will explain later, there are very good reasons why those countries have made that decision. They are not commercial reasons, they are not flippant reasons; they are very serious reasons and I am very sorry that the Government has rejected all the advice that has been given to it and has abandoned these serious reasons and serious considerations and has gone ahead with this measure.

Let us look at some of the arguments against inward duty free shopping. I do not want to labour the commercial arguments, as I have said, because there is a more serious argument. The Treasury estimates that the cost of this measure to government revenue will be some $10m a year. The Government is forever talking about its commitment to reducing expenditure, although I must say, judging by the exponential growth in expenditure since the Hawke Government was elected, it is hard to believe its rhe- toric. But why it should want to impose an additional $10m cost on the taxpayer I just do not know, particularly when that cost comes out of something which is of such relatively or seemingly minor importance as inward duty free shopping. No doubt Treasury opposed this proposal because it would cost the Commonwealth $10m.

The Australian Customs Service also opposed this proposal. Honourable members opposite have spoken in glowing terms of Australian Customs. I reinforce the remarks they have made about the professionalism of Australian Customs officers. Their professionalism has shown through in their submission to the Industries Assistance Commission on inward duty free shopping. Let us very briefly look at the arguments they made. The first point is that it would aggravate queuing and passenger delays at airports. The second point they made is that it would cause major problems with the completion of required and legally significant customs declaration forms. The third point they made is that it would probably increase revenue losses, and in saying that they are supporting the contention of Treasury. The fourth point they made is that it would increase passenger processing times, especially where airports operate on restricted curfew hours-for example, Sydney. The fifth point that the Customs Service made is that inward duty free shopping would lead to a risk of narcotic and message exchanges requiring additional Customs and security work loads. That is the nub of the argument and the nub of the Opposition's concern about inward duty free shopping and it is a concern which has not been addressed at all by those sitting on the other side of the House.

In other words the very real concern that we on this side of the House have and the real concern that the Americans had and the reason why they have not introduced inward duty free shopping is where one would establish barrier control. Inward duty free shopping is, by definition, before one gets to the Customs barrier, not after. Therefore, this provides opportunities for drug trafficking and the passing of narcotics, as was pointed out by the Customs Service. Clearly, the effect of having inward duty free shopping before one gets to the Customs barrier is that inward passengers have contact with civilians before they have contact with Australian Customs officers. That is why Customs is concerned ultimately about this measure, that is why the Americans have not introduced it and that is why nearly all the European countries have refused to introduce it. I think I am right in saying that should we go ahead with the measure Australia will stand alone in having ignored that extremely important and significant argument. I have quoted the Industries Assistance Commission on a number of occasions but I think it is worth quoting its particular concerns on this matter as set out in its report. It stated:
Incoming passengers could pass contraband to arrival shop staff who would later bring it through the barrier.

It is not just me or Australian Customs making these contentions; they are also being made by the Industries Assistance Commission, which is highly respected by both sides of the House. The IAC has confirmed these very real problems. The Auditor-General in his report of September 1984 also expressed concern about the possibility of this process taking place under present arrangements for incoming passengers at Melbourne Airport. I think that it is worth looking precisely at what the Auditor-General said:

In addition to the selling points located for departing passengers the duty free shop at the airport has a store and office premises which are located in the inward concourse area. This created a high level of risk as the premises were accessible to incoming passengers before they reached the customs inspection barriers. To reduce the risk, the Department had the location under security camera surveillance, but it would be preferable if the store and office premises were relocated to an area not accessible by incoming passengers.

Those comments related to Tullamarine Airport, which does not have inward duty free shopping. That section of the report points to the very great dangers of moving ahead, in the ill-considered way in which the Government has done, to inward duty free shopping where there will not be a store of some kind before one reaches the Customs barrier but a sophisticated supermarket style shop. That, as I have pointed out, is the nub of the whole of the Opposition's concern about inward duty free shopping. It is the primary reason why interdepartmental committee after interdepartmental committee has rejected this proposal. It is the reason the Industries Assistance Commission has rejected the proposal. It is the reason the Americans and the Europeans have rejected it. It is a pretty good reason also for a large number of Ministers in the present Government to have opposed it, with the sole exception, as far as I understand, of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very powerful.

—As the Minister points out, he is a very powerful Minister. At least, I think that is what he said. He is a very powerful Minister. He has persuaded all of his colleagues to go along with this ill-considered and very serious measure which will, unless action is taken to avert this danger, only aid and abet drug trafficking in this country, which is one of our very major social problems that should be addressed and rectified as best we can; and it should not be aided and abetted.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Government will seriously reconsider, even at this late stage, the measures that it is proposing in this package of legislation. I think what it is proposing will be contrary to the long term interests of Australian Customs and, to a much greater extent, the Australian people. As I have said, the other measure about which I was concerned-the imports of metal working machine tools having duty increased from 2 per cent to 25 per cent-is also a matter which, frankly, requires very careful consideration. These Bills are over-hasty. They have not been considered properly. I would like the Government to reconsider them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-We have had an exhilarating, hard hitting and well informed debate. The debate began at about half past eight last night. Thank goodness we did not have an all night sitting. We have debated no fewer than seven Bills, but virtually all the discussion has concentrated on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). The main thrusts of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) are to provide for a system of inward duty free shopping at airports-there is no doubt that there has been more debate on that subject than on anything else-and also a change in the system for the payment of diesel fuel rebates. The licences granted for inward duty free shopping will be extremely limited, to the sale of certain quantities of prescribed goods-spirituous liquor, tobacco products and perfume. The only people able to purchase goods at an inward duty free shop will be travellers on incoming international flights.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government took its decision to proceed with the introduction of these shops after exhaustive consideration of the issues. I think it is fair to say that it is essentially experimental. If it causes any of the major problems alleged by the Opposition, naturally it will be reviewed. There will be no change in the concessional limit, that is, the aggregate concession available to passengers. One could have picked up the inference from the debate that passengers reeling onto their flights at Hong Kong, absolutely stacked up with litres of grog will then get another set of bottles at Sydney as they reel off the plane. That is not possible because they will still be limited to the total concession. It is not doubled or increased at all. Many of the problems raised are completely avoidable. Nevertheless, the matter will be kept constantly under review.

Clause 9 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill provides for a different rate of rebate to be payable on diesel fuel used for different purposes. That would enable, in particular, the total customs duty payable on diesel fuel used in primary production to be rebatable, as announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the 1985-86 Budget Speech.

I refer to some of the comments made on the first Bill by honourable members. The honour- able member for Ryan (Mr Moore), befitting a member representing a Queensland electorate, was concerned about the definiton of rum. The new definition was the result of a review by the National health and Medical Research Council. It undertook an extensive review of the definition of rum, brandy and wine over several years-at considerable personal cost, I may say, to the members. Industry had ample opportunity to present its case to the NHMRC over that period. This is essentially not an industrial change, but a change related to health research. To change the definition of rum, it will be necessary to make further representations to the NHMRC. This issue was raised early in 1984 and was answered in similar terms then. If honourable members want to flick through their back numbers of Hansard, they will find it at page 2838. The matter will need to be looked at again by the NHMRC if the matter is to be referred to it because it has the responsibility for making the necessary recommendations to the Government. I think that was probably the case even when the honourable member for Ryan was the responsible Minister.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) suggested in regard to diesel fuel that the Government was giving on one hand and taking with the other-a remarkably original choice of phrase, I thought. He was arguing that we were giving back the excise on diesel fuel and taking dumping duties on fertiliser. I think that is an amazing statement because it is hard to believe that he is suggesting that the provisions of the anti-dumping Act should not be used if it remotely affects farmers.

The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) made a characteristically individual speech in which he indicated his support for this legislation, despite his Party's opposition. We hope that perhaps the honourable member for Ryan will intercede with the National Party to see that he comes to no disciplinary harm-

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ring up Joh.

—That will do. For the honourable member's information there would not be, of course, sufficient space to enable the total range of products that he mentioned to be sold. I think he mentioned, among other things that could be sold at inward duty free shops, 44-gallon drums of tractor lubricant which I have rarely seen in such shops at airports. The shops, of course, will be located between the aircraft and the Customs barrier.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was concerned that declarations in repect of rebates would not be made. As mentioned in the second reading speech, adjustments to the rebate will continue to be made in accordance with consumer price index increases, as will adjustments to the diesel excise. The Bill clearly states that the declarations will need to be higher than the rate specified in the Bill. As in the past, increases will occur only if there is an increase in the CPI. The honourable member for Curtin expressed some concern that the beneficiaries of the inward duty free shops at airports might be found only in Melbourne and Sydney. That may have been the result of an ill-timed interjection by me. It is the intention that all international airports will have the facilities, and there is no desire to keep Perth out in the cold.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will take some time, though.

—The whole process will take time. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) raised several issues. He spoke on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) as well, and I will refer to that in a moment. He devoted a great deal of his attention to inward duty free shopping. The Government is satisfied with the processes that led to the decision to introduce this legislation and it is not proposed to change it, despite the powerful arguments put by the Opposition. When an interdepartmental committee is established to consider an issue, the IDC is normally chaired by the Minister who has prime carriage of the policy. The issue was characterised not as an industry and commerce matter but as tourism matter. It was entirely appropriate that the IDC should be chaired by the Ministry for Sport, Recreation and Tourism.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the amendments in the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2). The honourable member for Mayo said that there had been an enormous increase in tariff on metal working machine tools. The increase is merely a restoration of the duties that applied before the tariff simplification of 1 January 1983. The Industries Assistance Commission found that local industry had lost sales following the reductions in sales tax imposed in 1983. The honourable member referred to the Australian Machine Tools Association. This is not an association of manufacturers, as he seemed to believe. It is basically a group of importers and merchants. He also referred to the cost impact on industry when duties were imposed on goods not made in Australia. It must be recognised that there is an industry producing parts and accessories, and it is clear from the IAC report that where specific products are not made in Australia it is open to the importer to seek entry of the goods under the commercial tariff concession system. I understand that some matters will be raised in the Committee stage of the debate on this legislation, so I will reserve further remarks for then.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION ADMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 13 November, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.
Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes this clause and will be dividing on it. This clause relates to inward duty free shopping. A number of items in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment (No. 2) 1985 relate to inward duty free shopping. The Opposition is opposed to this proposal for a large number of reasons. We have heard already this morning an explanation from the Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones) that this proposal has nothing to do with concessions. We concede that. We concede that the provision for inwards duty free shopping will be kept constantly under review. However, that is not the point; the point is that the introduction of inward duty free shops will expose us to large risks in areas of drug trading, will restrict the possibilities of surveillance and will put additional stresses and strains on the Australian Customs Service. As the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) pointed out, this proposal was considered an undesirable development by the Customs Service and by an interdepartmental committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the development aspects involved in this extension of the ability of people to buy duty free goods within the terminal area-as the Minister described it, between the aircraft and the Customs barrier-there will be a requirement for the construction of yet another shopping centre, another place in which people will gather. Instead of moving from the plane to the Customs barrier and then outside people will be contained within the restricted area for a longer period. There is no doubt that these days international travellers are subject to all sorts of pressures. Any area that allows the possibility of drug trading or other illegal activities ought not to be encouraged or facilitated. The Opposition sees this development as unnecessary. Certainly the Opposition sees the proposition as opening up all sorts of possibilities.

The only argument which I have heard in favour of the proposal which carries any validity for me is the saving by Qantas Airways Ltd of fuel costs. It should be remembered that Qantas is but one of the airlines servicing Australia. By introducing inward duty free shopping we are not only giving savings to the international carriers to Australia but also losing to this nation a considerable amount of domestic revenue. That was noted in the submission by Treasury to the Industries Assistance Commission in its report on inward duty free shopping. Therefore, the Opposition will be opposing this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —In commenting on the decision of the Opposition not to support clause 4, I think that it is worth making a couple of points. I noted that the shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), mentioned that Qantas Airways Ltd had made a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission concerning the extra fuel involved in carrying duty free goods. One should remember that almost every Qantas plane flying into Australia and bearing 400 passengers will almost always be carrying something in the vicinity of 40 dozen bottles of spirits.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite apart from the extra fuel involved in carrying that load there are a few other factors that should be considered. First of all, the freight charge for 40 dozen bottles of spirit carried from any port-for example, Singapore-would be extraordinarily high. We should add to that also the danger of having spirits, which of course are flammable, loose in the cabin. As was pointed out recently in relation to the drama surrounding the misbehaviour of some Melbourne footballers, when the staff shut down the bar because of the inebriated state of some of the passengers, those passengers proceeded to drink the duty free liquor which they carried with them. This is just another danger which will be obviated if people can be encouraged to buy duty free liquor when they get off the plane in Australia. In addition, there was a belief associated with duty free purchases overseas that countries such as Australia needed to help the economies of developing countries. No one can tell me that the economy of Singapore, for instance, needs propping up by Australian passengers. Compare Changi Airport with Tullamarine or Sydney airports. One can see the obvious ridiculous nature of that argument.

There are lots of compelling reasons why we decided Australians should be able to buy these sorts of duty free goods on their return to Australia. The final reason in favour of introducing inward duty free shopping is that it will result in an immediate advancement in the Australian economy by people buying those sorts of goods here. At this stage inward duty free shopping has been restricted to the purchase of alcohol, tobacco and perfume. As was pointed out by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), there are certain weaknesses in duty free shopping. It seems to me to be an incredible advantage for the comfortable middle class, of which politicians are a part, to be able to travel abroad and, as part of that advantage, be able to bring back whatever amount of duty free goods they want for their own use.

Also I think that there is a certain safety element that should be looked at in terms of people lobbing back into Australia with many large parcels of, for example, hi-fi equipment that were carried on the plane as hand luggage. Of course, we must add to that the knowledge that people who have travelled abroad and bought a hi-fi set or some other piece of electrical equipment in Hong Kong, or wherever, often have found on their return great difficulties in using that equipment in Australian conditions. If these things break down, as they invariably do, it is difficult to slip back to Kowloon to get them repaired. I think that is a good reason for in the future extending duty free shopping in Australia at the point of arrival beyond the three commodities catered for in this legislation.

On balance, I think there was a compelling reason to allow inward duty free shopping in Australia. I know that several government departments put forward a lot of reasons why this should not happen. It seems to be mandatory for departments and interdepartmental committees to give 20 good reasons why something should not happen. Sometimes however there is just one good reason why something should happen which is not used. I hope I have advanced such good reasons in this debate.
Question put:
That the clause be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 5 agreed to.
Clause 6 (Outwards duty free shops).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 6 is another clause leading to the facilitation of inward duty free shopping. While I take on board and understand the remarks of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), they still do not alter the position of the Opposition. We will be opposing all clauses which facilitate the introduction of inward duty free shopping, but it is not our purpose to divide on further clauses of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 7 (Inwards duty free shops).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same applies to clause 7. I maintain the comments I made before.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 8 to 11-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 12 agreed to.
Clauses 13 to 16-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 17 agreed to.
Clause 18 (Inwards duty free shops).

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the final clause in the Bill relating to inward duty free shopping. I raise just two other items which I think are worth mentioning. I would like to know from the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who owns the franchise at Sydney Airport in relation to duty free shopping. Who would be advantaged in these matters?

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is that no decision has been made. Presumably Sydney will be tendered for in the ordinary way and some decision will be made at that level. But no decision was made about Sydney or indeed any of the airports.

—Following the question from the Honourable Member for Ryan (Mr Moore), I ask the Minister for Science: Will the proposed duty free facilities be new facilities and not use the existing facilities? Will there be shopping at the existing facilities? If so, there must be an existing operator at the airport who will tender.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In doing administrative work for Customs I have gained some personal familiarity with this aspect. The facilities will be entirely new. They will be located between the off ramp from the plane and the immigration gates. So physically they will be quite separate from the current outwards duty free shops.

SPEECH.PARA: I should have said something in strong defence of the Customs officials. The Customs regulations are enforced conscientiously by an extremely diligent group of people. They do not anticipate great drug problems in inward duty free shopping areas. I think that is really quite remote. There may be some problems related to congestion and people slowing down as they go through Customs. That is a decision for people to make. They can choose the fast exits or to be diverted into duty free shopping. Obviously the inward duty free shopping area will be supervised with the same vigilance that airports are supervised now. I do not anticipate any problems. There would have to be a separate area physically.

As honourable members know, the concession for the duty free shops at Sydney Airport is held by Allders International Pty Ltd. My understanding, and I will double check, is that the inward concession has not been tendered for. I will have to take this matter up with my colleague, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), who may have inadvertently given me a bum steer. I told the chamber, relying implicitly on his advice as I always do, that the concession had not been allocated to anyone at Sydney Airport. That is true, depending on when the new inward duty free shopping area is established. The assumption is that there will be the same concessionaire for inward and outward shopping. The question is whether the new shops actually come into operation during the currency of the present concession.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly the point we are making.

—I will get information and advise the honourable member. I am not sure when the concession expires. If the inward duty free shop is ready for business, we will say hypothetically, by September 1986 and that is not within the concession period held by the present concessionaires, both will go up for tender together. It depends entirely on when the inward duty free shops are established. In a number of States it will be some time before they are established. I apologise for having inadvertently misled the chamber earlier.
—Who are the major shareholders in this proprietary company?
—That too is something that I will have to regard as being on notice and provide the honourable member with the information.

—I thank the Minister for Science for his replies. They remind me to ask a further question in light of his answers to questions which I asked and which the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) asked. It seems to me that there is a case for different tenders to be called for outward duty free shopping on the one hand and inward duty free shopping on the other hand, which might provide for an element of competition in pricing. The next question I ask is this: Is it in any way contemplated-I assume the answer is no but I would like this to be confirmed in relation to the inward duty free shopping-that there is only going to be one tenderer? In which case, how can the Minister guarantee to the travelling public that the prices at the inward duty free store will be competitive with prices in overseas duty free ports and in downtown duty free shops that is, off-airport shops in Australia?

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Additional material may have to be obtained and passed on when the debate is resumed in the Senate. Members of the House of Representatives can be informed as well. In a recent issue of Choice magazine there was a comparison between duty free shopping in Australia and in Singapore, Hong Kong and some of the other great entrepots. That comparison indicated that the Australian duty free price was lower, I think, than most of the areas reviewed. That surprised me, but certainly prices were very low compared, say, with Singapore or Hong Kong. I suspect that in many cases a comparison between the duty free price going out and the duty free price coming back is not going to be very relevant. Much of that buying is partly impulse buying. I do not think anyone in their right mind is going to get a couple of litres of whisky and lug it overseas, take it through every Customs barrier and then bring it back again simply for the fun of having something to carry around. The decision whether to buy something going out or whether to buy something coming in is really predicated on all sorts of different factors. It is not done on a very sharp calculation where people say: `I think I can save 25c if I buy it at the end rather than if I buy it going out'.
—It depends on the product.
—Of course it depends on the product.
—Perfume.

—Perfume possibly, but remember that there are only three categories of goods involved. In the case of tobacco products, I find it difficult to believe. In the case of the demon grog, I find that a bit hard to believe too. I think perfume is a possibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ELECTORATE: (Shortland Minister for Transport and Minister for Aviation)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to some of the discussions during the debate on this matter. I do not think I have heard a more ludicrous contribution come from the Opposition than there has been in respect of the proposal for inward duty free stores. What the Government's legislation is about is providing a better service to passengers, providing greater convenience to passengers, reducing costs to the international airline operators because of the less weight involved in carrying a substantial quantity of alcohol around the world from foreign ports and providing better value for people. Is it not better that people be able to purchase in Australia goods for home consumption from Australian employees rather than from abroad? What happened last night and during the debate this morning created a problem for the Opposition. As I understand it, one of the members of the Opposition is a consultant to the duty free operators association. He has a brief, and that is public knowledge. It has been published in the magazines of the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The battle is going on and the Opposition is putting up a case. It is putting forward a case for the off-airport operators as against on-airport operators. Let us get it right out in the open. That is the Opposition's case. Our case is that here is an opportunity, very much desired by the tourist industry and sought for years by the international aviation industry, to provide, firstly, a better service to people; and, secondly, to reduce the weight of alcohol being carried around the world in aircraft to this country which in itself involves a cluttering of the cabins of aircraft, a difficulty in evacuating people from aircraft in the event of a catastrophe or in the event of an emergency. That has been shown in recent events in other parts of the world--

TALK.START.PARA: —Manchester.

—Manchester was one. In the event of breakage of those alcohol containers, it adds to the fire hazard in aircraft. At the same time, we enable people as they come off aircraft to purchase those three items alcohol, perfume and tobacco.

SPEECH.PARA: Really, from what honourable members opposite are putting, the Opposition and the people it represents see that as the thin end of the wedge. Their real fear is not about those three items. Their case is argued-I think the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said something about this last night-on the basis of cameras. The honourable member talked about passengers getting off an aircraft at Sydney airport half asleep, staggering down the concourse and rushing in and buying a camera.

That kind of proposal or argument exposes what they are really about. That is not what the Government's proposal is. The Government's proposal is simply in respect of the three items I have mentioned-no more, no less. It is designed to give a better service to Australians and people visiting this country. It is designed to expand business in this country. Why is it not a better deal to be spending money in this country rather than abroad, employing Australians rather than overseas people? But the Opposition does not want that. It would rather that not happen. Members of the Opposition would rather run the brief they are running to protect off-airport operators. That is what the Opposition's position is all about.

I would like to say something about congestion at international airports. Have a look at Sydney international airport where the terminal is totally inadequate. This Government is not responsible for that. We are debating one of the measures that will improve the services. We are moving to improve arrangements to facilitate passenger traffic through the terminal. All of the problems at Sydney international airport have been inherited from the Opposition. We are putting an emphasis on two things-passenger service and passenger convenience. We are seeking a more efficient utilisation of airport investment. However, our efforts to do something by way of this legislation are being opposed by the Opposition. The Opposition is opposing the establishment of an airport corporation on some quite spurious grounds.

The last matter I want to mention is that, even though the Opposition does not want it, there will be a substantial addition to Federal revenue because we will be collecting a percentage of concessionaires' sales. Is there something wrong with that? Should we forgo a substantial addition to Federal revenue and say: `No, we do not want that money. Let us leave that off-shore. Let it be spent elsewhere.'? This is the same Opposition which is saying that we have to get the deficit down, that we have to reduce public expenditure. But it is a quite schizoid Opposition. What we heard last night and this morning was a debate of anarchy. The anarchists opposite are not sure what they are about. What has been said by those opposite shows the hopelessness and division within the Opposition at the moment. We will not move from our objective of providing a better service for passengers coming to this country, providing greater efficiency and taking the opportunity, where there is opportunity, to increase properly additions to Federal revenue.

The point was raised about who will have the rights to concessions in the duty free stores. That will go to the existing lessees and concessionaires during the currency of their contract. There are very simple reasons for this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—That flushes honourable members out because what they are really talking about are people off the airport. They are not--
—Who are the shareholders?

—I will give that information to the honourable member in a moment. The honourable gentlemen's case is not about public benefit; it is about protecting a lobby group for which one of his colleagues is a consultant. He ought to come right out in the open and declare his interest. Let us be quite blunt about it-come right out in the open and tell us. The honourable member should not use the phoney excuses that he has been giving.
—Will you deny that E. J. Walsh is involved?
—I would not know anything about that. The honourable member ought to declare his interest.
—Well, you declare yours.

—I do not have a personal interest. I have an interest as a Minister to see that we get the best value for taxpayers' money. We will do that-no more, no less. I want to get the best deal that we can for passengers who use international airline services.

SPEECH.PARA: What we propose is that the right to operate arrival inwards duty free shops should be granted to the existing licensees of airport departure duty free shops. These operators are presently mid-term in their contracts which were won in open competition following public invitation of tenders. There are practical problems with providing additional administrative and bond store areas that would be required by a second operator. The benefits should flow to consumers from economies of scale associated with the pooling of existing bond store arrangements, staffing, staffing facilities, administration, purchasing and marketing arrangements. As I have said, the inwards duty free store purchase is expected to replace mainly overseas and in-flight duty free purchases. Anybody who is interested will be able to put his case when the existing contracts expire. I have just been passed a note to advise me that E. J. Walsh is not involved in Sydney duty free stores. I do not know what that is about; I do not know why the honourable member opposite raised it. As I said, I am concerned only with improving the service that we are providing to people who use our terminals. We are taking the obvious and eminently commonsense approach, that of giving international airlines which haul alcohol around the world an opportunity to reduce costs and therefore reduce passenger fares. We will also take the opportunity to obtain additional income through the proper operation of services that people want.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) has just been at pains to make some mention of me. It is a pity that his ears were not as good as his mouth because, if they were, he would have realised that the statements he attributed to me were in fact the original statements of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who I think was the first person in the Australian Labor Party to bring the idea forward in Caucus and in the Press. The honourable member said last night that in fact he thought that the Government had not gone far enough and no doubt he will continue to lobby in that regard. He said that inward duty free facilities should be extended to cover video cassette recorders and cameras. In my speech I raised the pure stupidity-and I think the Minister, by his comments, agrees with me-of suggesting that an inward passenger would be in the business of buying a camera, having just come back from a trip where he needed the camera. I went on to suggest that he buy 50 or 60 rolls of film as well when he gets back which he can put in the cupboard and use on his next trip in a couple of years time. That just shows how much the Minister listens. It was a member of his own Party who made that suggestion. I agree with the Minister that it was a very dumb suggestion as were most of the Minister's comments of a few moments ago.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has gone as far as to tell us that the proposed arrangement will in some way replace the need to make in-flight purchases. A wonderful argument has been put forward about all the dollars that Qantas Airways Ltd will save by not having to cart alcohol all around the place. Is the Minister suggesting to me that Qantas would cease carting alcohol that it tries to sell to passengers and not try to maximise the sale of alcohol? Of course it will not. It will try to get the shilling; it will try to get the money.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not know what you are talking about.

—I know a lot more about it than the Minister because in fact I am a bit smarter than he is. That is all we have to worry about. I do not take my instructions from where the Minister gets his. At least I am a free agent in this place.
—I do my own thing.
—Yeah, I bet the Minister does. We have seen plenty of evidence of that. If he wants to debate that issue with me, we will have a lot of fun.
—We will, I am sure.

—Good. Let me get back to the clause before the Committee. The Minister suggested that somehow or other people will get better value because they will be able to buy goods in inward duty free shops. The Minister knows what that means. He is suggesting that it will be cheaper to purchase goods duty free than to purchase them once a passenger gets through the barrier. That is absolutely true. The profit margin will be higher but there will be no government taxes. If the Government has a commitment to helping the consumers of alcohol, perfume and cigarettes, it should just take a simple decision to reduce the excise and other taxes that it imposes on the poor devil who does not have enough money to take an overseas trip-the fellow who has his holiday down the pub on a Saturday morning. That is what the Government might do if that is what its intention is. I heard the Minister say that that is where the savings will be. However, the profit margin on alcohol will be higher inside the Customs barrier. In fact, it is well known in Australia and throughout the world that the silliest place to buy anything is in an airport duty free area, where one generally pays substantially more compared with an off-airport duty free facility. I am wearing a watch which I was silly enough to buy for $150 duty free in Hong Kong. I saw the same watch for $100 on my inwards trip to Hong Kong, but did not make up my mind to purchase it then.
—You have a free choice.

—Of course. It is fine to have a free choice. The Minister suggested that there would be better value in buying goods this way. If he reads Hansard tomorrow, he will see what he said. He should not credit those comments to me or the honourable member for Stirling. We all know, because it is the historic fact, that the dearest place to buy goods is in duty free stores which pay massive revenues to the airport authorities. They have a monopoly and they make sure that it pays for them after they have paid for their concession.
—Did you hear what I said about the Choice survey?

—I did not see the Choice survey. I am just telling honourable members opposite what will happen. I also want to say something about the convenience argument. A person can sit on the aeroplane and in the last part of the journey a trolley is wheeled up the middle of the aisle and passengers can select items of alcohol, cigarettes or perfume and carry their purchases off the plane. The difference will be that the passenger will walk off the plane without the goods and five minutes later will be carrying them. That does not suggest to me a huge degree of convenience. I suggest that the Government's estimates of the huge revenues to the people around the place, particularly the Government, from this activity might not be all that it expects.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other opportunities for abuse, clearly identified by the Australian Customs Service. I wander off the plane with a perfect stranger, I look over and see that he has not got his two bottles of Scotch, and say: `Hey, Charlie, aren't you going to buy some Scotch?' He says: `No, I don't drink it'. I say: `Here's a few bucks. Would you go in and buy two for me?' All I have to do is to stand outside the airport and line up five or six people and I have got a couple of years supply of alcohol. For all those people inside the barrier, it is as simple as that and it happens. It happens on other issues, too.

One of the great problems is that although Labor members consider they have great political brains they do not understand these things. They have distanced themselves from ordinary people, particularly the blue collar people whom Labor members claim to represent. They do not know how the people think. Have they ever asked themselves the last time they sat down and had a few drinks with some strangers in the front bar of a hotel, as I do, and many of my colleagues do? People talk like this and they will do those sorts of things, and it is great. But the only benefit is the fact that at the last point before one goes home with the family, or as a tourist one goes off to a hotel, one knows that the Government will not charge the traveller the tax.

The present Government introduced indexation of excise, as I said in the House last night. There was a time when the Treasurer of Australia had the courage to stand before this Parliament and people and say `I'm going to put up the price of beer or of whisky', and he had to confront that situation. We are well aware of the pressures that used to be put on him if that was even anticipated, but Labor brought in taxation by stealth. Labor did not worry about the poor working man-and beer, I would remind honourable members, has the highest tax level of anything. The Government indexes this every six months. When members of the public see the price go up in hotels these days, they do not know who to blame because Labor members do not have the courage to tell their own constituents that they are being taxed in this way. That is what we shall say about this arrangement. That is the only saving. The profit margin will be higher and there will be no tax.

The Minister spoke of the percentage turnover to the airport authorities. Incidentally, it will be quarantined off, to use a favourite word in this place now, into the hands of the new airport corporation because, presumably, it will get the rent and presumably the rent will be a percentage of turnover. One does not know how that will be diverted to government revenue so that it can be transferred to some of the better social efforts we make around this place. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) was complaining the other day about how the Queensland Government is not pulling its weight. We will just be diverting a little extra money that might go to some worthy social cause. But in that process the Government, according to the estimates, will forgo an additional $10m of excise, which is the property of the Government and is available to spend in what the honourable member for Lilley would consider very worthwhile activities. So that is what will happen-and all this to convenience a person who wants to get a bottle of whisky, a bottle of perfume or a couple of hundred cigarettes five minutes, or let us say 20 minutes, later than that person otherwise would.

What are the risks we take? We heard the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) in his usual style telling us about all the lobbies for the small business sector. I stand unashamedly in this place for the small business sector. I believe those people are entitled to a living and to be protected from Labor's type of centralism and regulation. The present Government is taking regulation off the big boys. Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and others have got a few concessions recently, but I do not see any being given to the little fellows. I stand unashamedly for them and their right to make a living and for the tourist hotel operator to sell a mixed drink rather than having tourists sitting in their rooms drinking out of a bottle. I stand for that operator and believe he has a right to make a profit-and he of course pays all the taxes.

One has to consider other problems. There will be problems in confusing the in-flow of passengers and the problems that will be created for Customs in detecting drugs and the other imports that we certainly do not want. That is the basic principle on which the entire Opposition stands. It stands on the principle that nothing should be done to confuse further the situation in handling of inward passengers. Clearly, as Customs has said, this will happen. People will not take a strong and central stream from aeroplane to the checkout counters. They will be wandering off; there will be opportunities to meet and mingle, and all sorts of things that will contribute to importation of drugs and other undesirable commodities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not intend to take part in the Committee stage of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, but I wish to make a brief reference to some of the comments made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). If one wants to get any advice about any sort of shady practices, or about means by which one might circumvent the laws or regulations, ask the honourable member for O'Connor-he is an expert. He has just given an example. He put forward a nonsensical proposition that people coming through the airport from an international flight will approach a stranger and say: `You haven't bought any whisky. Will you go over there to the duty free shop and buy me a bottle of whisky. Then after we have gone through Customs, if you are delayed or if I am delayed, wait outside there, when you are wanting to get home to the family, and deliver the whisky to me'.
—It will happen.

—What an absurd proposition. Of course it will not happen, and the honourable member for O'Connor knows it. As I was saying, if one wants to get any advice about circumventing laws or regulations or about shady practices to get around the regulations, ask the honourable member for O'Connor, but do not rely on that advice because we have just had a good example of the fact that the advice would probably be seriously deficient. Any person listening to this debate would have to congratulate the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) and the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) on an overwhelming, compelling and absolutely convincing case they have made out. The paucity of arguments used by members of the Opposition should leave them in shame. They have made some ridiculous claims. In addition to all those serious, important and compelling arguments used by members of the Government, there is one that has not received any attention up until the present. The implication of the Opposition's position is that, rather than buy in Australia from Australians at Australian airports, passengers should buy in Hong Kong or Singapore. If passengers buy in Hong Kong or Singapore, they will be using Australian foreign exchange. The amount of money involved may not be very much, but we have a seriously adverse current account at present, a serious imbalance in trade at present, and here is the possibility of additional saving. But for reasons best known to themselves, and they have not advised us of the reasons--
—Un-Australian!

—The honourable member for Chifley indicates that the position they have adopted is un-Australian, and that is putting it mildly. The honourable member for Chifley is a great Australian, a great advocate of all things that are important to Australians. It is a pity that Opposition members do not emulate the position so convincingly and effectively adopted in this place and elsewhere by the honourable member for Chifley-an outstanding national Australian advocate. Some of the arguments used by the Government, as I have said, have been absolutely compelling and convincing. There has been the whole question of the security of air flights. If we want any evidence, or if we want to be given any cause for concern about the adequacy of security and safety considerations on international aircraft, events in recent times give us more than sufficient reason to give our attention to it. All those points have been made adequately. I fail to understand first of all how the Opposition can possibly oppose this eminently sensible proposal, but not only to oppose it but to divide on the question. It will be recorded for posterity in the Hansard of the national Parliament that the Opposition adopted such a ridiculous and indefensible position on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The case has been more than adequately made out. Yesterday, when I participated in the second reading debate on this legislation, I appealed to the Opposition. I said: `You still have time to realise the error of your ways and to improve your credibility not only in our eyes'-it has a long way to go to do that-`but also in the eyes of the Australian people. You still have a chance to withdraw from this absurd position you have adopted and do the sensible thing'. Of course the sensible thing-(Quorum formed) Had I been allowed to conclude my remarks I would have said one sentence. That final sentence was going to be that despite the fact that hitherto, in connection with this question--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would the honourable member for Stirling not conduct a conversation in the middle of the floor.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, you will remember that the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) was one of the members on the Government side who made an absolutely compelling case in connection with this legislation. It was a great case. Yesterday I referred to it as a sterling case. I was going to suggest that in the dying moments of the considerations of this legislation the opportunity is now available to honourable members opposite to redeem themselves, to show that they are men of substance, that they are men of conviction and open to convincing when they hear compelling arguments of the kind that have been presented not only by the honourable member for Stirling, but also by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), the Minister for Science, the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. After all of the arguments have been presented, the Opposition has an opportunity to indicate that it is prepared to accept that advice and change its position. It is not too late for the Opposition to say that it has been convinced by the nature of the arguments and to indicate its support for the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I made two particular points. One was that if honourable members want any advice about shady practices, about how to circumvent the law and about how to get around regulations, they should ask the honourable member for O'Connor. His time is monopolised by such considerations. However, do not expect to get advice of substance. The honourable member gave an example of people getting off an international flight at Sydney Airport or Tullamarine, seeing someone who was not carrying any whisky walking towards a Customs barrier and going up to that person and offering him a few dollars to buy a bottle of whisky believing that the person would take the money, buy the whisky, go outside the Customs barrier and wait patiently for the person to come out and for the exchange to be completed. The honourable member spends a lot of his time trying to devise smart practices but most of them do not work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—During this debate the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) made an accusation which reflected on all Liberal Party members of this chamber. If I have it right, he accused a member of the Liberal Party of being a consultant to the industry. I invite the Minister for Transport to withdraw those remarks or to substantiate them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to extend this debate only because of the accusations that were just made. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) was at pains to say that if any honourable member wants to look at how people would treat with the law and how they might act there is something wrong about that. Firstly, he suggested that a person would not be silly enough to address a perfect stranger while walking down the airport passageway. That is not what I suggested would probably happen.
—You are inciting them to do it.
