—I am telling the honourable member that people are not as dumb as you-Mr Cameraman-and would do it. I am saying what they will do; I am identifying the problems with the law. The first point I make is that one does make acquaintances with people on aeroplanes. They happen to be the people next to whom one sits. They are probably perfect strangers when one gets on a plane.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Oh, oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —So Government members do not know the people they sit next to by the time they get off an aeroplane? That is probably the case with some of them. There are probably odours around that make people want to move away from them. I am well able to strike up a conversation with the people sitting next to me and it is not to get a bottle of duty free grog. I am quite happy to pay the going Australian retail price. I am quite happy to pay my taxes, unlike certain members of the front bench. Considering the deviousness of the Tuckey mind, is it not surprising that it has been necessary for me to bring certain matters to the attention of the House and to have suspicions that maybe not everybody on the Government side who criticised the tax system was so honest as to pay all of his taxes? I identified the then Minister for Finance as having dodged $1m worth of probate. He had a devious mind but I performed a service to this Parliament and to Australia. I pointed out to the Government how simple it would be to subvert the Australia Card.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for O'Connor is now moving very wide of the clause before the House. There has been no general accusation and I think it is completely irrelevant for him to continue with what is a very broad-brushed accusation. He should concentrate on clause 18, which is precisely what we are dealing with.
—I ask the honourable member for O'Connor to return to the matter before the Committee.

—It is interesting that while a personal attack was being mounted against me regarding my previous comments on clause 18, the Minister for Science did not get out of his chair to defend me. I am standing here to defend myself because at that time nobody from the Government side worried about the Standing Orders.
—You were not mentioned before.

—Last night I got another roasting from the honourable member for Charlton. He suggested, first, that I had a hotel in my electorate. I do not. He made some obscure suggestion that maybe there was some water in the rum. I took it that what he meant was that when I drank a glass of rum I added some water. I pointed out to him that I also do the same when I drink a glass of whisky. The point of my standing here and consuming the time of the Committee is that I have been attacked in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I rose a few minutes ago to speak to this clause to point out that the Government was creating a set of circumstances which would assist in further breaches of the laws of Australia, particularly regarding drugs, and I gave some examples. That was turned around by the honourable member for Charlton who suggested that there is something wrong with me because I point out to people how the Government's laws will not work. I gave the example of the Australia Card where up to $500m of taxpayers' money will be spent on something that will not work. What is wrong with an honourable member standing up in this chamber and identifying why it will not work? The greatest complaint which the Opposition makes about this clause is that the Government is facilitating the importation of drugs. Honourable members opposite can scoff about it. It does not matter if the Government is facilitating the importation of drugs by one half of one per cent, three-quarters of one per cent or 50 per cent. If it is adding to the opportunity for the importation of drugs and those sorts of substances, with all the harm that they do to our young people, it is not worth it.

I have made the point that it is not worth it because the previous point of purchase available to an inward traveller is the aeroplane. A person can buy duty-free goods, particularly the products dealt with in this legislation, on the aeroplane. That is all the trolley on the aircraft is full of. Someone suggested to me a little while ago that perhaps the aeroplanes do not carry enough. Maybe there are other means to overcome that situation. If a person flies by Qantas Airways Ltd he can even purchase the goods in Australian dollars. The convenience is not worth it when compared with the improved opportunity, even fractionally, to introduce more drugs to this country.

Honourable members opposite can forget all what I think of valid arguments about the loss of revenue to the Commonwealth and its application in helping needy people. I unashamedly repeat that the industry in Australia that is involved in providing goods that otherwise can be bought at duty-free shops contributes to the Australian economy in a substantial way. It is rumoured that only a mere 600,000 small business people will be involved. Many of those people will be affected by this in terms of competitiveness. The question is: Is it smart? I concede that if people make a decision to take a trip to Australia they are much more likely to do so on account of the Hogan advertisements than as a result of the fact that we suddenly convenience travellers to the point where they can pick up a bottle of whisky as they walk off the aeroplane. People come to Australia for the following reasons: Because it is damn cheap-the Government has devalued the dollar by nearly half of what it used to be worth; because of the good advertising program-I concede that; and because it is a great place to be and they are likely to get on and off the plane without being shot at and harassed in other ways. They have good reasons to come.

Honourable members opposite can put away the idea that they will be encouraged to come to Australia because they can purchase a bottle of whisky at the airport as they get off the plane. Very few people will make a decision to travel to Australia on that basis. The only ones who would do so would be so drunk as they got off the plane that there would be little reason for them to come here because they would not see much; they would be in an alcoholic haze all the way. It is not that important. It is particularly not that important in the limited way in which the Government is doing it. In truth, if the Government wants to convenience people-I do not agree with it-it should take up the suggestion of the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards) and let people pick up their video cassette recorders when they return to Australia. At least people would not have to hump them all over the place. But to make the changes merely for a bottle of whisky is meaningless.

The Industries Assistance Commission or someone suggested that there should be some bonding arrangement back in Australia. If the Government wants to keep the dollars in Australia it should let a bona fide air traveller make his purchases, have them bonded and allow him to pick them up when he gets back. It may as well do so. That is what it has almost achieved in this regard. At least that would not open up the opportunities for drug dealing and so on as we believe the current legislation does. I reject the comments made by the honourable member for Charlton. I know that he was trying to get a little light-hearted about the matter, but he should be grateful for the fact that I think past the obvious on many of these issues. When the Government forms its legislation it is a pity that it does not say: `Well, that Tuckey might be a bit of a devious character, but he might think that way because he has been out in the real world while members of the Government have been hiding behind the doors of academia, union business, science matters and things of that nature'. The reality is that the Government is on the wrong track and, at the moment, I think that it is on the wrong foot.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise only three points. The first is that the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) made a reflection on the Liberal Party and a member of the Liberal Party in relation to that member's professional representation. The Minister has not named that person. As he has not been prepared to name that person, I take strong objection to that insinuation. The Minister's intrusion into the debate brought in a fairly sharp contrast. There are now three positions in the situation that applies in respect of concessions. Firstly, there is the position put by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) who said in his contribution that these concessions are there and they will be up for tender in the normal course for the allocation of these inward duty-free shops. Secondly, there is the position of the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who took a totally different position, as far as I can recall, in relation to the concessionaires. Thirdly, the Minister for Transport has taken a different position. He said that those who currently have the concession will keep it.
—He is right. It is his responsibility.
—There are three different positions.
—No. He is right.

—We take the position of the Minister for Transport. If we take his position as the true one, the introduction of inward duty-free shopping means that the existing concessionaire gets an enormous advantage, for the latter part of his term, at no extra amount. According to what the Minister for Transport said, he will be the operator because he holds the concession. Therefore, he will pick up a very handsome windfall. While I am on the subject of economics, I find it quite fascinating to listen to the Government talk about the balance of payments situation and the effect of this, that and the other. I would have thought that the three items which it is proposed to sell-namely, grog, perfume and tobacco-were all imports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Together with my colleagues the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), I also wish to express my real and genuine concern about the totally unsubstantiated allegations made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) in the debate. The Opposition has expressed concern about the impact of inward duty-free shopping on the illegal importation of drugs. We raised that point. We maintain our concern in relation to that. The Minister for Transport has come in here, having been presumably called from his office, and has suddenly turned our concern about drug imports into a political debate. He made a totally unsubstantiated claim. He has now been asked twice by this side of the chamber to substantiate that claim and he sits there mute. Come on! If he is going to make those claims he should substantiate them. He knows damn well that they are not true. If there is a conflict of interest he should substantiate the allegations. He should come up to the despatch box. He has the right to do so. We have invited him twice-I invite him for the third time-to substantiate or withdraw these allegations. He used to throw around such allegations when he was in opposition. It is obvious that he is still willing to throw mud and hope that a bit of it will stick. Making unsubstantiated allegations is not, in my view, the way in which the proceedings of this chamber ought to be undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite laugh. The allegation has been made. If there is any fact, any substance, to the allegation I ask the Minister for Transport now to come to the despatch box and explain or withdraw. He should have the decency to withdraw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few points briefly in response to the matters that have been raised by the Opposition. I say on behalf of my colleague the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) that he did not specify a Liberal member. He said `a member of the Opposition'. I think it is very curious and very gracious of the Liberals to own up and say: `Well, it is not one of the Nationals'. They immediately identified that it was not a member of the National Party and that it must be one of them. It is curious that they should say that. The Minister for Transport knows his onions. He is an excellent Minister. I am glad he came into the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Transport knows more about what is going on in airports than anyone else in Australia, certainly more than I did, on the question of the concessionaires. I point out that the question of the change in the law and the change in the duty as applied is the responsibility of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and, of course, the Treasurer, as the Minister responsible for revenue. But the actual running of the airports, that is, in regard to the allocation of the concessions to the applicants, is the responsibility of the Minister for Transport. As I say, I was very pleased that he came into the chamber at the critical moment. I expressed my regret earlier that I was misinformed about what was going to happen in regard to the additional concession for the inward duty free shop.

I wish to clarify one or two points. Honour- able members have really forgotten what it has been like to travel by air in the last few months. The airlines do not sell grog from the trolleys any more in flight. That used to be the case. But if honourable members reflect, they will recall that for some little time now the airlines have not sold liquor in flight on the journey to Australia. That is because of its high bulk; it is weighty; it is inflammable; and it is fragile. They still sell items like jewellery, tobacco and perfume in flight because they are high in value, small in bulk, and so on. Honourable members will recall that one of the factors that came out of the recent Boeing 737 disaster in Manchester was that the amount of cabin carried duty free goods was regarded as a contributory factory in hampering the exit of passengers from the aircraft. That must be taken into account.

I referred earlier to an article in the Choice magazine for November 1985 which showed that Australian duty free shopping was extremely competitive compared with shopping in South East Asia. The goods are not always as cheap as those available in Europe, but the prices certainly compare very well with prices charged in other countries in our region. For example the price of 14 millilitres of Chanel No. 5 in Australian dollars in Brisbane was $49 and in Hong Kong $60.81. The Singapore price was not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —That wouldn't have anything to do with the currency at the moment, would it?
—No, I am talking about a price in Australian dollars. It is a constant figure.
—What is the Australian dollar worth at the moment?

—We are talking about a constant price in Australian dollars irrespective of where goods are sold. The price of a Canon AF 35 MII New Sure Shot was $175 in Sydney and $193 (Australian) in Hong Kong. Again, the Singapore price was not quoted. Similarly, in Australian dollars, a carton of Marlboro cigarettes was $5.40 in Melbourne, $7.45 in Singapore and $8.69 in Hong Kong. Those prices are all in Australian dollars. Clearly, so far as Australia is concerned, the pricing here is extremely competitive. The prices in Europe do seem to be somewhat cheaper. For example, a bottle of Chivas Regal, which is a very expensive 12-year-old whisky, costs $10.99 in Rome, $11 in London and $11.16 in Amsterdam.
—What is the price of synthetic rum?

—I do not think that the price of rum is listed. In Sydney the lowest duty free price for Chivas Regal was $9.90, in Singapore $16.50 and in Hong Kong $17.76. Comparatively speaking, local shopping represents very good value for the Australian traveller.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill 1985 corrects a multi-million dollar bureaucratic blunder of the Government's own making, a blunder for which the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) must take full responsibility. Until late last year all the quarantine duties covered by this Bill came under the control of the Minister for Health. As a former Minister for Health I can understand the burden of his portfolio and I sympathise with him in some of the difficulties that he must be having in trying to administer Medicare, but there is no excuse for mistakes of this magnitude. This House is being asked to remedy a bureaucratic bungle resulting from the Hawke Government's failure to meet its own legal requirements. It is not a minor blunder; more than $3m in quarantine fees have been collected without proper legal authority. Now the House is being asked to give retrospective approval to what have been, under strict application of the law, illegal actions over the last 12 months. The Government is supposed to be making the laws, observing the laws and setting an example to the rest of the community. But here we have a situation in which the Government makes the law, proceeds to maladminister that law and then finds that it has collected money illegally and seeks retrospective approval for having done so.

SPEECH.PARA: Members on this side of the House will not oppose the Bill, but we seek to highlight the poor administration of the law by the Government. I think it is fair to say that Groucho Marx would have been proud of this Bill. The Quarantine Amendment Act operating from 24 May 1984 inserted a new section 86E into the original Act which created ministerial authority to set quarantine fees. There was a dual requirement that new fees be published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette and that both Houses of Parliament be notified of such changes. The Government did only half a job on its own requirements. Its failure to notify Parliament of Gazette notices last October has created one legal problem after another. A notice in the Gazette on 1 October 1984 revoked all fee determinations for human, animal and plant quarantine.

Two difficulties arose from that notice: Firstly, Parliament was not notified and, secondly, new fees were set only for livestock exports. Failure to advise Parliament meant that the determination became null and void on 24 October. The fees, therefore, were applied under the Acts Interpretation Act which dates back to the year the Commonwealth Government was founded. Meanwhile, the Government continued to charge fees for quarantine services other than livestock even though such fees had been completely revoked on 1 October. Between 1 October and 24 October there was no legal provision for any such fees to be collected. On 13 December 1984 administration of the animal and plant quarantine Act was transferred to the Primary Industry portfolio, but the consequent fee determinations made by the Minister for Primary Industry have also proven to be defective. An estimated $2.5m has been collected for human, animal and plant quarantine services without proper legal authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful!

—It is absolutely disgraceful. The honourable member for Cowper hit the nail right on the head and I hope that he says it again. A further $630,000 has been collected from airline operators in 1984-85 for removal of galley waste from aircraft without correct legal provisions being in force. What do we say about that?
—Shocking!

—It is absolutely shocking. It is disgraceful. It was assumed that section 64 of the Quarantine Act covered such fees but, under advice, the Government has now gazetted new measures under section 86E. The action of the House in passing this Bill gives effect to a notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette last week.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the Opposition does not intend to block the passage of this legislation, we do seek to have incorporated in the legislation three amendments which I believe are fair and reasonable and which should be readily acceptable to the Government. I foreshadow that in the Committee stage I will move amendments to protect any recipient of quarantine services who may have had reason to challenge the payment of these fees since the problems arose with the administration of the Act. Under the circumstances I believe that it is essential that the interests of all parties are protected, including both the Government and those receiving the services. Unless provision is made for anyone challenging the payment of fees to continue their action, this Parliament may, by approving this Bill, give unwitting protection to the Commonwealth Government in what should be unencumbered legal proceedings. I will outline the details of those amendments in the Committee stages of debate. I understand they have been circulated.

The Government has taken the only available course of action to clean up this messy administration of section 86E by presenting a fresh Bill to the Parliament. At least it has not tried to totally cover up the whole debacle; yet, the point must be made that the way in which the Government administered its own laws leaves much to be desired. The Opposition's reluctant support of this Bill should not be taken as a precedent that we will not oppose retrospective correction of such mistakes in the future. The administration of government is not an easy task. I know it is not an easy task but surely we can expect that such a recent amendment should be properly implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us bring a little common sense into this debate on the Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill. This Bill restores a proper legal basis to aspects of one of the most important public services in Australia. This Government acknowledges that. Let me put this particular piece of legislation into context. It was the Hawke Government which undertook a complete overhaul of the quarantine system to make it much more effective. It is the first such complete overhaul of the Quarantine Act since it was introduced in 1908. In fact, it is an overhaul which was applauded by the Opposition at the time it was undertaken last year. I will quote from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), who said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I am pleased to be able to say that on this matter of quarantine there is quite a broad measure of agreement. I am able to say some nice things about the Minister in regard to this Bill.

He was referring to the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett. No Australian could doubt the overwhelming necessity for an efficient and effective quarantine service in the protection of the nation's interests. Australia is a unique country in many ways and its geographical characteristics and its isolated position have serious implications for our cultural and economic relationship with the rest of the world. In this context, the need for an adequate quarantine service becomes a paramount consideration and the financial means by which the service is maintained assumes a position of central importance.

The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has already capably outlined the necessity for the introduction of the legislation to overcome a defect in the legislative arrangements under which fees have been charged and collected for quarantine services already provided by the Commonwealth, but which services, because of the anomaly referred to, did not have legislative backing. Under Commonwealth law, the Commonwealth is obliged to have some legislative authority for the levying of fees. In relation to the matters dealt with in clauses 4, 5 and 6 of the Bill, this authority lapsed for two periods due to an administrative oversight of a technical nature; that is, a drafting error and a failure to table the notice revising fees within the prescribed period of 15 sitting days. In relation to clause 7, validating legislation is necessary because of recent legal advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department to the effect that, contrary to the view previously held by the Department of Health, there may be no legislative basis for the levying of fees in relation to the collection of aircraft waste even though the Act provides for the recovery of the expenses incurred. This Bill, therefore, seeks to validate certain fees charged by the Commonwealth to private individuals and to commercial groups for these vital services at varying times between October 1984 and October 1985. The legislation will cover $2.5m in quarantine fees.

At this stage I would like to comment on the amendments to be moved by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) on behalf of the Opposition. The amendments proposed by the Opposition appear to reflect a complete lack of understanding of the Bill and its effect on the quarantine system. It appears to me that, were these amendments not put up by the honourable member for Gwydir, who does not usually indulge in such capers, it would be a typical case of the Opposition dreaming up issues and then running around looking for homes for them. I cannot forget with what energy honourable members opposite strived to insert an abortion issue into the Bill of Rights legislation. As the Attorney-General recorded clauses to meet their objections, Opposition members changed tack to find another clause or home for their issues. They were here to oppose it and, by golly, oppose it they did. However, maybe I have misjudged them in this instance. They may really misunderstand the purpose of the Bill, which is to pass legislation to set what has already occurred within the letter of the law.

I make it quite clear that this legislation will not modify the quarantine system, the appeal process or any other aspect. The legislation will not raise additional fees, impose levies, fees or charges retrospectively and will not remove the rights of aggrieved parties to challenge the fees paid during the relevant periods. Therefore, these proposed amendments are irrelevant. Though possibly well meant, they are misdirected. I understand that the honourable member for Gwydir is attempting to preserve people's rights to protest if charges are imposed retrospectively. However, I think I have made it quite clear that this will not be the case and in these circumstances I think the Opposition should consider not proceeding with its amendments.

I would like to put the particular amendments that I am referring to into context with the Federal Government's overall actions to reform administrative aspects of Australia's quarantine system-actions which I am pleased to note have, as I have said already, received the support of Opposition members in this House. Since its election in 1983 the Hawke Government has recognised the importance of an effective quarantine service and it has sought to ensure that the service fulfils its functions appropriately and economically. The Government, in its 1984 amendment to the Act, moved to increase significantly the penalties for the breach of quarantine rules to provide a formidable deterrent to the import and export of harmful products. The Opposition foreshadowed the need for a serious deterrent in this regard but it was the Hawke Government which responded to the appeals of the rural sector for a much stiffer penalty. As a result, the maximum fine for a person who brings a disease agent into Australia has been raised from $10,000 to $50,000. This is a much more stringent and realistic fine and will ensure that the quarantine rules will not be taken lightly by anyone.

In addition, the Government has honoured its 1983 election promise to transfer some of its quarantine services to the Department of Primary Industry. Therefore, we now have a logical system in which the Department of Primary Industry handles the quarantine of animals and plants while the Department of Health handles human quarantine. At the time that this particular incident which this legislation is designed to cover occurred in October 1984 and was being investigated, the Minister had detected another anomaly with regard to the collection of levies paid by airline operators in 1984-85 to offset expenses for collecting and disposing of galley waste from aircraft arriving from overseas. The legislation, therefore, will also validate $630,000 in airline charges that were levied in this context without the authority of the quarantine Act.

I have outlined the sensible administrative reform which has been undertaken to enhance the health of this country and to maintain its economic strength. I mention economic strength in this regard because of the crucial relationship between a totally effective quarantine system and our competitiveness on international markets. Australia is an exceptionally lucky country. We are blessed with an abundance of natural resources, a landscape of enormous size, wealth and beauty and an environment which so far has been mercifully spared disastrous diseases such as rabies and foot and mouth. The control of these diseases in Australia is not due entirely to our isolated position on the globe. Neither is it due entirely to the fact that we are a lucky country. It is due, to a large extent, to the persistent efforts of our Customs and quarantine officers whose invaluable service has ensured that the diseases which cripple the agricultural output of our trading partners and rivals have not come here.

Were it not for the quarantine services which many of us take for granted, our international competitiveness, not to mention our reputation for integrity in the international community would be severely damaged. Meat export, for instance, is one of the linchpins of our economy. If adequate protection for our livestock were not guaranteed, the cost in export earnings would run into millions of dollars. A major outbreak of foot and mouth disease would devastate farmers. But any of a number of diseases-swine vesicular disease, African swine fever, screw worm fly-would wreak havoc if introduced into Australia.

Tourism offers considerable benefits for this country and has contributed much to the economic growth achieved under this Government; but it also offers potential dangers. An increased traffic of visitors to and from these shores increases the risk of exotic disease entering the country. Many of the visitors to our country are not aware of our essential quarantine stringency and the utmost care must be taken to ensure that our quarantine services can cope with the demands of an expanding tourist industry. A perfect example of this stringent security has been provided to me by a quarantine officer of the Health Department, which handles human aspects of quarantine. One of the major functions of this section, as referred to earlier with reference to this validation legislation, is the disposal of the galley waste from international airlines-that is, the unused food served on international flights. Because the food on these flights is prepared in many different areas of the world, it is far more likely to harbour exotic diseases. Such is the exacting scrutiny of the quarantine service that traces of cholera, which were detected in some airline food, were traced back, after analysis, to the water which had been used to wash some lettuce in Bahrain.

Honourable members can gauge from this example just how vital our quarantine services are in the control of exotic diseases. I hope the House will forgive me for saying that so efficient are these services that I am confident there is no danger that any exotic birdlife disease may have infected this hallowed chamber as a result of the unauthorised entry this week. I know that our quarantine officers would be quick to determine whether this was animal, plant or human and act accordingly. The range of quarantine services provided by the Departments of Primary Industry and Health are undeniably essential. These services include treatment, inspection and supervision of animals and plants at all points of entry into Australia and an extensive surveillance of our coastline accounting for $7m from the Health Department alone.

This Bill is all about maintaining these services by ensuring that quarantine fees, as discussed, are placed on a proper legal basis. The Government has acted quickly to restore this legality to the services' operations and passage of this legislation will allow this to continue. I feel secure in the knowledge that our quarantine services will play their part in reconciling the economic benefits of tourism and the health and safety of our people and of our environment. Particularly, I speak on behalf of Queenslanders whose new international airport in my electorate is due for completion in time for the bicentennial celebrations. The matters discussed today should be one of the prime concerns of any government. I stress that they are a prime concern of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House, noting the progress being made towards the establishment of a national meat inspection service and the constructive steps being taken with regard to export inspection, congratulates all governments for their co-operation in this endeavour.

Australia is part of an ever increasingly competitive world market and as such I believe we should be aware of cost pressures in export oriented markets. The National Farmers Federation recently summed up the importance of maintaining international competitiveness in a series of farm briefs. Commenting on this area the NFF stated:

All Australians have an interest in achieving and maintaining improvements in international competitiveness. Such an improvement will lead to increased economic activity in export and import competing industries. As a result Australia will be able to generate more exports and less imports.

It therefore follows that any initiatives to achieve such an objective would be clearly inarguable. Already the Hawke Government has taken decisions to reduce cost pressures in our primary industries, a sector that still contributes almost 40 per cent to our export wealth, so much so that under this Administration increases in farm costs are now running at about 6 per cent in stark contrast to the 12 per cent typified by the Fraser period of government. Therefore any actions taken to reduce costs, and any action to develop an improved meat inspection system, should be worthy of public comment in this House.

The establishment of a national meat inspection service coupled with developments in the Export Inspection Service is a reason for congratulating all governments involved. I stress the words `all governments'. Like the lack of a standard gauge rail system, a vestige of introspective colonial jealousies, we have had a classic example of historical division of Commonwealth and State functions for many years after Federation, no more so than when it comes to the question of meat inspection. Despite the fact that all involved have generally agreed that a single national meat inspection service was more efficient and obviously in Australia's best interests, progress unfortunately was painfully slow for many years. Governments, both Commonwealth and State, meat industry authorities, major importing countries and even the 1982 Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry endorsed the concept of a single meat inspection service.

Clearly, there are obvious benefits arising from a single inspection service. For the benefit of this House I would like to outline some of the more obvious benefits. First, it provides for better control over the whole meat chain under one authority, providing for increased security of export meat, a higher level of compliance and one point of contact for all meat inspection. Secondly, it facilitates uniform domestic inspection and construction standards nationally, thereby allowing easier movement of meat and reduced costs to industry. Thirdly, it provides for uniform domestic legislation with ministerial orders aligned to the specific requirements of each State and Territory.

Fourthly, it provides for a uniform national charging policy. These charges are lower than those applying in all States that presently charge. Fifthly, it eliminates the duplication of State inspection fees in those export registered works which also produce for the domestic market. Sixthly, it provides a base for more efficient use of staff, reduction in duplication and, very importantly, elimination of demarcation disputes across domestic and export operations. Based on experience to date, these can result in staff savings of some 10 per cent. Seventhly, it provides for economies through nationally based systems. For example, in computers, uniform transfer of documentation, training of industry and inspection staff and so on. Finally, it facilitates the introduction of more efficient and effective practices in areas such as animal welfare policy on abattoirs, exotic disease control and new inspection practices. Recognising the obvious benefits, there has generally been a co-operative approach by all governments-a very pleasing aspect and a reason for the introduction of this motion into General Business today.

It is worth outlining the history. Prior to July 1983 each State, with the exception of South Australia, carried out the task of meat inspection for domestic purposes. Since 1964 an agreement had been in force with South Australia that provided for the Commonwealth to inspect both domestic and export meat, and further refinements to this scheme are presently under discussion. However, on 1 July 1983 the New South Wales Government transferred its domestic meat inspection service to the Commonwealth. This eliminated duplication of both staff and charges with considerable benefits to all concerned. Savings of some 19 per cent of total domestic staff have been achieved in New South Wales alone by this decision-19 per cent just in one State.

From 1 April this year the Queensland Government transferred responsibility to the Commonwealth for all domestic inspection in export registered abattoirs and, again, the separate State fee in these works was abolished. The Tasmanian Government has passed legislation which will enable co-operative arrangements to commence on 3 March 1986. The Northern Territory has already agreed to a single inspection service, using the New South Wales model, to commence two months later, on 1 May 1986. The Western Australian Government has also announced an in-principle decision to transfer responsibility to the Commonwealth for domestic inspection in export registered works. Negotiations to this stage suggest that the separate State charge for inspection will be abolished towards the middle of 1986.

Victoria presents some difficulties in the movement towards a single inspection service. For a while both the Commonwealth and the Victorian Governments had intended that such a scheme would operate from the beginning of the new year. Unfortunately, the necessary Victorian legislation to enable a single inspection service in that State was defeated by the Liberal-National Party Opposition in the Legislative Council just two days ago, at a cost to the industry of some $2.4m. I am sure my good friend and colleague, the honorable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), will enlarge on the effects of such a narrow minded decision, particularly by the National Party, which claims some type of special relationship with rural industry.

Overall, the cost benefits have meant a saving of some $5m a year through the abolition of the dual fee. Furthermore, the economies and more efficient arrangements have meant that the 1985-86 inspection charges will be frozen at the previous year's level. The States, of course, always have the option to withdraw from the ministerial agreement at any time. However, at this stage the States seem more than satisfied with a system that produces economies and cost savings to the meat industry but still allows them to control such areas as domestic abattoir licensing, design standards in such works and the formulation of standards for domestic inspection.

I now comment on the Export Inspection Service. Other speakers in the debate, I am sure, will enlarge upon some of my remarks. The Export Inspection Service was established in the wake of the meat substitution scandal and the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry that followed. This arrangement began on 16 March 1982 under the previous Government. Some of the major changes over the past five years have been as follows: Firstly, the recommendations of the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry have been implemented-a move, I am sure, that has been welcomed by all governments, by the meat industry authorities and by all concerned about Australia's future. The Inspection Policy Council, which advises the Minister and the service on policy issue functions, with membership from industry, unions and consumers, as well as State and Commonwealth governments has been established. New inspection arrangements for meat and meat products have been agreed with international authorities, unions, State governments and the industry. Final implementation is expected by the end of the current financial year.

Numerous other changes have occurred along with the broadly based plans for the future with the aim of making inspection practices in Australia the envy of any other international competitor. As a result of these changes, costs were reduced considerably during 1985-86. Cost increases of some $10.5m have been absorbed and new and improved practices will mean further savings of about $8.5m. Direct savings to the industry of some $4.5m should reduce labour and material costs as well as handling costs. I think all honourable members will appreciate that the move towards a national meat inspection service and the Export Inspection Service generally have meant good news for the Australian primary industry field. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) said in this House on 24 August 1983:

I am convinced of the benefits of a single national inspection service and I remain optimistic that such an arrangement can be achieved in a spirit of co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States.

Let us hope that actions such as were taken by the Liberal-National parties in the Victorian Legislative Council do not diminish the Minister's optimism of just two years ago. My motion is stated in quite clear, positive and, I hope, bipartisan terms, which reflect a movement of sensible, co-operative endeavour and I commend it to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I want to associate the Liberal and National parties with the view that we should have a single meat inspection service in Australia but that that service should be accountable and responsible. I have no disagreement, therefore, with the thrust of the motion put forward by the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) but I was a little intrigued when, in canvassing his argument he did not roam over the whole breadth and length of the killing floor. I would have thought that when he was talking about costs-that is a very admirable emphasis in any debate-he would have commented on the fact that the Government of which he is a member, representing a rural electorate, made a decision which resulted in inspection charges in this country increasing by 200 per cent. That is what we are talking about-containing costs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is absolutely irrelevant, as I see it, to expound the pluses of a Government decision without also detailing the minuses. I want very briefly before developing the minuses of the present inspection service to indicate to the honourable member the reasons for the National Party in Victoria exercising a levelling effect on the lower House by its decision in the upper House. Members of the Party were concerned about the lack of discipline contained in the legislation. They were very worried about the fact that the ministerial arrangements gave power to hand over control of product description to the inspection services. Quite obviously there were very good reasons.

I can understand the need and the wish to reduce costs by $2.4m a year, but there were these great reasons for concern. I might say to the honourable member that those reasons for concern were also espoused by the relevant industrial and farmers organisations in the State of Victoria. So in effect the National Party view was a view which was backed by the industry. Our concern about the legislation as it has come into practice is that the present arrangements, in effect, develop a monopoly service. It is a service which, in effect, has shown that it has enormous industrial power. It has very limited accountability. There is far too much emphasis on rights, and it completely disregards responsibilities.

Let us talk about some of the things that the single meat inspection service has done in the very limited time it has been in existence. It can put an embargo on a particular works. In effect, it can break a works which does not bow to its demands. It can cause hold-ups in the operations. I have seen on the killing floor a meat inspector, for no reason at all, pull up the chain, amidst howls and hisses then from his fellow workers, because he sees an imaginary hair on the back of a carcass. All these things, these stops while the chain is in progress, lead to extra costs. We find also that a works might be killing 600 head of cattle a day, 400 for export and 200 for the domestic services. The industrial power of a monopoly service, unchecked and unchallenged, can in effect cause a shortfall in domestic product. Under the previous arrangement, if the Federal inspectors went out, the State inspectors could continue to operate and provide the domestic service. This system does not allow it to happen.

Let us look at what happened in Queensland when the single Federal service took over. The inspectors waited until the next day-they were magnanimous-before they called a strike. It was a strike on the matter of changing their hours of work from 40 hours a week to 38 hours a week. In effect, the day after they took over that service in Queensland there was a strike. We saw what happened at Mudginberri. Inspectors refused to obey a direction from a Federal Minister to cross picket lines at Mudginberri. More importantly, they refused to cross picket lines-imaginary in some instances-elsewhere in Australia at meatworks where the relevant union was not the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union. This is what happens when we have an unrestricted monopoly organisation with tremendous industrial power, backed up and aided and abetted by a government. The union movement saw fit to call out meat inspectors at works which were staffed by unions other than the AMIEU, which had absolutely nothing to do with the Mudginberri dispute.

Let us look at this business of using power to grant a 38-hour week. Obviously it was a sweetheart deal between the union, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Public Service Board and, finally, the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I cannot think of any other such sweetheart deal which indicates a paralysis of the mind. The unions do not want to get on with the job of making Australia once again a competitive country as far as exports are concerned. But what did the inspectors do? Instead of working the 38-hour week, they continued to work their ordinary hours and-wait for it-they had an extra 12 days added on to their annual leave. They still worked the same length of time, the same number of hours a day, but they were given extra annual leave. I cannot think of anything that is more ridiculous. This was at an extra cost of $4m a year to the Australian industry. A Press release from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), dated 25 September 1984, states:
I believe that the plan has the potential to reduce costs by about $12m a year, using the present national export slaughter level of 7 million cattle equivalents as a base . . .

We also find that those decisions were taken without any consultation with the industry. I refer to a confidential document forwarded to the Arbitration Commission. It was argued before the Commission that:

. . . documentation . . . clearly indicated that productivity improvements in EIS amounting to $12m a year were foreshadowed by the Minister for Primary Industry as early as September 1984, well before the 38 hour week agreement was firmed up. Consequently it was a reasonable deduction that the 38 hour week agreement was not the pre-condition to efficiency gains.

It argued that a 38-hour week would cost EIS an extra $4m per year-hardly a cost-saving exercise. So let us not talk about a principle decision in the Victorian Government which is going to cost an extra $2.4m a year while at the same time this Federal Minister is costing the industry an extra $4m a year. Equally important, as this document says, industry was not involved in the drawing up of the agreement and was not adequately consulted. So much for a government which talks about consultation. I am amazed, as I said initially, at what goes on in an organisation which has monopoly powers, backed up by a government which is not strong enough to legally enforce the powers that it has.

We find that these meat inspectors now start work at 6 o'clock in the morning and are paid two hours overtime until the other workers come on at 8 o'clock. Because there is so much idle time they knock off at 2 o'clock in the afternoon and go home, because their part of the inspection procedures has been finalised. I suggest that, if we are interested in cutting costs, we should cut out this idle time. We should say to meat inspectors: `Right, you start at 6 o'clock and you knock off at 2 o'clock. Those are your standard hours of work and no overtime is allowed in this period'. At least then we would be bringing some type of accountability, some type of responsibility, into the system. These are the problems which have emerged. No wonder the cost of dressing a carcass in Australia is $A50 compared to $30 and $25 overseas.

Let us now be constructive. We know the problems. The system has been in operation for sufficient time. There are obviously solutions. Firstly, the Minister must be legally responsible for providing the service. That is terribly important. Too often, as I indicated previously, when he gave an instruction meat inspectors refused to cross a picket line. The Minister must be legally responsible.

I want to make my second point quite clearly, with no mistake and no double talk. We want to declare meat inspection to be an essential service, for logical reasons. First, the meat inspection service is the custodian of health and hygiene. Disease can be spread from beast to man. Secondly, we cannot market meat overseas, either export or domestic, unless a certificate is provided. We have enormous problems with our balance of payments. We have increased competition from overseas. We are talking about reducing our balance of payments. It seems that the Australian Labor Party cannot do much about cutting down imports, but maybe we can improve the balance of payments by increasing our exports and keeping costs down.

If a service is declared essential by the Government, the Government has to stand behind its legislation. Let us give an example. In Queensland we had essential service legislation in the power industry. We had a government which was prepared to stand behind its legislation. What is the net result? Firstly, we have had no strikes. As a Queenslander, I have had plenty of power, like all Queenslanders during the last winter, and, equally importantly, there has been an enormous saving. To summarise, if we have essential service legislation, where it is logical and appropriate to do it, and a government which is prepared to stand behind it, we have no strikes, plenty of service and cost savings. These are the important things that we have to look at when problems emerge from a particular piece of legislation.

Personally, I would like to see the inspection service privatised. I cannot see any sense whatsoever in incurring enormous costs in transferring veterinary officers from point A to point B. It seems to me to be logical, whilst the Government has the responsibility for providing the service, to have local veterinary officers offering their services on a fee for service basis. I was rather intrigued when the honourable member for Calare did not comment on the second part of his motion where he says that constructive steps are being taken with regard to export inspection. Why have an inspection service, as in honey and fresh fruits and vegetables, when the overseas importer does not require it?

This issue is all about costs. The centralised wage-fixing system has over the years been largely responsible for keeping our cost structures above those of our major trading partners. On two aspects fundamental to international competitiveness-cost structures and inflation rates-this Government is proving to be hopelessly inadequate. It has used the prices and incomes accord as an excuse for weakness but the accord cannot cover up for any length of time the structural weakness of the economy and Labor's inability to get the basics right. If it has a legal power it has to get in and exercise that legal power and not run away from it as it did at Mudginberri. It has shown no discipline and no common sense in regard to the problems of Mudginberri and meatworks anywhere else.

It is time we reconciled our policy with today's economic and financial realities. We are becoming less and less competitive with the rest of the world despite the 20 per cent devaluation of the Australian dollar. Here are the facts. Australia, alone among major trading nations, has increased Government expenditure by 6 to 7 per cent in real terms over each of the past two years. It has been alone in abandoning monetary supply targeting. It is the only Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development country with full wage indexation. We have an inflation rate that is almost twice that of our major trading partners and three times that of Japan. We have interest rates at 20 per cent and on the rise compared with less than half of that amount in our competitor, the United States of America. Clearly, other countries can deliver both high growth and wage cost restraint without the need to resort to a rigid, centralised wage system. For example, in 1984 the United States economy grew by 6.8 per cent while labour costs grew by only 2.5 per cent. In Australia our gross domestic product grew by 4.6 per cent and labour costs by 4.1 per cent.

To put it bluntly, Australia's costs are too high, its working hours too short and its productivity too low. That is what is wrong with the meat inspection service. Our rural sector faces low prices abroad and soaring costs at home. It faces transport and wharfage costs well in excess of those of our competitors and a bad reputation for reliability of supply. Our once rich rural sector is struggling to cope, let alone compete in a world economy distorted by subsidies and agricultural trade wars.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to support the General Business motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons). At the outset I will make a few brief comments to recap on some of the background to the national meat inspection service. It has to be said that the responsibility for meat inspection in Australia has historically been divided between the Commonwealth and the States. The Commonwealth traditionally has had responsibility, obviously, for export areas and the States or Territories and, in the past, municipal authorities have had responsibility for the inspection of product which is consumed locally.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the historical context but it has to be emphasised that for many years it has been generally agreed that a single national meat inspection service would be far more efficient than the present cumbersome and outdated arrangements. In some States the means of achieving that single service, and principally, in effect, the question of who will run it, has not been agreed, even though the principle of the need for a single meat inspection has been strongly supported.

The Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry in 1982, following the meat substitution scandal, also endorsed the establishment of a single service concept. Many authorities and importing countries have indicated their support for a single system. There has been, particularly in recent years, growing and strong support for the concept of a single national meat inspection service.

The reasons for that support are very well and logically based. The contribution of the honourable member for Calare was one of the most lucid explanations, the most tightly analytical speeches, that I have heard explaining all the substantial benefits which flow to meat inspection establishments, to States and, inevitably, to primary producers from a single meat inspection service. It was an excellent contribution and it left the contribution by the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), which I will come back to in a few moments, just miles behind.

There are a number of benefits of a single meat inspection service. Perhaps the first and major benefit, as the honourable member for Calare noted, is that it provides for better control over the whole meat chain under one single authority. It provides for increased security of export meat and it provides for a higher level of compliance at one point of contact for all meat inspection. That is absolutely fundamental to standards and export markets. Secondly, a single meat inspection service eliminates the duplication of State inspection and fees in export registered works which also produce for the domestic market. In my own electorate, the Mayfair company, which is a very large establishment, some years ago had an export licence. It was paying out $300,000 a year in inspection charges-double fees in a sense-for its exports which did not even total that amount. In other words, it was penalised by having to have every single animal in that abattoir inspected for export even though only 10 per cent of its total produce was going overseas.

As a result of that arrangement Mayfair was forced to relinquish its export licence. I think that is a disaster for Australia. One more export establishment in this country went under with the old system of double costs and double penalties which, frankly, this country cannot afford. So, as I have said, the second benefit of a single meat inspection service is that it eliminates that duplication. There is a third benefit. It also provides for a much more efficient use of staff. It reduces duplication and it eliminates demarcation disputes across domestic and export operations. As the honourable member for Calare pointed out in his excellent contribution, the experience to date shows that staff savings can result in cost savings of 10 per cent.

I want to get on to the question of Victoria, because this motion refers to encouraging the Commonwealth Government and the State governments in their efforts in bringing about a single meat inspection service. As the honourable member for Calare pointed out, many States have made agreements with the Commonwealth. In Victoria we have a fascinating but appalling situation. The Victorian Government is supportive and enthusiastic and concurs with the Commonwealth on the need for a single meat inspection service and has passed legislation in the lower House, the House of Assembly. I think it is a matter of great regret to this Government and to this Parliament that last Tuesday night in the upper House in Victoria the combined forces of the Liberal Party and more importantly, I think, the National Party, voted against this legislation, effectively to sink it.

What that means is that that legislation, that proposal for a single meat inspection service in Victoria has bitten the dust. It has bitten the dust because of the blatant opportunism of the Liberal and National parties in the upper House in Victoria. That unrepresentative upper House, the members of which talk of democracy, of the State's interests and of representing farmers, on Tuesday night sunk a proposal put up by the Victorian and Commonwealth Governments that would have saved Victoria $2.4m. A saving of $2.4m per annum in inspection fees is not chicken feed.

The fact is that the National Party in the upper House in Victoria simply caved in to unrepresentative vested interests in that State. The effect will be that it will cost Victorian producers-farmers, the people who produce the livestock that goes to the abattoirs-more than $2m. There is substantial evidence, which has been documented, that the costs incurred in abattoirs are effectively passed backwards in lower market prices for produce. What it means is that Victorian farmers next year, in 1986, will be getting $2m a year less in the market place for their produce-their fat lambs, their pigs, their steers and their vealers-than they would otherwise would have got.

At a time when farmers are struggling because international markets have been corrupted by the European Economic Community, when they need every dollar of income they can get, I think it is an absolute disgrace that the National Party in Victoria should oppose this legislation and effectively make the farmers of Victoria lose $2m of revenue that they otherwise would have got. What we have seen is just a flagrant capitulation by the National Party in Victoria to vested business interests which will cost Victorian farmers $2m next year. I just cannot condemn that decision enough.

I want to say just a few brief things about some of the arguments-if I could be generous enough to call them arguments-that the National Party and, to a lesser extent, the Liberals in Victoria put up in the upper House to oppose this single meat inspection service. They basically said that they are concerned about two things. First, they are concerned about State safeguards and, secondly, they are concerned about union power or domination.

Let me look at the question of State safeguards. Under the national meat inspection proposal there are considerable safeguards for States which join with the Commonwealth in this single arrangement. The States will retain sole responsibility for the licensing of domestic works, for the standards of construction and equipment in domestic works, for the setting of standards for domestic inspection and for the setting of individual State requirements for the preparation of domestic meat. They are the State safeguards.

It belies all of the logic, all of the careful analysis in the world to stand up in the Upper House in Victoria and say that one is worried about State safeguards and State rights when clearly under this legislation every right of a State to licence or set standards in its domestic establishments will be totally and absolutely safeguarded. What a lot of rot the National Party and Liberal Party in Victoria have come up with. There is absolutely no credence at all to their claims.

I go to the second matter which they purport to be a reason for rejecting this legislation which, as I have said, will cost Victorian farmers $2m a year. They have talked about the problem of union domination or power because of the formation of a single service. They have argued that there will be too much power in the hands of a single union. I shall make a few points about that because that is one of the most puerile and banal arguments that I have heard in this whole debate. The National Party would do itself a favour if it came up with its real reason for opposing this legislation. It is because of its arrangements-if I can call it that-with a certain business interest in the abattoir industry in Victoria. The National Party is very close to that organisation and frankly, it just has not had the guts to stand up for farmers in Victoria.

Let us look at the union question. Firstly, the record shows that the Commonwealth Meat Inspectors Association is a responsible union and has always preferred conciliation to disputation. I make the second point that as part of the 38 hour week package, the Meat Inspectors Association recently entered into an agreement, ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which includes a dispute settling arrangement. I emphasise that the arrangement provides that work continues while disputes are being resolved. In other words, there is no disruption to the industry.

The third point I make is that in the past, where the Commonwealth Meat Inspectors Association has been involved in industrial disputes with the potential of affecting domestic inspection, it has taken action consistently, time and again, to ensure that product supply to consumers is totally unaffected.

I make a fourth point. The Meat Inspectors Association and, as far as I know, every other union in the industry, is affiliated with the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Accordingly it needs to be stressed, industrial action which affects domestic production is unlikely to be taken by the MIA in circumstances where it would not have been taken by State unions. That is an obvious point.

Finally, I want to make a point over Mudginberri. New South Wales already has a single meat inspection service with the Commonwealth. It has had that for some time. It has saved costs of the order of 19 per cent. In respect of Mudginberri, New South Wales, where the Meat Inspectors Association carries out all domestic inspection, was totally unaffected by industrial action. So this claimed union domination, this union myth that, if there is a single meat inspection service, the union will suddenly bring our abattoirs to a close, is just a figment of the imagination of the National Party and the Liberal Party.

I conclude by saying that I did not find the contribution of the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) very informative. He asked why we need export inspection at all, he talked about privatisation, he talked about--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker--
—Order! If the honourable member for Groom feels he is being misrepresented, he can raise that at a later time.

—We will stand up and do that to the blokes on the other side too; it is very constructive. The terms of this motion congratulate the Commonwealth Government and those State governments who have worked towards the introduction of single meat inspection services. We have heard from the honourable member for Calare of how many States and Territories in the Commonwealth have already entered into agreements, or will introduce agreements early next year which provide for single meat inspection services. There are savings to producers and to abattoirs of in excess of 10 per cent per annum through the single meat inspection service. There are improvements in productivity; there is the likelihood of fewer industrial disputes over demarcation problems. There is a range of benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite that, despite the support by the Victorian Government, the democratically elected government in Victoria, for a single meat inspection service, we had the scandalous situation last Tuesday night when the National Party and the Liberal Party voted to veto this legislation. The effect of that is that Victorian farmers who need every dollar they can get will be robbed next year, in 1986, of $2m of extra sales at market places. The reason they are being robbed of $2m is the National Party's flagrant capitulation to vested business interests over this whole issue. I repeat that it will cost farmers $2m next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Very briefly, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), in the concluding part of his speech, indicated that I had said I was not in favour of any inspection services at all. What I clearly and definitely said was: Why have an inspection service in cases like honey, fresh vegetables and fruit where the overseas importer does not require them? I did not say that there is no need for any inspection services at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) in his very carefully worded remarks about the Export Inspection Service. I challenge the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) to take his speech back to Bendigo and present it to his local meatworks, argue the case with them on the ground, and talk about the costs that he so carefully put forward. We are talking about monopoly control of the meat inspection services. I compliment the upper House in Victoria for withstanding the pressure to have meat inspection services throughout Australia being under the total Federal control. In Victoria we have a bench mark, first of all, to establish the costing and, secondly, to make sure that the service in question will not be union dominated from a Federal source.

SPEECH.PARA: The historical background of the meat inspection services, which shows the number of people involved in the industry, makes very interesting reading. An Industries Assistance Commission report in 1983 indicated that the meat industry was seriously depressed at that time and likely to remain so. We know that the meat industry has improved a little in recent times because of the devaluation of the dollar. However, the number of meat inspectors employed by the meat inspection service during this time, when there was a change in the industry, make an interesting comparison. At the peak years of 1976-77, 1,616 meat inspectors were employed. In the peak years of 1978-79, 1,794 inspectors were employed and, although cattle numbers have now declined, in 1982-83 we still had 1,632 inspectors employed. I challenge both the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and the honourable member for Bendigo, to say where these inspectors have gone, what they are doing and whether they are effectively employed in the service. The number of cattle in Australia has been reduced from the peak figure of 33 million to some 22 million and we still have the same number of meat inspectors.

I turn to the position of Mudginberri where the Federal inspection service, in a monopoly position, was supposed to undertake inspection services on behalf of the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin). The meat inspection personnel were sympathetic with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in their dispute with Mr Pendarvis over the tally system. The Minister, in this House and in the execution of his duties as Minister failed to instruct the meat inspectors to break the picket line and inspect the meat for export to gain revenue to that works. The inspection service was set up to look after all export work throughout Australia, and at Mudginberri it was flagrantly abusing its charter to inspect all meat.

The honourable member for Bendigo was using figures to try to demonstrate that inspection services were more efficient and more cost effective in Victoria. I draw the House's attention to the comparison in the figures. The Federal contribution to cattle slaughter inspection charges is $2.55 per head and the producer's contribution is $2.55 per head, making a total cost of $5.10. The State meat inspection service or a similar service charge is $3.36 per head and there is a 25 per cent contribution by producers of 84c per head, making a total of $4.20. That quite clearly demonstrates that a cheaper service is being provided by the Victorian Department of Agriculture compared with the Federal inspection service. These figures are substantiated by the Meat Wholesalers Association of Victoria.

The other problem that was discussed by the meat industry was the fact that a dual meat inspection was being carried on in export abattoirs. That was removed by mutual consent, saving $900,000. So that particular argument of efficiency no longer applies. Also, if we look at the figures for Western Australia, we see that the local authority meat inspection charges are $3.60 per head and are coming down to $3.20. The Commonwealth charges are $2.55 plus the 50 per cent contribution of $2.55 from the producers. We see from the figures for Western Australia and Victoria that the costs are lower at the local level.

In answer to a question that I placed on notice on 28 February, the Minister himself quite clearly demonstrated the total cost of the Federal meat inspection service. In that answer, recorded in Hansard, he reported that in Victoria it cost $11.9m for a 10 month period up to April. That figure, if extended to represent an annual cost, would be $14m, which would cover 8.4 million units. Let us make a comparison between those figures and the State figures. The State inspection service was able to inspect 17 million units at a cost of $9m. I challenge the honourable member for Bendigo to take up these figures when he suggests that the Federal inspection service is cheaper than the State service.

The honourable member for Bendigo referred to the 38-hour week matter. He made a great play of the fact that there was a no-strike clause in the agreement. We found that that did not operate too well at Mudginberri and other export works around Australia. The key feature in the 38-hour week proposal by the meat inspectors was that they did not, in fact, have a reduction in working hours to 38 hours; they had 12 days extra leave. That was the award agreed to, which means that meat inspectors around Australia will not be available for 12 extra days. That will cost the meat industry $4m extra. I would like to quote this morning's Stock and Land editorial on this issue. Obviously, this motion has been brought forward in this House because of the Victorian upper House's very firm desire to maintain a competitive meat service. The Stock and Land had this to say:

A handover is often a simple solution to a more complex issue. The question still remains whether the simple solution would have been the best solution for both cost purposes and efficiency of service.

Because the Department of Primary Industry is responsible for domestic meat inspections in both South Australia and New South Wales it is not a sound enough reason why Victoria should follow suit. Victoria is unique; it has far more domestic meat works and export works than New South Wales where a majority of meat works are killing for both domestic and export orders.

Victorian processors and farmers know full well that the Commonwealth is offering a carrot. . . a reduction of the existing domestic fee, which it says will only recover 50 per cent of the cost of services. They are entitled to ask how long this subsidy on meat inspection will last.
The other intriguing issue in the hand over debate is why hand over an efficient service to a Commonwealth service which was so heavily indicted in the meat substitution scandal of 1980.
There we have it, the Stock and Land in Victoria supporting the position of the upper House to hold the meat inspection services.

I draw the House's attention to the union pressure to which the meat industry is subjected in Victoria. On 11 October Mr Wally Curran, who is a well known personality in the Victorian meat industry and I think a personal friend of the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), spoke about the meat industry in Victoria. A Press report stated:

. . . employers would pay one way or another for the $100,000 fine imposed on the union for contempt of court, said the meat employees union. Union Victorian secretary Wally Curran said a week-long strike was planned at the peak of the Victorian spring season.
He said the action would cost employers up to 20 days production and overload the market, forcing meat prices down and reducing farmers' profits.
The union was fined for contempt after it refused to lift pickets at the Mudginberri abattoir in the Northern Territory during the continuing dispute with the abattoir owners.

That is the attitude of the meat workers union and Mr Curran. We can see the result of having a monopoly position by the inspectors who work in sympathy with the meat workers union. I have here a comment by the Victorian shadow Minister, Mr Austin, who totally agrees with my position. He says, along the same lines:
Wally Curran of the meat workers Union is watching this Bill with great interest because this would give his union the whip hand.
One inspection service throughout Australia would mean that if the Federal Export Inspection Service were to strike, all meat works in Victoria would be shut down.
I ask the honourable member for Bendigo to refute that proposition. Mr Austin continued:
There are only 4 export works in Victoria and about 100 local abattoirs and other licensed premises.
It is well-known that Mr Curran likes to have his members in and around Melbourne, and he does not have the same control over those who work in the country.

Finally, I say that Victoria is lucky that the people voted to maintain a break on the excesses of the socialist Government by voting Mrs Rosemary Varty in at the Nunawading by-election. The upper House has exercised its control in a responsible manner by maintaining the meat inspection service which I have clearly indicated with the figures is effective and efficient and does a very good job. It will provide a benchmark for costing so that the excesses of the Federal inspection system will not go unchecked. This provides the possibility of producing a more flexible wages system, as we have seen demonstrated in the Mudginberri exercise. Also, in New South Wales, Charles David Pty Ltd, which is attempting to open a new meatworks, is looking for efficiency on the part of the meatworkers and the meat inspection system. I totally reject the motion and support the Victorian Opposition in its attempts to maintain a very effective and efficient meat inspection system in that State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise quite happily to support the motion moved by my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) and so ably supported by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) in his very precise comments about this industry. I must say that I speak with some knowledge on this issue because I have four major meat processing works, one of them a major export works, right in the heart of my electorate in places such as Kyneton, Castlemaine and Daylesford.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to the position of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh), I am right there on the ground where the action is happening and I understand what is going on in the meat inspection industry.
