I am aware of what has now happened in Victoria through this idiotic decision of the Victorian upper House to reject a proposal to streamline the meat inspection service. It is almost so ridiculous as to be unbelievable.

The national inspection service is a major initiative and it will bring considerable benefit to the whole industry-to producers who have been badly looking for improved performance and markets so that their products have somewhere to go, to processors who are looking for more efficiency and lower costs and, of course, to the consumer. Both domestic consumers and export consumers are looking for quality and competition in the industry. I think those points are sometimes forgotten by honourable members on the other side of the House when they rise to oppose, simply for the sake of opposition, quite beneficial and wise moves to deregulate the areas of industry that affect the agricultural sector so badly.

I make the point too, that this action by the States and the Federal Government to bring into being a single national meat inspection service arises from the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry which came about from the scandals relating to horse and kangaroo meat substitution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was in government then?

—Yes, who was in government then? We have heard from honourable members on the other side of the House during this debate that the farm sector is constantly told by its representatives that wages and industrial relations in meat processing centres are the cause of their failing export markets. The farm sector is never told. Let no one underestimate the irreparable damage done to the red meat markets.
—Where are they?

—As the honourable member for Bendigo asks, where are they? They have left the House now that we are talking some facts about this matter. They do not tell anybody about the irreparable damage done to the red meat markets of Australia by the actions of the kangaroo and horse meat substituters, under their government. Let no one underestimate the damage that was done. I commend the Government for its prompt action on the findings of the Royal Commission, in a report that was not pigeon-holed, but promptly acted on by the Labor Government in the real interests of the agricultural sector. I commend the Federal Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for his approach to deregulating all those areas that have imposed so many costs on the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: As everyone in this House will realise, it is not easy to bring together the States and the Commonwealth in a uniform approach, as we have experienced in Victoria. Because of sectional and, in fact, absurd parochial interests, the National Party which claims to represent the interests of farmers, has voted to leave Victoria on the outer while the meat processing industry in other States benefits from this action by the Federal Government to co-ordinate the activities of the meat inspection service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Bjelke-Petersen.

—Yes, even Bjelke-Petersen agrees, as my colleague the honourable member for Calare points out. Given that the Victorian Labor Government in the lower House was totally supportive of Minister Kerin, we have an example here of State Labor governments in several States acting co-operatively with the Federal Labor Government to bring about efficiencies for the rural sector. I predict that that message will not be lost on South Australian voters in the next couple of weeks. The national meat inspection service-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 109 as amended for this session, the debate on the motion is interrupted.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the time for discussion of Notice No. 1, General Business, be extended until 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying, that message will not be lost on South Australian voters shortly. The national meat inspection service initiative is a positive step. It is not just words; it is a very measureable and tangible benefit flowing directly to Australian provincial and rural industry through the activities of this Government. I think that is to be commended, and I commend my colleague the honourable member for Calare on his initiative in bringing forward this motion. Already, through these initiatives, we have seen savings to the industry of some $5m. We have seen the New South Wales domestic service make savings of some 60 per cent in staff costs. We have seen considerable efficiencies and economies achieved that have enabled Commonwealth inspection charges to be held at 1984-85 levels.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to comment also on industrial relations. The honourable member for Groom made some mention of this issue; the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) wandered on to the topic, too. It has been mentioned earlier that producers-I accept this-are very sensitive to the handling of their produce. It is an area that is totally out of their control once the produce reaches the meat processing centre. It is out of their control, yet it affects their viability and livelihood. This Government has taken a very positive initiative in bringing industrial relations in the meat industry to a much better level. We believe that consensus beats confrontation any time. I am very pleased to support the honourable member for Bendigo in his outline of the way in which the new industrial relations package for the meat inspection service has been brought together.

The Government is not satisfied yet. There are more efficiencies and economies that we are looking for. We are looking for ways of making further self-regulation possible. We are looking for ways in which the industry can modify its present operating and commercial practices to cut back further on inspection costs. For instance, we are looking at speeds on the chain and forward planning of slaughtering operations to bring forward those benefits. We are talking action to break down barriers, not build them.

I should, in making that point, mention the Government's primary and provincial affairs committee, which has been formed specifically by the Cabinet to ensure that members of this Government-there are some 21 of them who represent rural Australia-are collectively working together to ensure that our policies work well in country areas. We have recently had talks with the National Farmers Federation, and the feedback to me is that that organisation has been pretty impressed with the level of expertise shown on this side of the House on country and provincial matters. I notice that there is no mention of this issue in a set of policy briefs that I have received from the NFF concerning meat inspection. I can only take that as a measure of the Federation's satisfaction with what has happened and with the directions that the Government has taken. I think that is good.

As my colleague the honourable member for Bendigo said, we have just one problem. All that has been good news. There is one black spot on the horizon-where? Down in Victoria, due to the actions of the Victorian National Party in the upper House in blocking this legislation. As the Victorian Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs, Mr Evan Walker, said, here we had a situation where the Commonwealth offered us a more efficient cost-effective service that has already been accepted by other States, including New South Wales and South Australia. Victorian farmers are now disadvantaged because of the Liberal and National Party Opposition's intransigence. There is no other way to express it, and one wonders how that can have come about.

I noticed in the House just a few days ago that my colleague the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) asked a question of the Minister for Primary Industry on this issue. He saw the problem in Victoria arising and he saw the writing on the wall, that the opportunists would succeed in the upper House over those representing rural farmers' interests. The Minister, in his reply to the question asked by the honourable member for Ballarat, said that the immediate cost benefits to the Victorian industry would be some $2.4m per annum. How an Opposition can vote in the upper House to pass up $2.4m worth of savings to farmers and meat processers leaves me staggered. We can only hope that someone will come to his senses down there, that the matter will be reintroduced in the State Parliament and that those benefits will flow on to the Victorian rural sector.

I noticed that an Opposition member of the Victorian upper House who voted against this move by the Government is retiring early next year from the Central Highlands Province. Victorian provincial farmers in Central Highlands just might have an opportunity to let people know what they think of that sort of a move.

I commend the Minister for his prompt action on the Royal Commission report. I believe that the co-operative approach that has been established between the States and the Federal Government is to be commended. I abhor the actions of the Victorian upper House Opposition in its short-sighted and opportunistic decision to oppose what every other State has leapt to join the Federal Governmnent in, and I note the substantial savings and efficiencies which are coming to the industry as a whole, except in Victoria, through this formation of a single national meat inspection service. I commend the honourable member for Calare for bringing this motion forward in the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak on this motion by the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simons) I would like first of all to take up a couple of points made by the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) and the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby). The honourable member for Bendigo went to some length to put a case for a single meat inspection service which probably in theory was a very plausible case. What he failed to recognise is that in practice this has not worked nearly as well as it should have and the Government has not faced up to some of the real shortcomings that are presently in the Export Inspection Service. If he is so concerned about what is happening in Victoria and what happened this week, I think he ought to read the editorial of the Stock and Land which my colleage the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) read out a few minutes ago. I think that sums up very sensibly why the upper House would not be conned into what the Cain socialist Government was trying to do. On the question of savings-perceived savings might be a better word; I think the member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) has already pointed out what the Commonwealth Export Inspection Service has just had to pay out or will have to pay out because of the 38-hour week issue-it talks about a saving of $2m or thereabouts. As I recall it, the Victorian Labor Government spent well over $2m in advertising to try to win the Nunawading by-election. The fact that it failed I think shows that the people of Victoria were not conned and they wanted the right to have an upper House which could put a break on some of the excesses of the State Government in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Bendigo made some assertion about the National Party in Victoria but he would not actually allude to what it was. I suggest that he ought to put up or shut up because one does not want to make such statements and not carry them through.

I suggest to the honourable member for Burke that his gratuitous comments about knowing all about meatworks because he has some in his electorate overlook the fact that there are many other honourable members in this chamber who have meatworks in their electorates. In particular, there are meatworks in both the electorate of the honourable member for Corangamite and my seat of Wannon. To say that he is the only one who knows what is going on is a little misleading. The honourable member for Burke said he could not understand why the Victorian upper House rejected the move to a single inspection authority. I suggest that he should at least have listened to the speaker before him, the honourable member for Corangamite, because he would have found out why it was such a sensible vote.

I will just go through a few points on the motion moved by the honourable member for Calare. It seems that he spends quite a bit of time congratulating himself, congratulating his Government and congratulating his State colleagues. But I would ask, who is he kidding? Who is really getting an advantage and who is really gaining? Is the Government doing a service to a great export industry, an export industry that is earning Australia something like $1.6 billion a year in export income? Is centralising meat inspection really helping the industry?

I think the honourable member for Corangamite has already outlined some of the weaknesses in the Export Inspection Service and the additional costs that the Federal service has over the very efficient State one. The Export Inspection Service at the moment does have some real problems in the level of costs and the level of inefficiency. The Government is trying to have one centralised service, creating a monopoly out of a service which is already considerably over-staffed. I think anyone who has spoken to people in the industry will have found that over-staffing is a great problem. We have only to look at a few simple facts to realise why it is such a problem.

If we look at the level of export inspection service back in 1978 we will find that there were nearly 1,600 meat inspectors. Today we find that there are nearly 1,800 meat inspectors in the federal inspection service. In fact, there has been an increase-quite a big increase-of well over 100. As the honourable member for Corangamite has already pointed out, the number of livestock in Australia has fallen, particularly in the beef industry. In fact, it has fallen by nearly one-third since 1978. We have an amazing situation in that the number of livestock has fallen, the number of stock being slaughtered has fallen proportionately and yet the meat inspection service has more staff today than it had back in 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —Scandalous.

—As the honourable member for Wakefield says, it is scandalous. Quite obviously, there is growing inefficiency and considerable cost. We have already seen the move to the 38-hour week, which was nothing more than an excuse to get another 12 days holiday pay. It may be great to talk about a single inspection service but in practice we are seeing that this one is not proving to be very effective.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Groom spoke about the problems of Mudginberri. I would just like to reiterate a couple of points that he made. We had a situation there where the meat inspectors refused to `cross the picket line'. I put those words in inverted commas because in fact they were living at the works and did not actually have to cross the picket line. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) directed them to work, he claims, on three occasions, yet they refused to do so. But what did he do about it? He said `It is too hard', and he walked away from it. Because of this $2.8m worth of export contracts were lost. The Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has paid fairly dearly for it, nonetheless this highlights just one of the weaknesses in the present system.

As my time is running very short I would just like to touch on one or two other points. There is no doubt that the present Export Inspection Service leaves a lot to be desired. It is very inefficient. The Government should be aware of this. It talks about forward planning and so on, but in fact it is all talk. At the moment, in practice we are getting no results. The number of meat inspectors is increasing while the number of stock being slaughtered is falling. I think that for honourable members opposite to talk about the virtues of a centralised system overlooks what has been shown in Victoria, that a very efficient service can operate at a very much lower cost. So I think rather than congratulating itself, the Government should have a good look at the meat inspection service and see what it can do to address some of the efficiency problems and the overstaffing. When it has done that it might have some reason to come into this place and crow about what a terrific job it has done for the meat inspection service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite surprised to get this opportunity to speak on this motion. I must congratulate the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) on his fine motion. We all know very much how he looks after the industry. In this small amount of time--

Does the Attorney-General still maintain, as he did earlier this week, that it would be appropriate to use the Bill of Rights legislation to change the electoral systems of Western Australia and Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked a question earlier this week, to which I replied, as to whether the imbalance in one of the upper House provinces of Western Australia, to the extent of 11:1, would be in conflict with the intentions of the Bill of Rights. I said in reply that article 25 of the Bill of Rights had an obligation to what was called universal equal suffrage. In my view, universal equal suffrage does not permit an intolerance or imbalance of 11:1. Therefore, it would be appropriate for a court to determine that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The way for a court to do so would be if there were no such Bill of Rights in Western Australia or an appropriate piece of legislation here pursuant to the international covenant to say that not only in Western Australia but also in all elections in Australia, both Federal and State, there should be compliance with the international covenant on the basis of universal equal suffrage. If that matter were the subject of legal debate in the High Court of Australia, it could well be that the High Court would say that the distribution, particularly in Western Australia and also in Queensland, was contrary to the Bill of Rights. That was what I said.

I am aware of the fact, and I have no objection to it, that the Premier of Western Australia feels that Western Australians will be able to solve their own electoral problems. I am sure they will, and I am sure also that he will win the next State election; there is no risk about that. In winning it he will be fortified by the fact that the average Western Australian knows that there is electoral injustice in Western Australia which cannot be corrected because the upper House there will not allow that to be done.

Further, they are also aware of the fact that when the Premier suggested to Western Australians that they might have a vote of their own people to see whether there should be electoral reform in that State, the upper House indicated that it would not approve of such legislation. I think that adds a lot to Premier Burke's chance of being re-elected with an even greater and substantial majority, and I am very pleased about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about having a referendum on the human rights Bill?

—From the point of view of human rights, the people in Western Australia recognise that when it comes to electing the upper House they are not being given democratic rights. Premier Burke, as a senior member of our Party, is a pretty fair politician and is able to judge public opinion in Western Australia. I make it very clear that if Premier Burke is satisfied to remain Premier of Western Australia, I also am satisfied for him to remain Premier.
—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs inform the House of current developments in relation to South Africa, including the Commonwealth Group of Eminent Persons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker-
—You had better be careful. Dawkins is after your job.
—My good parliamentary friend Petomaine is trying to rasp out some sort of message. I did not quite hear it.
—I said that Dawkins was after your job.
—Order! The Minister should not invite the honourable member to interject.

—I certainly would not have knowingly sought to embarrass the Minister for Trade by asking the member for Denison to repeat that sort of comment. I make it clear that the Minister for Trade and I are good mates. He is a mate of mine from Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Very much as I have discovered in the last month or so that I have a similar good mate in Victoria, and they no doubt join a great phalanx of mates from New South Wales. I appropriately recall the words of the late Jimmy Durante: `Everybody wants to get in on the act'. It is a hard act to follow.

ANSWER.PARA: I have seen reports that Kim Hughes has expressed his disappointment at what he calls a boycott by the Australian Embassy in Pretoria of rebel cricket matches. Mr Hughes accuses the Government of hypocrisy, saying that he looks forward to returning home so that he can let people know what is really happening in South Africa. I think we have to ask questions as to whether Mr Hughes would be in a position to be able to report on the internal affairs in South Africa.

First of all, according to Dr Bacher, President of the South African Cricket Union, the situation in South Africa is too complex to allow Australian cricketers to be allowed to comment on it. Mr Hughes, according to the reports, has contractually undertaken not to make any comment about conditions in South Africa.

I find it hard to believe that Mr Hughes would be in any position to tell the Australian public anything about the real situation in South Africa. He stays in comfortable hotels in white areas and he plays largely before white crowds. It is questionable whether the rebels will have been able or permitted to see the violence and squalor of many black townships, or indeed have had any opportunity to talk to the black community which feels so strongly opposed to the tour.

While the rebels play, the level of violence in townships continues. In the past four months since the South African Government declared a state of emergency the number of people killed has increased sharply. The South African Institute of Race Relations reported only this week that in the period from 1 January to 21 July 1985, some 335 people lost their lives in township unrest. In the period since 21 July, the Press has reported that the death toll may be as high as 400. There are few signs that the violence in black townships is easing or that the South African Government is prepared to move boldly and decisively on political reform.

In reply to the other part of the honourable member's question, the Eminent Persons Group proposed at the Commonwealth Head of Government Meeting has now been established and was announced by the Commonwealth Secretary-General on 25 November. We, the Government, welcome the establishment of the Group, and I trust that this is also true of the Opposition. The initiative has the support of all Commonwealth countries and can make a singularly valuable contribution to assisting the process of dialogue that is so urgently needed in South Africa. The initiative was put in place by the Prime Minister of Australia, and I think that we can all feel some pleasure and pride at that action. It is to be hoped that the South African Government will recognise the Group as a genuine attempt to contribute to peaceful change in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Science aware of the W. D. Scott and Co. Pty Ltd recommendations for a review of the trade measurement system? Does this report recommend a transfer of all responsibilities to a centralised national system and full cost recovery from small business and others by way of an annual licence fee? Further, is it a fact that the costs involved would be approximately $15m for implementation, plus $5m per annum minimum annual operating costs, resulting in a $20 per instrument annual licence fee? In the light of the fact that centralised meat inspection costs three times local government charges and has escalated 75 per cent under this Government, does the Minister support these recommendations to add to this additional cost to small business, along with the current 20 per cent interest rates?
—The final report made seven major recommendations and 26 detailed recommendations.
—What are they?

—Do you want me to give them all? An interdepartmental committee has considered the recommendations. It was agreed that Government officials would meet with private sector representatives to provide them with an opportunity to express their views. That meeting was held in August. A meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory officials was held later that month to consider the outcome of the meeting. Uniformity of legislation or its interpretation between States and Territories has been identified by all interested parties as being of most importance; it will require State legislation as well. Trade measurements tend to be enforced at the State level rather than the Commonwealth level. The officials had a further meeting in November 1985. The agreement is that the Committee will report to Ministers-that is, to me and the State Ministers-within six months. The matter will then go before Cabinet but no decision will be made before that. The factors raised by the honorable member for O'Connor, I assure him, will be thoroughly taken into account.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND ISLANDER BROADCASTING AND COMMUNICATIONS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the attention of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs a statement made last evening by the honorable member for Bradfield in commenting on the tabling of the Government's response to the report of the task force on Aboriginal and Islander broadcasting and communications. He stated:

QUESTION.PARA: Perhaps over the last three years the Minister and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs have been so obsessed with aspects of the Aboriginal land rights issue that many of the key elements relating to education and the general welfare of the Aboriginal communities, especially in the outstation areas, which are obviously most related to this report, have in many respects received less attention than perhaps was their due.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honorable member should come to his question.
—I certainly will, Mr Speaker. Having related that to the Minister, I ask: Can the Minister advise the House as to the accuracy of these perceptions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I heard the statement made by the honourable member for Bradfield and I regret it because I think that while the honourable member has been shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he has endeavoured to apply himself to the facts of the situation. Unfortunately, I suppose because of the pressure of work, he was unable to acquaint himself with all the material. One of the distinguishing features of the newly formed Opposition under its present leadership, one of the single facts that emerge, is that if it thinks it can score a point it will never allow an assertion, whether true or false, to be encumbered by any reference to the facts. The evidence that is available with respect to the two assertions which are continually trotted out by members of the Opposition is this: The Government is so concerned about land rights that it does not attend to basic necessities such as health, education and the basic services that need to be applied to Aboriginal communities. That is assertion one, which is false.

ANSWER.PARA: The second assertion is that the cost of administering the Department of Aboriginal Affairs means that so much of the funds that are allocated for the benefit of Aboriginal people never get to them. I would like to deal with this matter. All of the facts are set out and are available to any member of the Opposition if he wants to check the recently tabled report of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. Let us look at the evidence. Under the Fraser Government and when this Government came to office there were 27 Aboriginal medical services. Now there are 46 such services. The number of Aboriginal communities participating in community development employment schemes in the last year of the Fraser Government was 19.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said that you were going to scrap them.

—We hear from a shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs who lasted less than 12 months. He was sacked. I know that the facts hurt but the Opposition has to face them. In the last year of the coalition Government there were 19 such services and now 34 are provided for Aboriginal communities. Often in my portfolio I am bedevilled by State rights. I never thought that the provision of electricity or water supply services was the responsibility of the Commonwealth; I always believed it was the function of the States. In the last year of the Fraser Government $2.1m was spent on the provision of those services. This financial year, under the Hawke Government, $13m is being spent. I turn to housing, which honourable gentlemen opposite, who have no regard for the facts, say is being neglected. In the last year of the Fraser Government the budget for Aboriginal housing was $41.5m. This year, under the Hawke Government, it is $54m. At the time the Fraser Government lost office the Government was supporting 22 outstation projects. At the moment we are supporting 59 outstation projects. The Government has now moved into the area of remote broadcasting and television services and record sums are being expended in that area. I turn to administration.
—Make a statement.
—I do not want to take up the time of the House making a statement. The facts are there and the Opposition will not read them and it will not think about them. Let me deal with the other-
—Make a statement.
—The right honourable member would not listen anyway.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting. I call the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, who I trust will conclude his answer.

—Mr Speaker, with great respect, I would like to develop one other point and again it is a matter of fact. It has been alleged continually as a throw-away line by members such as the honourable member for O'Connor that funds do not get to Aboriginal communities because they are absorbed in the administrative costs of the Department. The fact is that if honourable members look at the annual report of the Department they will see that its administrative costs were 10.15 per cent of its total budget. Any analysis would show that at no stage in the history of the Department has the figure ever gone above 12.7 per cent. It is interesting to note that the occasion when it went to 12.7 per cent was in the last year of the Fraser Government.

—Does the Minister for Social Security recall responding recently to my long time request for details of the value of assets held by people who returned their assets form and as a result had their pensions cancelled? Will he now concede that the millionaires the Government used to justify the introduction of the assets test represent 0.1 per cent of these cancellations while 53 per cent of the former recipients possessed less than $200,000 in assets at the end of their working lives and almost 80 per cent of all those who lost their pension were below or well below the $250,000 level?
—Order! The honourable member for Moreton should come to his question. He has the call for a question, not a statement.

—Will the Minister agree that the Government's pro-assets test campaign has been exposed as disgracefully dishonest by his Department's own figures, and will he apologise to those thousands of elderly non-millionaires who have had to go through the trauma of suddenly rearranging their lives at the twilight of their years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather surprised that under the new Howard administration of the Opposition we should return to this question because we hear nothing from the Opposition more than that in the area of social security we ought to be devoting ourselves to those most in need and indeed that there are people who do not deserve to receive payments who are currently receiving them. I think that if we are going to go down this track we have to be consistent. The reality with respect to the assets test is that its impact is on people with quite substantial assets. I have cited the case of millionaires. I ask the honourable member for Moreton whether he believes that people who are millionares or people with assets and curtilage around their home of more than $200,000 whatever percentage of the population they represent; I think he said the figure was 50 per cent ought to be competing for scarce resources with the hundreds of thousands of people, and particularly the hundreds of thousands of children, in this country who are living in desperate poverty.

ANSWER.PARA: Governments do, as a matter of fact, have to make relatively tough decisions. I suppose what distinguishes this Government from the previous administration is that it has been prepared to make some tough decisions with respect to its expenditure. Also it has been prepared to put that money into seeking to alleviate the most desperate poverty within this country. It is very interesting, when one reflects on the expenditure priorities of the previous Government, to look at who suffered under that Government. Additional pensions and benefits for children declined by 34 per cent during the Fraser years. The mother's-guardian's allowance also declined by more than 34 per cent. One can kick people in this community, but to kick poor women and poor kids seems to me to be taking politics a bit far.

Let us take the question of the unemployment benefit. After the Leader of the Opposition climbed down from his attack on people on the unemployment benefit and the supporting parent's benefit the other day he said that he thought the level of benefit might be adequate. Under the Liberals, the decline in the single rate of adult unemployment benefit was 18.6 per cent. The decline in the rate of the junior benefit was 45.6 per cent. This is what conservative administration means: It means that millionaires get pensions and poor women and children get kicked.

In terms of our stewardship, we have nothing to hide. Additional pensions and benefits for children have gone up 60 per cent-from $10 to $16. The mother's-guardian's allowance has gone up from $6 to $12. The single adult unemployment benefit has gone up more than 40 per cent. The people who everyone in the welfare community acknowledges are poor have received additional assistance. Certainly we have had to make some decisions to ensure that resources are available. That is why the new administration in the organisational wing of the Liberal Party was rather less sympathetic to the kinds of views that were expressed by the honourable member for Moreton and indeed often represented by many members on the other side of the House. Mr Valder said:

So if you are really talking about reducing government spending, it is all very well to say we will privatise this and we will do that, and fiddle about. That's all fiddling with the edges. If you are really going to make any big reduction in government spending-there are areas which you have to look at.
He went on to say that he believed, if we are going to move in that direction, that the assets test is a justifiable direction to move in.

There is a great deal of thinking to be done on the Opposition side of the House. We have seen the leadership of the Liberal Party change. We have not seen the Liberal Party sort out its policies. The reason the Liberals are in such disarray is that there are not two people on the other side of the House who can agree on anything the assets test or anything else. The Government does not resile from what it has done. We believe we are redirecting expenditure to ensure that people who are most in need receive further assistance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Throsby I indicate that when I called the honourable member for Moreton for the previous question I noticed a reflex movement in the Speaker's gallery. I noted that the former member for Moreton, the Hon. Sir James Killen, was paying his first visit to the Parliament since his retirement. We welcome him to the gallery.
—Can the Minister for Trade advise the House of any further developments in the application to export alumina and bauxite from the Gove Peninsula?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Throsby for his question. Might I say that this is one of the many consuming issues with which I have to deal-
—Don't read it out.
—Order!
—You need not read it out.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party abuses the tolerance that is given him because of his position.
—Oh!
—The Leader of the Opposition should pay respect to the Chair.
—You should pay respect--
—Order! I warn the Leader of the Opposition. I call the Minister for Trade.
—Mr Speaker--
—He doesn't know the answer. That is what it is all about.
—I warn the Leader of the National Party. There is a difference between tolerance and the contempt that honourable members are showing the Chair.

—This issue is one of the very many with which I have to deal in my thoroughly exciting portfolio, one which is made all the more fulfilling in that I have such close and extremely satisfactory dealings with my colleague the Foreign Minister. These are important issues. I welcome the opportunity to go beyond what I said a couple of days ago. There have been some responses from the companies involved, but neither of them has attempted to address the central issues involved. In the case of Austraswiss, we have the need for the company to obtain a freely negotiated fair market price for its alumina as was provided for in the agreement that it signed at the time when the project was established. Secondly, in the case of Gove Aluminium Ltd, the fact is that the company now wishes to have approval for export prices for bauxite below any prices which have obtained at any time since 1978. I cannot volunteer--

—I raise a point of order. There are procedures in this place for questions without notice. There are also procedures for statements to be made. Ministers persistently have been reading from prepared answers to questions. I suggest to you, Mr Speaker, that that is not an appropriate way in which questions without notice should be heard. It is on that basis that my colleague the Leader of the Opposition and I have been interjecting in the course of this Question Time. I direct your attention to the standing order which requires questions without notice to be exactly that.

—Order! The Leader of the National Party is well aware that the Chair has no way of knowing how the questions arise or how the answers are provided, nor has the House given him power to limit the length of an answer.

—I think that it is a pity that the Leader of the National Party should seek to trivialise this extraordinarily important issue, one that is central to the maintenance of ournational interest. As I was saying, it is not possible for me to volunteer the price details involved in the contracts because, under an agreement with all the companies, the price information they provide to us is kept confidential within the Government. However, of course, if the company were to release me from that obligation, I would happily provide the information which I am sure would be of very great interest to the House.

ANSWER.PARA: But let me say that Austraswiss has made a couple of responses. The first one, denying that the company has sought under the Freedom of Information Act information relating to contracts of other companies, is frankly false. In its request for that information it has sought all reports, all memoranda and all documents relating to the international transactions between Australia and other countries in relation to alumina and bauxite. The Government, of course, has resisted the release of the information relating to the other companies involved in this trade.

The Australian Government is not trying to break or renege on its contractual obligations. Indeed, the contract, as far as I am concerned, is not at issue. This Government is concerned-as have been previous Australian governments, including those of Liberal and National Party origin-to obtain prices which are freely negotiated, fair and reasonable. Austraswiss has failed to respond to my request to it. Instead, it has put out a very misleading Press statement which avoids the central issue. The other company, Gove Aluminium, has responded, but it has not provided the information that we have sought from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Respond outside the House.

—This is the place in which to respond to those questions and this is the place in which I intend to respond now and in future. If the Opposition would like me to release all the documents, it will find that the approach that I am taking is entirely consistent with the approach that was taken by several of my predecessors over very many years. Perhaps this is another example of the modern Liberal Party and the modern National Party deciding to turn its back on all of its former leaders and representatives in this place.
—Order! I remind the Minister that his answer has been going for some time. It makes it very difficult.

—Mr Speaker, this is a crucial issue which deserves a response. I want to assure the people of Nhulunbuy that this action has been taken only after the deepest and closest consideration of all the factors. It is in the interests of all Australians. We have no intention of seeing this lead to the closure of the operation in Nhulunbuy. But the Australian people would regard us as being derelict in our duties if we ignored this important issue. This is a question of the sovereignty of the Australian Government when confronted by an apparently unco-operative foreign corporation. We are, of course, aware of our responsibilities in maintaining our reputation as an important and reliable trading nation. But this is not what is at issue; what is at issue is a question of our national self respect, a self respect which I intend to enhance.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I ask the Minister to table the document from which he was reading.
—Was the Minister quoting from a document on public affairs?
—It includes commercial in-confidence information. I do not intend to table it.

—I ask Bill Hayden's mate, the Minister for Trade, to advise the House as to whether the trade accord between Prime Minister Nakasone and Mr Hawke, relating in particular to bilateral negotiations between the United States of America and the Japanese on commodities such as coal and meat, is being fully honoured.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, which concerned the assurances that the Japanese Government has given the Australian Government in relation to our trade, particularly coal and beef. The Australian Government attaches the greatest significance to the undertakings which have been given repeatedly to the Australian Government. In relation to coal, the assurances were first given to the Prime Minister by the Japanese Prime Minister in January 1984. They have been repeated on subsequent occasions, most recently to me by Minister Murata when I was in Japan in June. Significantly, the assurances that were given at that time followed our taking up with the Japanese our concern at some reported purchases of coal from the United States, other than under normal commercial conditions. What the Minister said to me at that time, in repeating the assurances that had been given recently, was that the coal trade had to be conducted on a commercial basis and that he would ensure that that continued to be the case. We are very proud of the record of our coal industry since the Government came to office. It has been not only highly competitive but also highly reliable. Of course, those factors need to be maintained in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been some media reports that the United States has attempted to reopen the negotiated agreement relating to access for beef to the Japanese market. We have taken up this matter with the Japanese as recently as 14 November. They have said that the United States has not attempted to renegotiate those arrangements. We would resist any attempt to renegotiate those arrangements because, even though they were less satisfactory than we would have hoped, they have provided for growth in the imports of beef to Japan, a growth in which Australia is able to participate. Whilst it is true that arrangements have been made which give some preference to grain fed beef as opposed to grass fed beef, there is an opportunity for Australia to participate in the quotas for both of those categories. The Australian industry has responded-indeed, I think it should respond even further-to the opportunities that exist for it to participate in those global quotas for both grass fed and grain fed beef. I assure the honourable member and the House that the Government does attach the greatest importance to the assurances that have been provided to us by the Japanese Government. We are sure that the Japanese Government will stand by those assurances.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister seen a recent article in the Australian newspaper bearing the headline `Tanks in Canberra's gunsights'? Will the Minister comment on the claim made by the author of that article that the Army's armoured capability is under threat?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen some Press reports to that effect and I have also seen the article referred to by the honourable gentleman. The first point I make is that the type of land forces that Australia really needs to suit our environment, which imposes considerable problems in the area of both strategic and tactical mobility, are very much at the heart of the work that is being done by the consultant to me, Mr Paul Dibb. I expect considerable and detailed comment on them in his report which will be available subsequently for debate in this place and elsewhere by the general public. Without in any way wishing to pre-empt the content of that report, I make the point-this is my personal opinion-that there will always be within the Australian armed forces a place for heavy armour as represented by the Leopard tank. There is absolutely no doubt that the Leopard tanks are among the finest tanks in the world. They have a well proven combination of firepower and survivability. We would always want to see an element of that in the Australian armed forces. In addition, as the honourable gentleman would be aware, as I announced at the time when we decided to proceed no further with Project Waler, we are looking at the upgrading of some of our M113Cs. I am expecting a report on that subject. Once that report has been received and a recommendation is made to us which is acceptable to the Government, we will be proceeding down that path.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I think it also needs to be said that when we look at the Australian strategic context, considerable problems are posed us by the nature of our strategic geography. For many purposes, not all, the type of armour we have at the moment is manifestly inadequate in mobility. That problem is one which we will require to resolve. In the first instance I will be able to receive advice on that matter from Mr Paul Dibb. However, we are not waiting for that.

As I also announced at the time we went through the assessment of the Waler program, I intended that there be an examination done by the Army of what our light armoured fighting vehicle capability ought to be, taking into account the enormous distances which we have to travel and the fact that we may require a type of armoured fighting vehicle that is designed for purposes other than the purpose which our current armoured fighting vehicles most clearly match, that is, of a fairly narrow Middle Eastern or European battle front.

Therefore, in addition to making sure that we have the capabilities in fire-power and survivability that that situation necessitates we are also obliged to look innovatively, indeed radically, at what other requirements we have. Mr Dibb is doing that. The Army is doing that. The honourable gentleman may be assured that that will be at the forefront of our concerns next year when we sit down to take a look at the direction in which our Defence Force structure and capability ought to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware that Australian Bureau of Statistics figures indicate that non-British migrants do not have the same high income earnings as the average Australian? Further, is the Minister aware that the same group of migrants is, proportionately, the largest home buying group in our community? As this group is the hardest hit by the Government's high interest, home buyers money rationing policies, when will the Minister take action to relieve the plight of migrant home buyers and owners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the first time in my first 16 years in this Parliament that a question has been put to me as Minister Assisting. I will receive this question as Minister Assisting the Treasurer because it has nothing to do with immigration and ethnic affairs.
—You should be worried about them. It is a serious question about migrants.

—I am not worried because I know that the economy of this country is improving enormously, so much so that in my portfolio of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs I note that there are over one million people wanting to come to this country each year but only 84,000 places are available.

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, I have noticed those statistics. I have noticed that there are still people wanting to come from the United Kingdom, as there are from every other place in the world. I note also that these people want to come here because the country is being well governed and because there are, indeed, jobs being created at present, homes being built and because they can have a better life here than they can in the countries from which they want to come.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AFRICAN AIRWAYS: FLIGHTS TO SOUTH AFRICA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Aviation aware of media reports that South African Airways has withdrawn its application for three supplementary flights over Christmas? Can the Minister inform the House of the position in respect of these flights?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I recognise his concern in this matter. Let me say that there has been no obstruction of the South African Airways and Qantas Airways Ltd applications for extra capacity at Christmas time on their routes to southern Africa. While it is true that South African Airways applied in July for additional flights at Christmas-Qantas also subsequently put in an application for a flight to Harare-the Government clearly could not take a decision until after the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in October at which civil aviation links with South Africa were a central issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Immediately after CHOGM the Government again considered the matter in the context of reviewing aviation links with South Africa, as agreed at CHOGM. I wrote in early November to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs seeking their agreement for flights on the basis that for the moment at least, the Government maintain civil aviation links with South Africa.

Subsequently both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs replied agreeing with my proposal on the basis that this decision did not in any way prejudice the outcome of the review. This decision was to be conveyed to the airlines on Monday, 25 November. Unfortunately for South African Airways, it chose to withdraw its application on Monday. It made the inaccurate accusations which have appeared in the media. The Government informed Qantas that its application had been approved.

Yesterday South African Airways refiled for two supplementary flights on 23 and 24 December and 7 and 8 January 1986. The Government has decided to agree to these flights on the same basis as the original request, that is, that this action in no way prejudices the outcome of the review of civil aviation links with South Africa.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEETING BETWEEN FOREIGN MINISTER AND PALESTINE LIBERATION ORGANISATION REPRESENTATIVE

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the reported meeting last month between the Foreign Minister and the Palestine Liberation Organisation representative at the United Nations. I ask: Did the Prime Minister know of this meeting prior to its taking place? If so, did he authorise the meeting? Does the meeting indicate that there is a change in the Australian Government's attitude to the PLO? What guidelines has the Prime Minister laid down for meetings between Ministers of his Government and senior officials of the PLO?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for his question. If he does not mind, I will take the parts of his question in reverse order. No, there is no change in the policy and the attitude of the Government to the PLO. In relation to the first parts of the question, I did not know of and did not authorise the meeting; nor did I need to know and nor did I need to authorise the meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: It should be apparent to this House and all members of the Australian public that I have total confidence in my Minister for Foreign Affairs. There is a very good reason why I should have. He is an excellent Minister for Foreign Affairs. He diligently gives effect to the policies of this Government in a way which I believe commands the support of the overwhelming majority of the people of this country.

Let it be said-I am not suggesting to the honourable member that he implied there was something sinister, devious or secretive about what the Minister did-that the meeting which the Minister held was quite open; there was nothing secretive about it. I assure the honourable member that the meeting was open; there was nothing secret or covert about it. It is not to be taken that it implies any change in the policy of the Government on this matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SOUTH AUSTRALIAN OPPOSITION LEADER: HOUSING PROPOSAL

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take back what I said about him. Thank you, Mr Speaker.
—Was there something I should have heard?

—No, Mr Speaker. It was the honourable member for Makin who said that. Can the Minister for Housing and Construction advise the House whether the proposal by the South Australian Opposition Leader, John Olsen, to sell Housing Trust public rental houses is permitted under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposal of the South Australian Opposition to sell off public housing stock at a discount--
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker, under standing order 144, questions should not ask for an expression of opinion or for a legal opinion. This question transgresses both those rules.
—The question asked about the effect of certain action on the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and I would not have thought that was a legal opinion. I call the Minister.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker.
—The question was whether it was lawful or legal to do what is allegedly proposed to be done by the South Australian Opposition.
—Were those the terms used in the honourable member's question?
—I will read it again, if you like, Mr Speaker.
—Will the honourable member for Grey read the question?

—And I must say, Mr Speaker, that I really hold you in very high esteem. Can the Minister advise the House whether the proposal by the South Australian Opposition Leader, John Olsen, to sell Housing Trust public rental houses is permitted under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement? That is straightforward.
—The Minister may answer.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I am glad we have cleared that up, because the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement is clearly under the administration of my portfolio. The proposal by the South Australian Opposition to sell off public housing stock in South Australia at a discount of up to 50 per cent will not be permitted by the Commonwealth under the current Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The Agreement clearly states that such sales are to be at market value or replacement cost.
—And you want to change that.

—In response to that interjection I want to make it clear that this Federal Labor Government will not be renegotiating the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to allow such asset stripping as is proposed by the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia. What the South Australian Leader of the Liberal Party Opposition proposes is not permitted under the current Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, nor will the provisions be changed to allow it. In that sense it is clearly in breach of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. Further, if such a plan did proceed--
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker, if that is not a legal opinion, what is it? Therefore, the answer should be ruled out of order.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—If such a plan did proceed under the Liberals in South Australia whereby they allowed a discount on public assets of up to 50 per cent without Commonwealth approval, there would be a cost to the State of approximately $85m in the first year. That is calculated on a very conservative take-up rate of 5,000 houses. So the South Australian Opposition proposal, I repeat, is not permitted under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and if it did proceed it would cost the State of South Australia $85m with a consequential increase in State taxes by a Liberal government, that is, in the unlikely event it was ever in a position to impose such a tax.

ANSWER.PARA: It is no wonder that the South Australian Labor Government is so clearly hostile to such a plan because it has such a great record in the provision of public housing in South Australia. This year it has broken all records in real terms for Federal-State funding in that State indeed, across Australia. It will spend $304m this year, a rate of State funding of $170 a head, which compares very well indeed with a figure of $60 per capita which is the average of all the States across Australia. The lowest per capita expenditure in Australia on public housing no prizes for answering is in the State of Queensland. So the Labor Government in South Australia has a great record in ameliorating housing related poverty. As a result of this record expenditure it will be able to increase rental stock in South Australia by 2,900 this year compared with only 1,700 during the last year of the former Federal Government in Canberra. I conclude by saying and I want to make this clear to Mr Olsen that we will not renegotiate the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement to allow his form of asset stripping of public housing stock in South Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Wills-Prime Minister)-by leave-The year 1985 marks the end of the United Nations Decade for Women. All over the world, governments have been reviewing their achievements in the last 10 years in raising the status of women. Australia has been taking an active domestic and international part in this process. In July we sent a delegation to the End of Decade World Conference in Nairobi, which was held to review the achievements of the decade and to devise strategies to ensure that progress continues. Our participation in Nairobi reminded us of the harsh conditions under which women live and work in many parts of the world and of the continuing need to work for progress at the international level.

SPEECH.PARA: At that conference Australia endorsed, without reservation, the main conference document, the `Forward Looking Strategies', which sets out a plan of action for carrying progress for women through to the year 2000. We in Australia have achieved some significant progress over the decade. In several areas of achievement for women we are in the forefront of the world's nations. Australia's governmental machinery for ensuring that women's concerns are taken into account in the formulation of government policy is in the top rank. The `Women's Budget Program', with its full-scale assessment of the impact on women of the Federal Budget, is without parallel anywhere else in the world.
Our overall record is one of which we can be proud. Since coming to Office, we have, in the short space of less than three years:
introduced the Sex Discrimination Act 1984, which provides the legal right to equal treatment;
established an affirmative action pilot program for women in the private sector work force and introduced legislation for equal employment opportunity in the Commonwealth Public Service;
ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; and are represented on the UN Commission on the Status of Women;
given high priority to the representation of women on Government boards, authorities and instrumentalities, appointing more than 120 women to such boards;
increased the supply of child care places by 50 per cent in the past two years and undertaken to provide a further 20,000 new child care places by June 1988;
significantly increased funding for women's refuges and guaranteed their funding until July 1989;
this year exceeded the 50 per cent target for employment of women in the community employment program;
agreed to assist the transfer of nurse education from hospitals to colleges of advanced education;
established a National Women's Consultative Council; and
initiated a $475,000 national women's consultation and assistance program to provide grants to national women's organisations and fund projects to improve the status of women.

A range of general Government policies have also been of significant benefit to women and their families. These include our income-support measures, housing policies, Medicare, the home and community care program, the supported accommodation assistance program, and the children's services program. Women have also benefited substantially, both directly and indirectly, from the almost 460,100 new jobs generated since April 1983. Fifty-six per cent of these jobs have gone to women, and full-time female employment has increased by 137,100 in the same period.

As we come to the end of the decade for women, it is time to say how we will continue to raise the status of women-to set out our Agenda for women as we move towards the year 2000. We want to give women the opportunity to contribute to the full to the future development of our nation, whether in a domestic setting, in the work force, or in any other aspect of life. This opportunity must be open to all women in Australia. We are talking about opportunities for Aboriginal women, for women from migrant backgrounds, for women with disabilities and for those who are in other ways disadvantaged, for young women and older women, for women at home and women at work, and for women in all the wide variety of circumstances that can face them.

The Government is proud of the fact that in the past year an additional 107,200 women have found employment, over half of whom have moved into full time jobs. At the same time the unemployment rates for both adult and young women have dropped and the numbers of discouraged women workers have also decreased substantially.

Although 46 per cent of women are now in the labour force, fully 64 per cent of women workers are employed in only three of the nine major occupation groups-clerical; sales; and service, sport and recreation-a situation which has shown little, if any, change over the decade. In general, jobs in these occupations attract low rates of pay and offer little prospect of advancement. The Government is committed, through its affirmative action proposals which I shall address shortly, and other policies, to improving this situation. We want to give women a say on this national agenda and a role in determining its priorities. It is against this background that I would like to present to the House the Government's preliminary thinking on the content of a national agenda for women.

Through our national agenda we will aim to open up opportunities to all women, and we will do that in three ways. We want to give women a choice. We want to give women a say. And we want to give women a fair go. Giving women a choice is perhaps at the heart of our agenda. Women must be able to choose, more freely than has been possible in the past, the kinds of lives they wish to live. They must be free to achieve economic independence: To choose employment, and the training to equip them for adequately remunerated employment, which, as we know, offers the best opportunity for escape from poverty and dependence. Full access to education and post-school training opportunities is a central aspect of our agenda to maximise women's choices.

Women must also feel free to choose to be full time mothers without the fear that their contribution to family life is somehow of a lesser status than work outside the home. They must be able to choose to combine motherhood and employment and not feel that the difficulties of being a working parent receive no acknowledgement or support. Increasingly, Australian women choose different roles at different stages of their lives. Many women want to leave the work force to nurture their young children and then be able to return to employment without having to start at the bottom again.

In the past, economic factors and social prejudices have constrained women's choices and women have often been seen only in their familial roles as wives or mothers. Nevertheless, family life is the central focus for very many Australian women and the Labor Government is committed to giving support to families, and recognises the wide variety of family structures now chosen by Australians. Support is provided to all families with dependent children through family allowance payments. Since coming to office, one of my Government's major social welfare priorities has been to increase assistance for low income families. To this end, the family income supplement and the additional pension/benefit for children have been increased by 60 per cent and the mothers/guardians allowance has been doubled. As part of our strategy for young people we have announced increases in education allowances, which should be especially helpful in giving young women financial support to undertake education and training. We have also announced the introduction of a new traineeship system for young people. This will provide important new opportunities for young women and men.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission is developing a national policy on the education of girls which will define a set of principles, objectives and priorities for action and serve as a basis for future State-Commonwealth collaboration on girls' education issues. On the same theme, following its acceptance of the main recommendations of the Quality of Education Review Committee report, the Commonwealth Government is pursuing resource agreements with State Government and non-government school systems. Among other objectives, these agreements will seek to obtain approximately equal representation and attainment of girls in major subject areas.

Child care is essential for working mothers but it is also needed by women at home who need a safe place to leave their children while they do the family shopping, or visit the doctor, or simply seek some relief from the demands of full time child-raising. The Labor Government's approach to child care policy has been to expand the provision of places. When we came to office in March 1983 there were child care places for only 4.6 per cent of Australia's under-five children. Following significant funding increases in our first two years in office we have now a three-year plan to provide 20,000 additional child care places by 1988 at an estimated cost of $107m. By 1988 there will be government subsidised child care for 9.5 per cent of Australia's children aged under five. We have also developed needs-based planning to ensure that new child care places are located in areas of high need. We are committed to funding quality care that is affordable for low and middle income earners. Recent changes announced to the funding arrangements for child care centres will result in a fairer system which continues to benefit all families irrespective of income while recovering a proportion of the real costs involved from those whose incomes allow it. The adequate provision of child care will remain high on the agenda.

Women who choose employment are entitled to have access to all the opportunities offered by the Australian labour market, to seek employment in any occupation which interests them, at the level which meets their qualifications. They are entitled to the enhanced skills and prospects which result from on the job training measures. They are entitled to a just wage for their efforts. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) announced in September special efforts to increase women's participation in labour market programs and open up jobs which were traditionally performed by men. A national strategy on women in the labour force is being developed by his Department. Implementation of some of the major recommendations of the report of the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs will improve the participation of women in labour market programs. In addition to the traineeship system, a new integrated adult program will provide major support for the training of disadvantaged job seekers, including single parents and women re-entering the workforce after long periods of absence due to family responsibilities. In the special trade training program, aimed at developing new approaches to complement traditional apprenticeship training, 500 places have been approved for women on preparatory pre-employment courses.

The Government is also pursuing a policy of affirmative action to enable women in all kinds of jobs to secure their entitlements to equal employment opportunity in the work-place. This policy was tested in a practical fashion through a 12-month pilot program. At the same time, we established a representative working party of government, business, trade union, higher education and women's interests, and a member of the Federal Opposition, to secure broad-based advice on how best to legislate to improve women's job opportunities. Today I tabled the report of the working party, whose recommendation the Government has already accepted. I would like to take the opportunity today to place on record my appreciation and that of the Government of the constructive input to the policy made by all members of that working party.

As a major initiative in advancing the status and opportunities of women in the work force, the Government will introduce legislation early next year requiring all higher education institutions and eventually private sector employers of more than 100 persons to report annually to the Government on their plans for providing equality of opportunity for women. We will establish a new statutory agency within the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations portfolio to administer the legislation. I am confident that agency will continue the co-operative and harmonious relationship with business, trade unions and higher education institutions developed by the Office of the Status of Women during the pilot program. Our affirmative action legislation will be supported by a number of complementary measures, designed to ensure that wherever possible obstacles to women's full participation in employment are removed.

The Government will actively encourage large private sector companies to supplement the child care services provided under the children's services program by establishing child care for their employees. Tax deductions are available for some of the expenses involved, and these services will be exempted from the tax on fringe benefits. In addition, the Government will approach the States and seek their co-operation in removing regulations or other requirements which inhibit the development of new child care facilities. I am conscious that some State laws and awards contain restrictions on women undertaking certain types of work. The Government will convene a high level conference of business, trade unions, State governments and other relevant parties early next year in order to determine how these laws can be amended.

The other supportive measures will be in the vital area of education. I have already referred to the national policy on girls' education being developed by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. In the context of the demands for qualified women expected to arise from the implementation of affirmative action, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) will be taking additional steps to increase the enrolment of women studying engineering, the field of study where women are least represented, comprising only 5 per cent of students. In introducing this program we will be building on several smaller initiatives already funded through the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's equity program. While affirmative action is designed to increase the range of jobs open to women, the Government is also taking action to improve the status of predominantly female occupations. The status of the nursing profession will be greatly enhanced by the upgrading of its training to a higher education diploma.

The Government is committed to encouraging the development of more efficient small business, which is a vital sector of the Australian economy. The Government recognises the important role that women can play as entrepreneurs and will ensure that its small business programs are accessible to women. We recognise the importance of maternity leave for women workers and that the current provisions put women in private sector employment at a disadvantage when compared with those in public sector employment who are entitled to 12 weeks paid leave. Many comparable Western nations have provisions through their social security systems for paid maternity leave for women in both the public and private sector. In order to be better informed on the subject and following an initiative of the National Labour Consultative Council, the Institute of Family Studies is undertaking a review of the usage of maternity leave in the private and public sectors. I look forward with interest to seeing the results of this research.

I announced in June 1983 at the International Labour Organisation convention in Geneva that the Government was committed to ratifying ILO Convention 156, that covering workers with family responsibilities. In keeping with accepted procedure, consultations are proceeding with State Governments with a view to reaching an early agreement on ratification. It will never with any truth or justice be said of this Labor Government that we are unaware of the tremendous contribution to our national well-being made by women in the home. Without the work they perform the economy would not function as smoothly. At present women's unpaid work in the home and in voluntary activities for the community is not measured and thus tends to be undervalued. In 1988 the Australian Bureau of Statistics will carry out a major time use survey which will provide sound statistical data on women's multiple responsibilities.

Health is an area of fundamental importance to all women and to those for whom they are responsible. A National Agenda for Women would not be complete without action in this area. To the traditional focus on the financing of care for the ill, and on women's reproductive health, needs to be added improvements to the general physical, mental and social status and well-being of women in our changing society. The Commonwealth Government, in the context of its commitment to achieve the World Health Organisation's target of health for all by the year 2000 and in response to a resolution from the Second National Women's Health Conference held in Adelaide in September 1985, will develop a national health policy in co-operation with the States and Territories and with women's health networks. The policy will recognise the need to improve the overall well-being of women and will focus on the demands on women's health arising from their many roles.

The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) will appoint a special women's health resource person to co-ordinate development of the policy. From the policy will follow programs to improve the general health status of all women in Australia, and through them the health status of all Australians.
Giving Women a Say

The Labor Government places a very great importance on the need to seek the views of women on matters of concern to them. We established the National Women's Consultative Council in 1984 to bring together a representative group of women to channel to government the views of their organisations on issues such as taxation, child care and matrimonial property. I would like today to thank most sincerely Mrs Edith Hall, the Council's Convener, and the Council members for the sterling work they are doing. I look forward to receiving the Council's first report on its activities.

The Labor Government take the view that women are entitled to have a say on all subjects in all the decision-making forums of Government and not just decisions on so-called `women's issues'. We are determined to improve our already substantial record in the numbers of women appointed to government boards and authorities and I have asked the Office of the Status of Women to advise the Government on the means of doing so. We are also conscious of the need to seek the views of particular groups of women on matters of concern to them. To this end the Aboriginal Women's Task Force has consulted widely with Aboriginal women throughout the country. Its report will be published early next year, and the Government will provide a speedy response to it. My colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) is currently addressing the representation of Aboriginal and Islander women while consulting with Aboriginal communities on a replacement national Aboriginal and Islander cosultative organisation. The Minister has also recently received a report reviewing the activities of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs as they affect Aboriginal women.

Recognising the additional disadvantages experienced by many migrant women, early in 1985 the Government consulted with experts, most of them women of non-English speaking backgrounds, on migrant women's issues. Recommendations for action were formulated in the four priority areas of health, safety and working conditions; access to language, education, training and retraining; access to child care; and services for aged and aging migrant women. These areas were specifically endorsed at a meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. As part of our ongoing commitment to addressing the special needs of migrant women, we will ensure that in making government appointments the skills of migrant women are not overlooked.
