To gain greater insight into the special needs of rural women, the Office of the Status of Women will early next year assist the Country Women's Association to conduct a major survey of country women. I am particularly looking forward to the results of that survey.

In the area of services for the aged and the disabled, the Government seeks both input and reaction to programs through key bodies including the Disability Advisory Council of Australia and the Australian Council on the Ageing. Women are well represented on both these Councils. I have invited young Australians to participate in the review of the Government's strategy for young people. I am personally involved in a national phone-in for youth covering all capital cities. I hope large numbers of young women will participate and thus have a direct chance to make their views heard.

The Government intends to give consideration to changing the make-up of the National Women's Consultative Council, when the term of the present Council expires next June, so that a number of women from community groups can be added to those representing national organisations.
Giving Women a Fair Go

The Labor Government is committed to ensuring that all Australian citizens can live in dignity. We pride ourselves on being a nation which promotes justice and equality for all. A fair go for women is the third aspect of our national agenda. The Labor Government wishes to promote the dignity of women and to attack those attitudes or practices which undermine it, for instance, those which downgrade women's domestic and nurturing roles, which stereotype women as ignorant or foolish in the media or in advertising, or which look with equanimity on the violence perpetrated on women both outside and inside the home. Many of these issues can only be addressed by government on a long term, considered basis. Others lie outside the scope of direct government influence. However we are determined to act where we can, and to help create an environment where women's dignity is acknowledged and valued in those areas outside our sphere of direct influence. For example, because of the level of concern expressed by women about the way they are depicted by advertisers, the Office of the Status of Women will commission research in this area as one of its activities to mark the End of the United Nations Decade for Women.

The Labor Government is committed to redressing women's poverty. The financial plight of many sole parent families is of particular concern to the Government. We have recognised the problem of unintended poverty traps which operate to keep people-particularly sole parent pensioners and beneficiaries-dependent on social security payments when they, and society, would benefit if they were able to join the paid work force. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his September statement on Reform of the Australian Taxation System, announced a number of measures to reduce poverty traps. The Government will continue to take action to reduce poverty traps as resources permit.

The Labor Government is aware that the existing maintenance system is sometimes ineffective and fails to provide adequately for children in sole parent families. Some non-custodial parents are able to avoid making an appropriate contribution to the financial support of their children. The Government has under consideration a range of options to establish a sounder structure.

The rapid growth in the number of women's refuges over the past 12 years-there are now more than 165 refuges receiving State and Commonwealth Government assistance-is grim testimony to the toll of domestic violence. I am certain I have the full support of this House and of State governments when I say that this kind of violence is intolerable. The Labor Government has significantly increased funding to women's refuges and, through the Commonwealth-State supported accommodation assistance program, has provided guaranteed funding until July 1989. We will evaluate these services to ensure the assistance provided is adequate. Through sport women can acquire skills and enjoyment, improved physical health, and also greater self-esteem and a sense of achievement. The Government will continue to facilitate women's participation in sport.

The areas covered in this statement make up our national agenda for women to the year 2000. On some I have foreshadowed immediate action by the Government. For most our strategies will be longer term or will need to be further developed. Nonetheless, these are areas where the Government commits itself now to effective action to advance the status of women. I have already said that we want to give women a say on this national agenda and a role in shaping its development. We will publish it widely and invite women to comment on it. Senator Susan Ryan, the Minister who assists me on the status of women, will lead this consultation process. We have already invited the National Women's Consultative Council to assist the Government in seeking women's responses. Drawing on these widespread consultations we will develop our proposed agenda into a detailed set of strategies and policies to further improve the status of women in Australia over the next 15 years.

I trust that we can secure bipartisan agreement to our proposed agenda. What we are seeking to achieve is a broad and comprehensive approach to improving the status of women, one that recognises women's important contribution to our society and which allows women to make free choices, unimpeded by discriminatory laws or practices. Under our national agenda women in Australia will have a choice, women will have a say and women will have a fair go. I commend that national agenda to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am happy to say on behalf of the Opposition that except for reservations and objections that we hold in a number of areas that I will come to, we are in very substantial agreement with the statement that has been made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). In very large areas I am very happy to say that the goals and objectives that were set out in the Prime Minister's statement are goals and objectives that are held by the coalition parties. They are goals and objectives for which, over the years ahead, it ought to be possible for both sides of the political scene in Australia to work together.

SPEECH.PARA: There can be no doubt that over the past decade there have been enormous advances towards greater equality of status for women not only in Australia but also around the world. It could also be said without any fear of contradiction that change, progress and reform in that area were long overdue. The time has long since passed when there can be any equivocation by any major political party in Australia as to the desirable goal of effective equality of status of women in the Australian community. Some of the prejudices and attitudes of the past which have prevented the achievement of that full status are not prejudices and attitudes that will find any receptive response within the coalition parties. The Liberal and National Parties are committed to an effective equality of status for women. We recognise the changes which have occurred and which affect the lifestyles of many women in Australia. We too share very much the goal expressed in the Prime Minister's remarks that we should desire to give greater choice to women in Australia. If the House will permit me I will refer in a moment to my speech to the New South Wales State Council of the Liberal Party in which I emphasised the importance of choice of taxation policies affecting women in Australia.

It is worth reminding the House that for much of the past decade Australia has been governed by a coalition government. It is interesting that many of the measures to which the Prime Minister referred with approval in his statement were, of course, measures which were introduced by the coalition Government. It is significant that the first measure of importance to women and the family that the Prime Minister mentioned was the family allowance. That reform, which was introduced by the Fraser Government in 1976, has won very widespread approval as one of the major social reforms in Australia over the past 20 or 30 years. That reform was brought in by the coalition Government and it has worked to the benefit of women and lower income families in Australia. It stands as a permanent reminder of and a permanent rebuttal to those on the other side and elsewhere in the community who would argue that in some way the Australian Labor Party has a monopoly of concern, a monopoly of care and a monopoly of initiative when it comes to taking measures that assist the less privileged and less fortunate in our community. That measure has lain as the basis of the improvement of the status, economically, of many women within many family environments and it is certainly a reform of which I and many others as members of the Fraser Government remain infinitely proud.

I think that it is also important to mention, as the Prime Minister did not, that during the lifetime of the former Government there was a significant liberalisation and improvement in the value of the dependent spouse rebate. Although we believe that provision for single income families can be better provided by income splitting, that particular rebate provides very significant help to low and middle income families who wish to exercise the choice of one parent remaining at home and caring for young children. We on this side of the House certainly regard that as a very important part of the taxation system at present. We welcome the fact that thus far the Government has resisted the undoubted pressure that has been placed upon it by some of the more radical of its supporters to abolish the dependent spouse rebate because we think its abolition would represent a very retrograde step.

It is worth mentioning that under the stewardship of the Fraser Government there were increases and improved benefits for single parents, pensioners and low income families. There was the extension of the rehabilitation payment to disabled married women. There was the establishment of the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee. There was the establishment of a special women's unit within the Department of Education, the Department of Social Security, the Attorney-General's Department, the Schools Commission and the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. There was the establishment of the Office of Child Care, and the establishment of the National Women's Advisory Council, which allowed significant community input into government policy making.

On the score of the contribution made to the development of policies which affected the status of women under the former coalition Government, I pay tribute to the work of the current honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) and the current honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) for their part as Ministers responsible for the status of women within the coalition Government and as shadow Ministers within the coalition Opposition.

In welcoming the broad thrust of the Prime Minister's statement and in saying to the House that the Opposition has no difficulty in identifying itself with many of the goals that are set out in the statement, I take the opportunity of placing on record the contribution made by the former coalition Government to the improvement in the status of women within our community. The measures that were put in place not only provide a record of our action when in office in relation to matters affecting women but also reflect our philosophy. Perhaps I can develop for a moment the central core of our philosophy on this and indeed on so many other matters; that is, the principle of choice. It is a matter of satisfaction for those who want to see, in the hurly-burly of political debate in Australia, occasional areas of agreement between the two major sides of politics on important issues that both the Prime Minister and I stressed the importance of choice as far as the status of women is concerned. I would like in that context to refer to a speech I made to the New South Wales State Council of the Liberal Party of Australia which, in relation to taxation, set out, as best I can, the principle of choice and the facilitation of choice as far as policies which affect women are concerned. I said that one of the principles of our taxation policy was:
. . . our determination to provide a family tax benefit plan as part of our taxation policy.
I went on:
This involves two elements.
Firstly, we intend to restore fairness to the tax treatment of single income families through the introduction of income splitting.
Income splitting allows married couples to divide their total income between themselves in whatever proportions they choose and for each of them to be taxed as single persons.
This approach will greatly benefit single income families and those double income families where there is a great disparity between the respective incomes of husband and wife.
It is designed to give real choice to those in the community who wish their young children to be cared for full-time by one parent remaining at home.
Increasingly that choice has become a fiction for low and modest income earners.

More and more those on low incomes with young children do not have the luxury of one parent remaining at home but are forced-often against their will through sheer economic necessity-to be two-income families.
Our proposal will stop that and give people on that level of income a real choice.
It is wrong in principle that a family unit at a given level of income from two sources should have a massive tax advantage over another family unit with the same level of income from one source.
That is what applies at the moment-and that is what we intend to change.
We also propose that tax deductions for child care expenses should be introduced.
This recognises the reality that in today's world about 50 per cent of married women with dependent children are part of the workforce.
There have been permanent shifts in the lifestyles of many families. Increasingly women wish to combine the responsibility of parenthood with careers.
The Liberal Party recognises this and is adjusting its policies accordingly.
Through a commitment to both income splitting and tax deductibility for child care expenses, the Liberal party is facilitating choice.
We offer a framework within which a choice for parents with young children of being either a single or double income household can be more freely exercised than is presently the case.
It is not for a government to impose a stereotype of behaviour. It is for governments to facilitate choice.
That ideal of choice lies at the heart of every Liberal policy.

Those remarks made at the Liberal Party gathering a couple of weeks ago emphasise that choice lies very much at the centre of our approach to taxation policy as it affects the family and as it affects both men and women. I therefore take this opportunity, in responding to the Prime Minister's statement-whilst I welcome so many elements of it-of reaffirming the commitment of the coalition within its taxation policy to the progressive introduction of income splitting and the introduction of tax deductibility for child care expenses. Through both of those measures it will be possible for a greater measure of choice to be restored to our taxation system and we will be fulfilling the important role of government; that is, to facilitate choice.

Having indicated that there are very large areas of agreement between the Government and the Opposition on this matter, I point to one or two areas where we believe the Government has ignored initiatives which could help women obtain, in a practical sense, a greater measure of equality of status and where existing practices which are no longer relevant in modern times might be changed, made more flexible or discarded so as to be of particular assistance to women in the work force or women who wished to re-enter the work force. I refer to our rather inflexible industrial relations system. One of the very practical desires of many women in our community is, of course, greater access to permanent part time work. It is clearly desirable that achievement of that desire be facilitated. It is noticeable that the Prime Minister's statement says absolutely nothing about the need to have greater flexibility in this area.

The Prime Minister spent 45 minutes talking at great length about the Nairobi conference, important though that was. He spent a great deal of time talking about the establishment of yet another statutory authority to oversee activities in this area, but he made no reference at all to the impact on the employment opportunities of women, particularly the part time employment opportunities of women, which derives from the fact that our existing labour market arrangements are so inflexible and rigid.

If we did have a more flexible attitude towards part time work from the trade union movement and this Government, if we did have a more flexible industrial relations system that did not impose penalties on individual enterprises that made agreements to stagger their working hours to make them more acceptable to female and male employees who had family responsibilities-in other words, if we had a more commonsense approach to working hours in this country-there would be a lot more part time working opportunities available to women. In a statement that was supposed to set out the agenda for change and the agenda for progress towards providing greater employment opportunities for women, there was virtually no reference at all to the need to have greater flexibility. I must say that in a statement with which otherwise I find a very substantial measure of agreement, I am disappointed that there was absolutely no reference to that point.

The Opposition sees no need for the establishment of a new statutory authority as envisaged in the Prime Minister's statement. There still seems to be a tendency which has been reawakened in recent times within this Government to establish statutory authorities right, left and centre to carry out obligations which ought to be encompassed within the normal purview and the normal operations of government departments. I also say to the Prime Minister and the House that whilst we have no quarrel with the desire of the Government and of the Australian Bureau of Statistics to carry out a major time use survey which would provide sound statistical data on women's multiple responsibilities, frankly, the contribution of women in the home-or, indeed, women and men in the home-towards the well-being of the community, goes a little further than performing work which makes the economy function more smoothly than it does at present.

It bears repetition, in case there should be any doubt as to the emphasis placed upon the family unit by the coalition parties, that there is no unit in our society which provides a greater degree of personal security and cohesion or a greater avenue for individual fulfilment than the family unit. It stands prime amongst the commitments of the coalition parties with regard to the effective functioning of our society in all its manifestations, not just in an economic sense but in the sense of the average personal and social stability of our community. Whilst I do not disagree with the announced intention of the Government to carry out that survey, I say to the Prime Minister that the contribution goes a little further than just making the economy function smoothly. I think that most men and women in Australia would regard their contribution to family life as essentially being a non-economic thing, or something that goes far beyond economics and something of a very personal and significant nature.

Beyond those general remarks, the goals that have been established by the Prime Minister in what he has described as a national agenda for women are goals that the Opposition is happy to support. I take the opportunity of emphasising again our commitment to taxation reform of particular impact in the area of the family, which will have enormous significance for women who have chosen to be full time parents at home, looking after young children or, alternatively, have chosen-as increasingly women are-re-entry into the work force. They are areas in which we on this side of the House believe there should be a complete facilitation of choice, and that is the basis of our commitment. In other respects I welcome the Prime Minister's statement and I am happy to say that the Opposition can associate itself with most of the goals contained in that statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For at least the past 40 years, one of the most consistent factors in the conduct of Australia's foreign policies has been the disagreement which it has provoked in public life. By contrast, the most consistent factor in the comunity's reaction to that sector of foreign policy concerning overseas aid has been support and agreement in principle. The report of the Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, the Jackson Committee, cites overwhelming commitment to the proposition that Australia should assist developing countries, especially the poorest of them and most especially those countries in our own region.

SPEECH.PARA: I note for the record that the Committee members were Sir Gordon Jackson, who was the Chairperson, Professor Helen Hughes, the Deputy Chairperson, and Mr Neil Batt, Professor David Lim, Dr Peter McCawley and Dr Brian Scott, respectively members of that Committee. I am honoured that in the House are Professor Helen Hughes, Dr Peter McCawley and Dr Brian Scott, who served on that Committee. the Government is extremely grateful to the Committee members for the diligent, professional and publicly spirited manner in which they went about their import task.

Another demonstration of the community's interest is the Jackson Committee's receiving more than 400 submissions in the course of its work from individuals and community organisations. Despite Australia's record as a comparatively generous aid donor, there is little sign here of the so-called `aid fatigue' which affects some other developed countries. This is not to say that the issue provokes no argument or controversy. It does, and very often in the most passionate terms. But the argument in the main is about ways and means rather than underlying principles.

The Government has examined anew the fundamentals, principles, methods and rationale following publication of the Jackson Committee's report, the reaction to the report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence and the response to the report by the community in general. This process began when I tabled the Jackson Committee report in June last year. The Government decided at that time that it should allow at least 12 months for such considered responses to be thoroughly evaluated. My statement today will describe the results of this evaluation. It is the Government's formal response to the Joint Committee.

As I said in the House on Tuesday, the sensitivity with which we administer the welfare of our own community should also inform the policies by which we conduct our relationships with the rest of the world. This is especially true of the aid programs in which we try to help improve conditions for people in other countries who do not share our good fortune or who cannot match our material prosperity. Our objective is to promote the economic and social development of the societies in which these people live, particularly in our own neighbourhood. Primarily, these programs grow from a humanitarian concern for our fellows. There is no point, however, in being coy about the fact that our aid program also has our political and economic interests firmly in sight. Our foreign policies and bona fides are enhanced by our status as a relatively generous and objective donor of aid. We are concerned to ensure as far as we can that economic growth and social progress are achieved in developing countries, especially in our region, and that they be achieved in orderly and stable ways. This in turn will ensure that our relations with regional countries, both political and commercial, develop in a harmonious and mutually beneficial way. Aid is not somehow tainted because, among other things, it helps serve our own economic interests. But there are arguments that go in that direction. The Government, in other words, maintains a balance of motives in our aid program-a necessary and perfectly defensible balance-between our humanitarian concern for our fellow human beings and our economic and political interests.

It is the complexity of these interests which provokes contention over ways and means and forms in the aid program. There are people in Australia who insist that, since our aid is provided on the basis of need, it should be given only to the neediest individuals. They argue that providing aid which contributes to infrastructural development, as distinct from alleviating hunger and disease, is a wrong priority; that it helps not the neediest but the richest. There are examples around the world of projects which are no more than status symbols or which do nothing to improve social progress but which are given official aid for the most transparent and expedient of political reasons. There are examples of aid for infrastructural development which has primarily, if not entirely, advantaged commercial elites in both donor and recipient countries. The Government acknowledges this. But it argues that it should continue to conduct the kind of integrated program which balances humanitarian and infrastructural aid towards economic and social progress; which can, by proper priority setting and management, avoid the problems I have just described. In other words, our aid should be given in ways which help provide the environment in which humanitarian aid can be most effective.

An isolated village can be given aid to improve its health, housing and education services, for example, and to improve agricultural production. If the village remains isolated and if it has no way to exchange its products, however, it will not be able to exploit its new advantages and move beyond a subsistence economic setting. If, on the other hand, roads are built to enable it to get its agricultural products to market and if its subsistence economy can be developed into an exchange economy, it will be able to realise its new potential. An example of just such an integrated development can be seen in the crop substitution program in northern Thailand, where hill tribespeople are being helped to substitute cash crops for their traditional opium poppies. Substitute crops have to be found; the people have to be taught how to grow them efficiently; they have to have markets which are reliable receivers and sellers of their substitute crop; these markets have to be accessible.

This is a simple illustration of the need for balance between humanitarian and infrastructural aid in an effective program. Development must be sustainable. This requires a judicious mix of programs and projects aimed at promoting both growth and equity. Australia will benefit from the economic activity which will flow from the stability which comes from sustainable development. This is one of the reasons we give aid. Furthermore, as I have said, it should be recognised that there are coincidentally demonstrable inherent advantages in the terms of trade we enjoy with many of the countries which receive our aid. In just about every case, there is a healthy trade surplus in our favour. If one takes Papua New Guinea as a case in point, the balance on trade and current account is about $500m as against our aid to PNG which totals about $320m. It is true that Australia's share of imports into PNG has fallen from 50 per cent to 40 per cent but the volume of our exports is still substantial.

There is no reason why industry should not take part in our aid program, so long as equity and effectiveness remain primary considerations and so long as this guiding principle is strictly observed: The aid given must be good for the recipient. This participation is encouraged by such policies as the 20 per cent preference rule in the procurement of goods and services for the aid program. The development import finance facility scheme is another which helps Australian enterprise to compete for development-related contracts by providing grant funds for use in concessional export credit packages arranged by the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation. This scheme has been slow in getting under way since it was introduced during 1980-81. A sum of $1.6m was allocated to it in that year and $2m in 1981-82 but no actual expenditure was made. In 1982-83, about $1.5m was spent from the $2.2m allocated; in 1984-85, only $936,000 from the allocation of $10m; and, in 1984-85, $12.5m from the allocated $16m. Another $16m has been allocated this financial year. After this hesitant start, the DIFF program is running well. The Government is advised that Australian business is becoming more aware of the program. There are, of course, risks in the scheme. In one case, for example, DIFF and EFIC between them provided 70 per cent of the cost of a whole project. We must be careful to ensure that such schemes do not develop primarily as help for Australian industry rather than developing countries. We have to be careful, when we administer such schemes, that we are fulfilling our primary purpose of providing aid, and good aid at that.

Another general argument about the form of our aid concerns the proportion which should be allocated between bilateral and multilateral aid. It is said, for example, that Australian industry could benefit if more aid were given bilaterally. There are difficulties about this at the receiving end of our aid. Aid allocations can be classified in four ways: That given via the multilateral banks; that given to PNG which is a special case; that provided for humanitarian relief; and that provided on a bilateral basis. The first three classifications are not particularly flexible, unless there is a considerable period of time to make the adjustment. For instance, it would take about seven years to direct a significant amount of aid from multilateral banks to the other forms of aid. The point needs to be remembered that, if we diverted funds from such agencies as the International Development Association-which is the largest source of soft loans for the poorest of the poor countries-we would be doing our bit to cripple the economies of those least able to cope.

Aid to PNG is organised over a five-year period. Humitarian relief is obviously unpredictable. But there are basic amounts which must be kept within this classification because we must anticipate calamitous events which will put sudden and great pressure on our resources. An example is the famine in Ethiopia for which more than $29m was provided in 1984-85. The recent earthquakes in Mexico and Colombia for which Australia provided $2.9m are other examples. It bears remembering also that the island states of the Pacific and Indian oceans with whom we have a special connection are liable to natural disaster. There is not much opportunity to rearrange the constituents of our aid program so as to favour bilateral aid, even if we wanted to, without markedly increasing the aggregate amount.

There will always be argument about the appropriate level of this aggregate amount. Australians can take some credit, however, for supporting a steady increase in the level over the past 40 years, through bad times as well as good. The current level is more than $1,000m, which puts Australia among the leading donor nations. Give or take some marginal differences, the directions and the form and the management of our aid program have been essentially unchanged for some years now. When this Government assumed office almost three years ago, it decided that, since considerable time had elapsed since the last review, a detailed, clear-headed look was due at the program in its entirety. Were we allocating aid as effectively as we could or should? Was our aid focused on the areas where we could best help solve the worst problems? Were we using the talents of all the people who had skills in the matter? Was our aid program being managed as efficiently as it should? Did we need to develop some propositions about future directions of our spending on aid?

The Government was fortunate in that its predecessor had begun moves to commission an inquiry into the aid program. It was also fortunate in that it was able to call on the services of Sir Gordon Jackson, his committee of eminent academic and business specialists and a secretariat-all with formidable expertise in the subject. The Committee has carried out a profound analysis on an issue which is complex enough in itself and which stems from such a complex of mandates. This analysis stimulated the valuable report by the Joint Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee and a busy process of response by many other interested and involved people and groups in the community. I propose to deal with the major issues and propositions which have been thrown up by this process.

The basic assessment of the Jackson Committee was that aid is given primarily for humanitarian reasons to promote development but that it also complements our strategic, economic and foreign policy interests. The Government accepts and indeed has predicated its aid philosophy on just such an assessment. The Government also continues to accept the commitment to work towards achieving the allocation of the equivalent of 0.7 per cent of gross national product on overseas aid, despite the sad but unavoidable fact that we are enduring highly sensitive economic circumstances. The three years up to and including this year have been the most successful period, from the economic management point of view, we have seen for many years. Economic growth has been at the rate of about 5 per cent a year in this period. Unemployment and inflation have been reduced. Activity and employment in industry have increased. But, since we are involved in international trade, we cannot isolate or insulate our economy from pressures on our external account, on which we draw down finance for our overseas aid. If this drawing on our external account were made to an extent which was demonstrably imprudent-however good the cause may be-we could run into problems. It is part of the price we are paying for having to inherit a dollar which was artificially valued for expedient reasons. That may have brought about some short term political benefit but, in the medium to long term, it was quite damaging to the economy. We have to manage our economy in a realistic way, in a firecely challenging environment, and we have to live within our means. So the inescapable fact is that our aid program has to be kept, for the time being, within stringent limits. But I remind honourable members that the current annual level of aid expenditure is still more than $1,000m. I am pleased to point out that the Government has decided that the real level of official development aid will increase yearly in the future. And I repeat that we will continue to press on towards our objective of providing 0.7 per cent of gross national product a year for overseas aid.

The Jackson Committee recommended that Australia make its aid more effective by targeting it more carefully. Our aid program, therefore, will now aim to concentrate its resources on fewer methods of delivery within fewer sectors. It will concentrate on areas where we have particular expertise or resources. This is another change which will take place deliberately. There will be no abrupt break in our program to any one country or sector. Due account will be taken of the interests and needs of both Australia and recipient countries. Our legitimate commercial interests will naturally be considered at all times but not to such an extent that serving those interests will be detrimental to the primary goal of development nor to the extent that our humanitarian motivation is compromised. Indeed, by drawing on competitive sectors of the Australian economy, our aid and commercial concerns should coincide.

Though we live in a region of developing countries, as I said a moment ago, we are also a member of the international community. It follows that we accept a share in aid responsibilities at the global as well as the regional and national levels. We shall therefore continue to take part with other countries in the programs of organisations which have global application. We shall be selective, of course, in funding these organisations so as to ensure that our contributions are used effectively. The Government has in mind the World Bank and its affiliates, the United Nations development program, the world food program, and certain sector-specific agencies which allow Australia to be active in key areas of global need. By this I mean such areas as international agricultural research, aid against drug abuse, for refugees and for mothers and children. These priority agencies include the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, the United Nations Children's Fund, and the United Nations Fund for Drug Abuse Control. We will also contribute to certain Commonwealth programs. Before I leave the subject of global aid, I would like to emphasise the Government's commitment to improving efficiency in multilateral programs. This is necessary if the funds provided by donor countries are to produce the best results and if developing countries are to get the maximum benefit from the resources which come to them from multilateral sources.

The Jackson Committee having proposed an aid eligibility framework as a more effective way to focus and deliver our aid, the Government has identified four groupings for the purpose of government-to-government aid at regional and country levels. The first grouping consists of Papua New Guinea, the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean small island states; the second-South East Asia and the small South Asian states-comprises countries to which we can apply a comprehensive programming approach. The third grouping-China, India, Pakistan and Bangladesh-are those countries where we must take a more limited approach; and the fourth-composed of all other developing countries-will continue to be eligible for short term technical assistance and training opportunities, though their access to other forms of aid will be limited. This planning framework is an adaptable tool which allows for flexible response to perceived needs and which calls for clearer thinking on forms and mechanisms of our aid to specific countries and regions.

The largest recipient of our aid is Papua New Guinea and it will remain so for the foreseeable future. Our relationship has been long and amicable-a partnership which was recently confirmed when the Prime Ministers of Australia and Papua New Guinea signed the new five-year aid agreement. This agreement provides for a continuing high level of aid but, in recognition of Papua New Guinea's goal of self-reliance, for a 3 per cent real annual rate of decline overall. Nonetheless, the total aid commitment for Papua New Guinea over the new five-year period, in current values, will be nearly $1.5 billion. The agreement contains challenges for both our countries. Papua New Guinea has had little experience in managing bilateral aid which is specifically targeted. It will require some effort on the part of both countries to ensure that the benefits of this aid will be fully realised. Australian and Papua New Guinean officials will hold annual discussions to assess the effectiveness of our aid and to ensure that incipient problems do not become unmanageable.

The aid program will continue to take account of the small size and fragile nature of the island economies of the South Pacific and the Indian Ocean. Some South Pacific countries are already obviously reaching a limit in their ability to absort traditional forms of aid. We are therefore examining alternative ways to meet specific economic and social needs. A regional team of specialist advisers has been formed to help in this work. An Australian aid mission visited the Indian Ocean small island states last year. It noted that their economies were fragile and that a cautious, measured approach was necessary to increased aid. Work is under way on developing an appropriate program for these small island states.

South East Asia embraces countries at different stages of development, characterised by widely varying patterns of growth and income distribution. Our aid programs to this region will continue to reflect this diversity. The Association of South East Asian Nations countries are rapidly reaching the point at which the traditional donor-recipient relationship is no longer relevant. Though they are all middle income countries, there are substantial differences between them and our aid program will need to take into account the different development challenges they face. The depressed standards of living in the Indo-China states mean that they continue to warrant our humanitarian concerns.

The third grouping in our eligibility framework includes China which, although it has made enormous progress recently, remains an underdeveloped country. Our aid program there is becoming more focused, with a sharpening of sectoral targets. The new program will emphasise the provision of Australian expertise in such key sectors of the Chinese economy as agriculture, transport, minerals and minerals processing.

Along with China, the bulk of the world's very poor are in the heavily populated countries of south Asia. These countries receive substantial benefits through our contributions to multilateral organisations. Our bilateral programs to these countries, on the other hand, have declined. We are placing new emphasis on enhancing our bilateral relationships in the region. We hope to be able to resume more direct assistance also.

We will continue to support the Asian Development Bank and Fund and other organisations which are effective channels for assistance to countries in our region. Before leaving the subject of eligibility, I want to mention Africa, which is assuming a particular place in our aid policies as in our foreign policies generally. The response of Australians to the famine in Africa has been prompt and generous. But long term development strategies are necessary so that the emergency does not continue. Australian aid programs to African countries will therefore focus increasingly on the objective of national food security. The Government is committed to a program which will draw on Australian resources and expertise to tackle the real problems. Our aid to African countries will continue to be channelled mainly through the World Bank and other multilateral organisations. We have also taken steps to look into the possibility of membership of the African Development Bank.

The Government recognises that non-government organisations are often able to do effective work in areas beyond the reach of official programs, and particularly at the village level. They implement programs which complement official aid. Perhaps most important of all, they help Australians to appreciate the often horrendous problems of developing countries and to demonstrate their personal concern about them. The Government has already acted on the Jackson Committee recommendation that official subsidies to NGOs be increased. Aid delivered through NGOs was increased by nearly 80 per cent in the current Budget over the previous financial year. Further increases in subsidies for projects of NGOs are justified, though further long term growth in these subsidies will need to be commensurate with the capacity of NGOs to mobilise public support and to deliver the increased allocation.

Training aid and especially the provision of special courses tailored to regional requirements will grow in importance as a means of strengthening social, economic and commercial links between us. Other initiatives taken since the Jackson Committee finalised its report include restructuring the student program, establishment of a special fund and new activities to assist the role of women in development, establishment of community based development education and wider programs of development research.

When I set up the Jackson Committee one of my major concerns was to ensure that our aid program was effectively managed. The Australian public, which provides the $1,000m a year which is going into our aid program, has the right to expect that the aid program is efficiently administered. The Jackson Committee report documented the difficult organisational history of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau. It described the external pressures which led to management resources being reduced without any compensating improvement to efficiency. The point had been reached at which resources were beginning to drop below the critical level needed to deliver aid, let alone to ensure that it was the highest possible quality. The point had also been made in reports by the Senate and the Public Accounts Committee.

The Jackson Committee made a number of recommendations designed to transform ADAB from a clerical to a professional organisation. It recommended that ADAB be restructured, that it be given management autonomy and control over resources essential to the delivery of our aid program, and that an immediate catch-up program be set in train to remedy ADAB's critical shortage of professionally qualified and trained staff.

The Government has accepted these recommendations. ADAB must have the capability to put the Government's aid objectives into effective practice. It must have the human and other resources to ensure that the Australian people get the full value of every aid dollar spent out of their taxes. ADAB, in line with the Jackson Committee's recommendations, has now developed a new organisational structure which will allow the delivery of aid to be carried out in a professional manner. This new structure allows for an increase in senior positions and a staged increase in overall staff resources at modest cost. This financial year, aid administration costs constituted 1.54 per cent of the entire aid program. Only New Zealand had a lower proportion of overhead among all OECD countries. As a result of the administrative reforms adopted by the Government, our proportion is expected to rise to 1.7 per cent. However, it will still be one of the lowest proportions on overhead among donor countries. In the Government's opinion, it is a cost worth bearing in the cause of greater efficiency in our aid program.

I conclude by reiterating on behalf of the Government its acceptance of the major premise of the Jackson Committee; that, while it complements and enhances our political and economic interests, our overseas aid program is designed primarily to promote durable and equitable development for humanitarian reasons. Australia is a developed country in a region notable for high levels of poverty and related problems, for economies inhibited by inadequate standards of infrastructure and shortages of administrative skills. Our aid program is the logical extension of our realising the consequences, to us and the rest of the region, of the developing countries having to compete for wealth and prosperity in a free market. We are aware of the consequences which flow in developing countries when wealth and prosperity are restricted to a privileged, influential elite. Regrettably, we sometimes see evidence of the need to eradicate corruption in developing countries. We see the result, for example, when monopolies in such basic commodities as sugar or coconuts are made the personal belongings of political cronies.

Though developing countries must bear the responsibility of following development oriented policies, they cannot be blamed for all the calamitous problems confronting them. The resource base of such countries may be too narrow. They may produce only a few staples subject to sharp variability of price beyond their control. They may have populations that are too large for their resource base. They may have entrenched cultural obstacles in the way of efficiency and equity. Population growth may be faster than economic growth. They may not have easy-or even any-access to liquidity on terms that are fair and sensible. Whatever the reason, when peaceful revolution is made impossible, violent revolution is inevitable.

Aid alone will not answer these problems. But it can help point the way, whether it helps feed the hungry or cure the sick or improve the administrative skills or even just helps get fruit and vegetables to market. Above all, it can help improve the lot of individual human beings-sometimes tiny children-who are forced by the economic circumstances of their societies into debasement and exploitation. If it were only for this reason, I believe we should continue to devote the maximum possible proportion of our resources to our overseas aid program.

I could not finish on this point without mentioning trade. The more the developed countries erect barriers, or fail to lower high ones, against trade from developing countries the more they hinder the drive of those countries towards self-sustaining economic development. If they provide aid and then hinder this trade, they are in effect trying to pay conscience money to soften the impact of their protectionist policies. Maybe they are even doing that on the cheap.

I am happy to repeat the commendation I gave to the Jackson Committee report when I tabled it last year. This most comprehensive and professional analysis to be made of our aid program has stimulated a dynamic discussion of the subject which I hope will not easily or soon subside. In fact, since I tabled the report, I have received more representations on aid than on any other single issue concerned with foreign policy. Because this interest is so intense and so that there is a regular and dispassionate review of progress along the path I have just set out, I have agreed with the Chairman of the parliamentary JFADC that ADAB should report regularly to it. The frequency of these reports has not yet been decided but my inclination is that they will be at around two-year intervals.

The measures which I have just outlined, the steps which the Government has taken and which it intends to take, will ensure that our aid program fulfils the aspirations we all hold for it. I am confident that it will act to encourage competitive and relevant Australian expertise, that it will make a genuine contribution to the social development of our neighbours and, above all, that it will help raise the status and enhance the well-being of the individual people for whom it is intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in its examination of the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program picked up a statement of mine that I made nearly 10 years ago on the rationale for aid. In an address to the Swinburne College I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia, like other Western aid donors, gives aid for a complex of reasons, with humanitairian concerns being paramount.
I said:
My Government believes it is the unquestionable right of all human beings to be relieved of poverty and to have a decent standard of living.

A decade later I stand by what I said. Before going further, may I join the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in congratulating and thanking the members of the Jackson Committee for the value of their work and the recommendations that are before not only the Parliament but also, as the Minister said, the people. They have attracted intense interest. Foreign aid, of course, is a transfer of taxpayers' money to other peoples, other governments and the officials of international organisations. It is a very scarce resource and that should always be borne in mind. The Australian Government has an obligation to see that that resource is used to maximum effect.

The fact that aid is motivated, to a large extent, by humanitarian concerns should not prevent its effectiveness from becoming an issue. Nor should it obscure the fact that the aid program should also, in part, complement our strategic, political and economic interests, as the Foreign Minister indicated. What is so welcome about the Jackson report is its overriding concern to improve the effectiveness of our aid program and its understanding of the complex and varied motives that underpin it. Regrettably, the record of aid in contributing to the relief of poverty and sustained economic growth is nothing to trumpet. There are some outstanding exceptions; but, if we look towards Africa, the least developed countries and parts of our own region, we see that the situation is still grim. This, of course, has revived both the strong criticism of the `growth' approach, as it is termed, to aid programs as well as calls for a reorientation of Australia's aid program to a `basic needs' approach and the direct alleviation of poverty.

The Jackson report talks of growth with equity and the importance of making development sustainable. The report states that development cannot be achieved solely by concentrating on basic needs, that infrastructural development is also essential. I agree with the Jackson Committee and in this regard it has largely reaffirmed the work of the Harries Committee on Australia's Relations with the Third World which in its report described the basic needs approach as misplaced humanitarianism and a `band-aid' approach. That may be going too far, but at least it sets the right direction in regard to the affirmation of those who proclaim that the basic needs approach must dominate.

The Opposition believes that this emphasis on growth and development is correct. To the extent that is has gone wrong, it has been in the implementation of this approach. In that regard it has gone wrong because many thought that newly independent nations needed greater planning and centralised control of their economies than do advanced economies. This ignores history and it flies in the face of the success of the newly industrialising countries in Asia. Moreover, such an approach was probably likely to fail because of the weakness of public administration and large scale organisations in less developed countries, their public bureaucracies proving to be not only, in some instances, hopelessly inefficient but also, regrettably, in the case of many, corrupt. It has gone wrong because it was thought that uncontrolled trade with industrialised countries and openness to foreign investment and foreign enterprise were generally harmful to economic development. This again ignored history and the striking association between the extent to which developing countries have been open to foreign competition and given priority to exports and their rate of economic growth.

Growth has also been hampered by the policies pursued by the governments of many developing countries-policies which have stifled the market, exploited farmers through government marketing laws, favoured urban elites, disdvantaged agriculture, ignored the problems of population growth and overly encouraged urbanisation. The reality is that the West can most effectively improve the material well-being of developing countries not only through aid but also by reducing restrictions on trade and by opening its markets to their trade. The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) might not accept that proposition, but the need to open trade is a reality that has to be faced in our aid programs. This, regrettably, is something on which the honourable gentleman has a closed mind, according to some of the remarks he made last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all; just on a balanced basis.

—If we could all get it into balance, the situation would be a lot better. However, I will not go back to the debate last night. The Harries report was unabashed in hammering the theme that I have struck and the Jackson report also gave this considerable emphasis. I listened with interest to the Minister on this point. I was interested because he seemed to be rigidly sticking to his last and tip-toeing around this aspect. But he should not, because it goes to the very core of development programs. Moreover, I believe that the developing world would be helping itself if it were to remove or reduce restrictions on the inflow of Western personnel, Western enterprise and Western capital.

SPEECH.PARA: The needs based approach to aid is a crucially important one. But in the end a solution will be found only through sustained growth. Effective aid programs combine both and a balance has to be struck, as the Jackson report and the Foreign Minister today have acknowledged. In the end, though, the emphasis must be on growth; otherwise the cycle of poverty will not be broken. There is no point in pouring longer term development assistance down a drain. Such developmental assistance must not only be tailored to the recipient country's special needs but also be used properly by that country. As I indicated in my opening remarks when I spoke about scarce resources, resources are too scarce to allow them to be dissipated. That said, there is only one appropriate response to starving people or people crying out for immediate humanitarian assistance, and that is to help them.

Increasingly, I am convinved that on the question of basic needs assistance non-government organisations-dealt with by the Jackson report and referred to by the Minister today-can often do it better. They can frequently go where Government aid cannot. They can frequently bypass bureaucracies and operate more directly at the grass roots level. I do not want to overstate it, but this can frequently be done. This is something the coalition will examine carefully in government. At this stage it is sufficient to express the Opposition's disappointment with the Government's response to the Jackson report's recommendation on voluntary aid agencies.

As the Jackson report pointed out, the one per cent share of Australia's official aid given to voluntary agencies is well below the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development median range of 5 to 6 per cent. The Government has tinkered with increases in funding of 80 per cent; but this is from a very low base, which I am the first to admit did not increase sufficiently under our Government. While I accept the need to keep a close eye on the capacity of non-Government organisations to deliver additional allocations of aid effectively, the Government's response today through the Foreign Minister on this point is disappointing.

Let me now turn to the volume of Australian official development assistance. The Government has stated repeatedly that it intends to achieve the United Nations target of 0.7 per cent of gross national product for official development assistance. The Australian Labor Party platform specifically calls for a target of 0.5 per cent in 1985-86. Well, what has happened? The estimate for 1985-86 is 0.45 per cent of GNP. The House should wait for this, because there is some sleight of hand here. The Government has included for the first time as part of Autralia's official aid budget funding the educations of overseas students in Australia. It has backdated this bookkeeping adjustment, so-called, to the 1984-85 period.

The Jackson report recommended this procedure and it does make sense. However, for comparative purposes the real figure is not 0.5 per cent but rather 0.41 per cent, and this is the lowest percentage of aid to GNP for more than 20 years. Yet, the Labor Party proclaims 0.7 per cent as its target. It then specifically calls for a target of 0.5 per cent in this financial year. The aim is fair enough; but the Minister has cooked the books to give an accounting result that appears as more than it actually is and the net figure, when one examines it, shows that this Government, so oft proclaiming itself amongst that brotherhood of international socialists and proclaiming its duty to mankind, gives us an aid program which, in terms of percentages of GNP, is the lowest in 20 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can tell who is suffering compassion fatigue.

—A lot of fatigue is setting in here. It is not all from compassion. I will get on to that on another day. This action has come from the Labor Party which honourable members will recall has savagely criticised the volume of aid provided by previous coalition governments. The Labor Party talks of a global moral consensus. Again, this can wait until another day because we are dealing specifically with aid, but the Minister refers to a basic needs approach and the humanitarian elements involved. He said in his statement yesterday that a primary goal of Labor's foreign policy is to achieve a global moral consensus. He did not explain to me what that meant. I sought to grapple with it and I found later in the speech that the adjectives had actually been reversed. Moral global consensus had become global moral consensus, but with no explanation as to whether the twain met or what they actually meant. The global moral consensus and the high-standing position taken rhetorically by the Government do not add up in terms of the percentage of aid it has allocated. This is the party that talked so much of its role in the developing world. Frankly, its humbug is exceeded only by its hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: These cuts were not made at a time of economic crisis. If we listen to Government Ministers at each Question Time or to Labor Party rhetoric around the nation we are told that this is a time of allegedly great economic growth. Not only has the volume of aid declined dramatically but also the value of the Australian dollar has declined. On a trade weighted index the Australian dollar has fallen by 25 per cent this year. Of course, this has savagely reduced the value of our overseas aid. The Jackson report stressed the importance of Australia aspiring to the 0.7 per cent figure and stated:
Australia's aid effort should not slip back.

It has slipped back dramatically. The Labor Party as such may have a commitment to international economic development but this Government has not met that commitment. I now turn to the direction of our aid program. I agree with the conclusion that:
The Australian aid program is spread over too many countries with too many initiatives and activities implemented in too many different ways.

The Jackson report's suggestion of four geographic categories as a framework for the delivery of Australian aid seems a sensible approach. It needs to be watched in practice to ensure that it maintains sufficient flexibility. It recognises that Papua New Guinea and the South Pacific should remain central to a bilateral aid program, and properly so. Papua New Guinea should continue to remain at the centre of our aid program. This stems from the special relationship between our two countries.

The Opposition endorses what the Government is doing in seeking to move the aid program away from budgetary support and to arrangements similar to those applicable to Australia's other bilateral aid programs. The previous budgetary support has, in my view, been outstanding but I accept the need for change as does Papua New Guinea. On the latter point, it is important to recognise a matter which I will mention in a moment. Papua New Guinea faces serious development problems and requires a renewed commitment from Australia. The gradual replacement of budgetary support, which now amounts to some 30 per cent of Papua New Guinea's budget, will be much easier for us than for Papua New Guinea. It promises an increasing maturity and self-reliance to our relationship while making our aid more accountable to the Australian people-a not unimportant factor. The timetables unilaterally laid down for this change are not, in my view, what is required. Rather, considered negotiations between our two countries are the preferable approach.

I also indicate my concern with our aid commitment to the South Pacific region. Australia must exercise primary responsibility for the South Pacific. When the Fraser Government came into power in 1975 the first aid program I produced increased our aid commitment to the South Pacific by 400 per cent. That is some indication of how our interest in the South Pacific had languished under Whitlam. It is well to recall that the Foreign Minister who has reduced our aid commitment during his present period in government did the same thing when he was Treasurer in a former Government. We, in seeking to focus on the South Pacific, introduced a three-year rolling program which increased our commitment by 400 per cent. We must exercise primary responsibility for the South Pacific. There is a humanitarian need to be met and, of course, it is an area where foreign policy objectives play a part.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad that the honourable member agrees with me. I am unabashed in saying that foreign policy considerations have to be brought to bear, although I add that when pursuing such objectives we should not allow them to override strategies of growth and the meeting of basic human needs. We should admit unashamedly to the important foreign policy influences that are obviously there.

SPEECH.PARA: The inclusion by the Jackson Committee of the four Indian Ocean island states in category I, I find interesting. I am, at this stage, unconvinced by the arguments that gave them equal priority with the South Pacific. We will review their categorisation when we return to government, as I will review the whole bilateral aid program. That is not to say that they are not deserving of assistance. They patently are but, in terms of Australia's duty, I do not believe that they rank equally with other countries in category I. I remain convinced that the orientation of aid should be not only mainly regional but also concentrated in those areas where we have a real expertise. That is the thrust of the Jackson report and we will watch how the Government implements that recommendation with great interest.

A major criticism of the Jackson categorisation process, from my point of view, is the placing of Africa in category IV, whereby it is excluded from project aid and country programs. I can understand why this was done, particularly if the Committee was predicating recommendations which had as their fount a concentration on our own region. I have long listened to people telling me that we should not be involved in aid programs in Africa because it is a long way away and we do not get too involved in South America and the like. We have increasingly-again, through the efforts of the previous government-been raising the profile of Australia and its effectiveness in the Commonwealth of nations through very close contact with Commonwealth leaders at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meetings. We have been able not only to make significant shifts in foreign policy internationally but also to meet areas of very real need. I do not say that that is the prime criterion. That is by no means the case. Meeting basic needs and putting them in balance with the overwhelming stress on growth are the criteria. The region must be the area of primary influence. I can understand why this was done but I do not agree with it. I disagree with the Jackson report whilst accepting that with scarce and limited resources programs will be somewhat restricted to Africa in comparison with those which are our primary duty. In addition to providing some project aid to Africa, I believe that we need to accept the need for technical assistance in such areas as agriculture and to consider joining the African Development Bank.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I visited Ethiopia at the end of last year. What is happening there is symptomatic of what is occurring throughout much of Africa. It is becoming apparent that Africa is confronted by a breathtaking crisis which the international community cannot turn its back on. I pause to say that, whilst there might be some faults and deliquencies in the West's response to the tragedy that has unfolded in Ethiopia and the Sudan, I have not seen much evidence of humanitarian response from the Soviet Union and its satellites. But that is for another day also.

SPEECH.PARA: It is becoming apparent that Africa is confronted by a breathtaking crisis. It is not something we can turn our back upon, nor can it be approached in a piecemeal fashion. The former approach is morally unacceptable, while the latter would serve only to make the problems interminable. The one and only good point-if one can call anything in this context a good point-regarding the tragic starvation in Africa is that we can fix it in the short term by feeding people. The one thing we know is that if we get food in and it is distributed, we are at least meeting in the short term the crisis of starvation that is facing countless millions of people. But in meeting the medium to long term problems the international record is frankly deplorable. The tragedy clearly will worsen unless there is the political will to plan for the future. There is little or no evidence of this occurring. I have not sought to make this a political issue for the obvious reason that one needs as much community support as one can get for programs to relieve starvation in Ethiopia. I do not intend today to say any more than that the Australian Government, with the rest of the international community, through the Foreign Minister, have got to inject some political will to move this tragedy to a point where the medium to long term problems are dealt with.

If I had been Foreign Minister, I say frankly that I would have pressed for a meeting of my international colleagues to plan agricultural development and reafforestation in Africa. We came together at the Foreign Minister level and I chaired a meeting in Geneva under the auspices of the United Nations to meet the critical tragedy that was unfolding in Cambodia. We received immediate pledges of signficant sums of money. Therefore, I am not thinking of the short term, but of getting foreign Ministers together to plan, in conjunction with African countries, what can be done in the medium to long term. If that is not done now, Africa will be facing this critical situation year in year out. The suffering of people that goes on simply because there is a lack of political will to look beyond the problem of today and to seek to solve the problem of the future is deplorable. I hope that the Minister will be able to crank up the international community in 1986. The same must be done for Africa as was done in meeting the short term problem in Cambodia, or the long term outlook will be a disaster even worse than the immediate tragedy we are facing. We need to undertake a comprehensive and co-ordinated donor approach to both the short term and long term problems. The ultimate goal must be to return Africa to food self-sufficiency.

Apart from providing substantial emergency relief aid, the Western World must also bring persuasive pressures to bear. People tend to duck this. There is talk of the human tragedy, but there are certain realities behind these tragedies, and pressures have to be brought to bear to fix them. Long term development assistance increasingly should in these situations be long term assistance conditional on African governments adopting policies conducive to agricultural production and efficiency. These must provide encouragement and incentives to smallholder producers, and the criteria for such long term assistance in my view should be whether or not there is some chance of success.

Another debate over aid that I must mention concerns the bilateral/multilateral mix. The Jackson report did not examine in great detail the effectiveness of multilateral aid. It did, however, recommend our involvement in the African Development Bank and the Caribbean Development Bank, and I am inclined to agree. I think my friend the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney), will inject a note of approval on the Caribbean Development Bank, as he did earlier when I referred to the African Development Bank. I will not push it too hard, although I am trying to enlist a little support.

The Minister in his statement went to some length to explain why it was difficult to cut back on our multilaterial aid effort. The fact is that under Labor there has been a drift to multilateral aid and this becomes clearer if one removes the little fix of the overseas student component from the bilateral aid figures.

The international financial institutions deserve our support. Their importance at this time cannot be overstated. The Jackson report confirms that such funds are increasingly used effectively. My problems with multilateral aid refer particularly to many of the United Nations organisations. There is a trend in this country, and in a few other places, that one is not allowed to criticise the United Nations. I am not talking of the talkfest of the General Assembly and other matters that should be looked at and examined and procedures implemented, but of some of these United Nations agencies. I did not do enough of this myself when I had the capacity to do it some ten years ago, but I will in the future. There is very little accountability, no control over their use, and very little benefit to Australian industry. The main argument in favour of multilateral aid is that it is said to be de-politicised, but in my view that argument is quite misleading. Political control and accountability is substituted by the control of international officials and no accountability.

Furthermore, when one looks at the multilateral organisations such as the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, a body which through its scientific and industrial research has an impact in some fields of aid, and more particularly at the Food and Agriculture Organisation, one sees that they are a shambles. When one examines the role played by all the recipients in demanding the sort of budget FAO gets compared to the influence that donor nations have over it, one finds that they are screaming out for reform. I have some signficant questions in my mind about the drift to further multilateral aid. Of course, multilateral aid will always exist with us. Of course we will continue many programs, but I am not as impressed with, and on behalf of the Opposition do not accept, the Jackson recommendation of maintaining a share of multilateral aid at roughly 25 per cent, but I agree that there should be a bias towards development banks.

I now turn to the question of aid and trade. I have already stated the Opposition's view that trade is the key to economic development. The Minister has raised a different aspect, and that is the question of industry participation in that aid program. The Minister has been very cautious in his statement today on this link, acknowledging that:

There is no reason why industry should not take part in our aid program, so long as equity and effectiveness remain primary considerations and so long as its guiding principle is strictly observed; the aid given must be good for the recipient.

I concur with this cautious approach. Opportunities for Australian business should open up in Papua New Guinea with a gradual re-orientation of our aid to project aid and accordingly tied to some provision of Australian goods and services. Similar benefits should accrue with a slight shift away from multilateral aid to bilateral aid and a more aggressive approach in bidding for contracts financed by multilateral organisations. One can look at the total value of some of the contracts, as indeed did the Minister, and compare that figure with our aid program. But I have to say again, in re-examining my own administration for the period I was Foreign Minister and looking at what Australian industry does and what a government can do to try to assist in this area to encourage Australian industry more, that our performance to date has not been particularly good.

With regard to aid/trade financing mechanisms, there is no point living in fantasy land. Objectionable as many of these mechanisms are-and to those of us who believe that these mechanisms distort international trade they are objectionable-I have to face the reality that Australia cannot allow its own industry to be placed at a competitive disadvantage by other donors' aggressive use of aid to foster their own exports. Again a careful balance is required between our industry needs and the goals for our overseas development assistance program. The two are not incompatible-I use the double negative-and the situation should be kept under constant review. I am as cautious on that matter as the Minister is.

Let me now turn to one aspect of the Jackson report which the Minister has ignored. It is easy to understand why he ignored it because the Jackson Committee's recommendation on overseas students was comprehensively rolled in Cabinet. As I understand it, the Foreign Minister put the recommendation but as we know it was not successful. I am sorry that it was not successful. I am sorry that the wimpish arguments of the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) prevailed. On this issue the Government was presented with two fundamentally different reports-the report of the Committee of Review of Private Overseas Student Policy, the Goldring report, and the Jackson report. In my view the Goldring report was conservative, rigid and hopelessly myopic. It was a document in favour of the status quo and entrenched bureaucratic educational interests. The Jackson report, to the contrary, offered a more dynamic and radical alternative which promised both an expansion in educational services and an increasingly effective educational aid program. This Government has opted for the shoddy compromise. But basically, as the Minister for Education said on 22 March, the Government was adopting `basically the Goldring approach'.

The great pity is that the market approach advocated by the Jackson report would not only provide Australia with an export industry but also it would have enabled Australia to meet its foreign aid obligations in a clear and equitable manner. We would have had a comprehensive system of scholarships based on merit and which included developmental criteria. We would have allowed foreign students unlimited access to tertiary institutes in Australia without prejudicing Australian students. We have now not allowed foreign students unlimited access to our tertiary institutes as a consequence of this extraordinarily shoddy compromise which is based on what I consider to be the backward-looking recommendations of the Goldring report.

In conclusion, I am a firm believer in Australia maintaining its aid programs as grants rather than as loans. Debt is the major problem facing developing countries and aid by way of loans to be repaid only adds to that crippling burden. Australian governments of both political persuasions have been correct in ensuring our aid is overwhelmingly in grant form. In government we will not change this.
