The record of the Labor Government on development issues generally, and aid in particular, is disappointing. It has not carried on the work of the Fraser Government on north-south issues. It has abandoned any pretence of obtaining promised aid levels and has ignored the major problems of international debt and poverty in the Third World.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I table the text of a statement relating to the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in respect of the Murrumbidgee in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to advise honourable members of the Government's decisions in relation to the future of the provisional Parliament House. The Government has considered the report by the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House concerning the future of the provisional parliament building. Before responding to this report, however, I would like to say that we are all indebted to the Committee for the work and effort that went into the making of the report. This building, which has witnessed events affecting the lives of all Australians over nearly 60 years, has exerted its own peculiar influence on those events and the people working within it. The Committee has come to grips with a most difficult task in proposing suitable and fitting purposes for a building that has been at the centre of Australian political and cultural development for so long.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government agrees with recommendation No. 1 of the Committee that the building, which has significant historical and heritage value, should not be demolished. With respect to the second recommendation, the Government considers that any decision to retain intact, modify, or restore the building to its 1927 form should be deferred pending examination of the findings of the conservation analysis currently under way. The Government agrees with the view expressed in the Committee's report that any future use of the building should take cognisance of the building's history and its location in the heart of the Parliamentary Triangle. The building therefore would need to incorporate national purposes and these should promote public access to and use of the building.

While not opposing that part of recommendation No. 3 concerning the concept of the building including a constitutional-political history museum, such use would require only part of the available space. Furthermore the Government considers that the function and the range of related existing and planned institutions must be kept in mind in developing the museum proposal. Accordingly, an interdepartmental committee is to be established to consider the appropriateness of establishing a constitutional museum, including its scope, size and relationship with other institutions. That committee will also, in light of the findings of the conservation analysis, give detailed consideration to the need for structural modifications to and the multiple-use and management of the provisional Parliament House.

A number of other possible users include: A meeting place for Premiers' and like conferences, headquarters of international organisations of which Australia is a member. The Government agrees with the Committee's view that Canberra is an excellent venue for such headquarters, but it does not agree with the Committee that the building is unsuitable for such purposes. Provided that special security arrangements can be made, these could be appropriate uses for the parts of the building. It could also be used as a general information and tourist facility in the Parliamentary Zone. Given the building's central location and the planning intention of developing and land axis concept with malls and tourist-related facilities down to the lake a Regatta Point-type exhibition could be fitting. Restaurant, kiosk and creche facilities would also be in keeping with such plans as well as being ideally located for tourist purposes.

Turning to the recommendation relating to the collection of works of art and other items currently displayed or stored in the provisional building, the Government would wish that most of the more significant objects concerning Australia's constitutional and parliamentary development be maintained together in what is recognised as a valuable national collection in its entirety. If a constitutional museum is established, the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) will therefore be consulting with the Presiding Officers with a view to making suitable arrangements for the display of relevant items on an `on loan' basis in the museum.

With respect to the future management of the building, it is the Government's view that control of the building and its remaining contents should reside with the Government after the Parliament moves to the new Parliament House. This matter shall be considered by the IDC in relation to the museum proposal and the management arrangements for the building as a whole post-1988.

The conservation analysis and plan recommended by the Committee is, as previously mentioned, already under way. Howard Tanner and Associates Pty. Ltd, a firm of architects and conservation planners, has been briefed to undertake the conservation analysis. The Government will report further to the Parliament after the IDC has considered the findings of the conservation analysis. Finally, the Government agrees with the Committee that the continued long term use of the provisional Parliament House by parliamentary departments is inappropriate following the transfer of Parliament to the new Parliament House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am afraid that the Government seems to have failed to realise that this is the people's Parliament. This Parliament House, while termed a provisional building, is in fact something that is very much part of the Australian community. The decision as to the future of this place is not for the Government to take. It is not for the Government to come in here today, through the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes), and tell us what the Government is going to do. It is not for the bureaucrats of Canberra to determine the use of a Parliament that has been so vital in the constitutional evolution of Australia. This Parliament, since 1927, has been the core of parliamentary debate for all those areas represented by either senators or members of the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, I regard the statement by the Minister not only as inept but also as a total abuse of the ultimate responsibility of the Parliament. It is not for the Government to come in here and tell the Parliament what it is going to do in this respect. In case the Minister has forgotten, as some Ministers tend to do-with their heads in the clouds and their feet feeling that they really do not need to worry about those lesser beings who are elected members of parliament-let me remind him that the fate of this place will not be determined by the Government. It will be determined by the senators and members of this place for the time being.

While there are elements within the statement with which I agree, I find the high-handed, arrogant approach that has been adopted totally unacceptable. For example, we are told that there is to be an interdepartmental committee to determine some aspects of the use of the place. Why on earth can we not have a parliamentary committee? What is up with those who own, control, run, and live and work in this place? Are the members of the Australian Labor Party so subject to the bureaucracy that everything that they wish to do is determined not by individual decision but by what they are told to do? We can see the puppets of the Labor Party answering to the beck and call of the bureaucrats in the same way as they do to the Australian Council of Trade Unions. In the last few days the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) has told us how the ACTU got the better of him again in the dealings on superannuation. The Minister for Territories came into the Parliament and said: `Never mind parliamentarians telling the people of Australia what they are going to do with this place. We will let the matter be decided by the bureaucrats'. I know that the bureaucrats know better than the Government, because the Government is inept and hopeless, but I let the members of the Government know that there are some people in this place who would rather like to have an opportunity to pass judgment on whether this Parliament House will be used and, if so, for what purpose.

I now turn my attention to the facilities in this chamber itself. There are few more hallowed or more traditional parts of Australia than this debating forum. It is a small chamber. It is not large compared with the size of perhaps the Congress of the United States of America or some of the newer parliaments in some of the countries we have seen around the world which try to emulate our democratic system. It is a chamber in which debate is facilitated by the proximity which we enjoy between one side of the House and the other. It is a debating forum in which it is possible for reasonable discussion to take place. There are opportunities for visitors in the gallery, Press in the gallery and for those listening to the broadcast today to get some idea of what is going on in the Parliament. But what does the Government want to do? It says: `Let the matter be decided by the bureaucrats. We will set up an interdepartmental committee'. An IDC is going to resolve the future of the Parliament House. Never mind whether it is possible for parliamentarians to consider the appropriateness of establishing a constitutional museum, including its scope, size and relationship with other institutions, which is the first of the reference points for the IDC. Never mind letting parliamentarians give detailed consideration to the need for structural modifications to and the multiple use and management of the provisional Parliament House. I would have thought that it would be more appropriate for the Minister to tell Mr Speaker, who is not present in this chamber at the moment, and the President that he would be prepared to permit the officers of the Parliament to consider in what way, and to what degree, the facilities of this chamber could be preserved and how those other facilities around the Parliament might best be used in the future. I do not regard it as acceptable that the Government is telling us that it has appointed a firm of architects and conservation planners to undertake a conservation analysis.

It is not for the Government to undertake these things: It is for the Parliament to undertake them. For the time being, this is the home of the Parliament. Even the Minister should know that the police officers we see about this place have no authority in here unless directed by Mr Speaker himself, as former Speaker Scholes would recall. I find it incredible that a government which at times pretends that it has some concern for the parliamentary insitution seems to ignore it, and arbitrarily refers a number of matters first to an IDC and second to a firm of architects, without discussing them in the Parliament itself.

I know that the Parliament has financial dependence on the Government, but let it be known to all that there is now a one-line appropriation for the Parliament. It would have been quite appropriate for the Government-of course, it has to declare its hand-to explain its attitude to each of the recommendations of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. I do not believe it appropriate that it should arbitrarily tell us what is to be done. I believe those are matters which should have been processed by consultation with the Committee. I suggest to the Minister that he take back to his colleagues the suggestion that in the evolution of the necessary decisions regarding the future of this place it certainly would be far more desirable that the Government act in a consultative way rather than, as now seems to be the case, pass the buck to bureaucrats to make the final determination on how this place will be used.

There are a number of matters about which each of us, I think, is concerned in terms of the future of this Parliament House. I think there are difficulties in some of the facilities. The statement mentions the southern facade of this building. One of the matters which influenced me in supporting the decision to construct a new Parliament House was that I believe probably all the water pipes, electrical fittings and many of the infrastructures of this building need replacement. The building has been here since 1927. It is an old building. There could well be a fire risk unless many of those things are replaced. Therefore, it is essential that when this building is converted for future use the same treatment be accorded it as was given to West Block. For those listening on the radio, West Block is one of those older government office blocks that have been tenanted and used by the bureaucracy since approximately the time this provisional Parliament House building was occupied. At the time this building is converted many of its infrastructures and services will need to be re-examined. Many of them may need replacement. It is essential, whatever is done, that it be borne in mind that some of those facilities-I mentioned the southern facade-be examined internally as well as externally.

As far as the internal facilities are concerned, I do not know whether many honourable members have been through the rabbit warren that is Parliament House. There are an incredible number of buildings which I suspect very few honourable members have visited. I have had an opportunity to go into most of them. There are rooms out the back of this place which I think most of us do not know exist. There is just about as much accommodation for those who work in and service the place as there is for those who are elected to it. Of course that accommodation is necessary. I draw attention to it because I think that whatever purpose this place is used for it will be necessary perhaps to remove some of it, to modify it, and to take into account the possibilities that I think there are for preserving this debating forum and the Senate chamber for whatever purposes might be ultimately decided.

In that respect, I certainly see it as being highly desirable that we encourage the use of this building for regular meetings. For that reason, I tend to agree with the statement by the Minister that it is possible that this be a meeting place for conferences such as the Premiers Conference. However, I believe it should not be used for only public-type conferences. It is an appropriate place for meetings that might well be of a broader national nature. It has been suggested that it become the headquarters of international organisations. If not the headquarters, it can certainly be a forum where international bodies and delegates from this country to international bodies might well find it convenient to present this nation's point of view. I believe that this forum and the Senate have to be preserved. Whatever adjunct there might be in terms of a museum or tourist facility, the two chambers must continue to be the focal point.

I hesitate also when I look at some of the other recommendations. I hope that the King's Hall facility will be retained. I certainly hope, too, that those library facilities, which I think have a particularly important place, could also be left in their present form. From my perspective, therefore, I believe that it is important that a number of integral parts of this building should be retained-the two chambers, King's Hall and perhaps, with some adaptation, the Parliamentary Library. The rest of the building largely, I think, has a great deal of flexibility. There will need to be a good deal of modification for it to suit whatever ultimate purpose the building might fill.

Above all, I stress to the Government that it is not for the Government to determine the use of this building. We all accept that within the Parliamentary Triangle there must be particular concern for the future. The John Gorton Government took particular decisions that ensured that there would be no development within that Triangle without it being referred to the Parliament. I know that this reference by the Minister comes about in part because of that obligation. I think it is essential, however, that before any decisions are taken, that there be reasonable unanimity among members of both Houses. It is a very important building. It is one that I think should remain, therefore, within the control of the Speaker and the President rather than of the government of the day. I am concerned at the attitude that seems to have been taken by the Government to a report which certainly showed care and consideration and, as far as I am aware, was unanimously agreed to by those who represented all parties in this place on what is, after all, a joint standing committee.

I believe therefore that, while we take note of the statement made by the Minister, one can only have reservations about the arbitrary nature of the Government's response and the degree to which it seems to be quite unprepared to listen to the very valid conclusions reached by those who represent us on a committee that was constituted specifically to concern itself with both the new Parliament House and the future of this one. For that reason, members on this side of the House will watch, with very considerable interest and not a little concern, future developments and whatever statements might be made by the Minister or his successor on this matter. Indeed, one believes that only with a change of government will proper care and concern be given to this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will be a long time.
—It will not be long at all.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—The Minister for Territories claims to have been misrepresented. He may proceed.

—I recognise that the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) was having a bit of a fling at the Government, but I think it is fair to inform him that the appointment of architects to do a conservation study is in response to a recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House. I think it is wrong to suggest that the Government is acting improperly in responding to it. Also, the Presiding Officers are on the interdepartmental committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the New Parliament House at the time when it deliberated on this matter and was one of those who concurred in the report of the Joint Committee. I welcome the assurance of the Minister for Territories (Mr Scholes) that the Speaker and the President of the Senate are to be involved in an interdepartmental committee. But I must say that, as a member of the Committee, I am concerned at the procedures that the Government has used to second-guess, I suggest, the views of the members of the Parliament. When we deliberated on this matter and came forward with a detailed and comprehensive report to the Parliament, it was after consideration of numerous submissions by various government departments which had views on what ought to occur in relation to this site. The Committee came up with quite firm views as to the way in which this building ought to be managed in the future; that there ought to be a continuing involvement of the Parliament in the management of it, particularly in relation to the important furnishings of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is most regrettable that the Government has determined to use the recommendation relating to the conservation analysis for rejecting the decisions of the parliamentary Committee on whether this building should be retained intact, modified or restored, because experts are now being asked to adjudicate on a matter on which the parliamentary Committee had already made a determination after receiving a great deal of information on that subject. The members came to the view that it was inappropriate to demolish very significant parts of our history, even the areas which are of significance to people who were in this place in 1975-I think that that will be a significant point in the future which people will want to be concerned about and talk about-and return to the 1927 model. It was the view of members at that time that this question ought not to be one to be handed over to some experts to try to tell us that the 1927 model was far more preferable and that we ought to avoid the history that has been made, even in recent times, in this building.

I would like to comment on the question of the interdepartmental committee, because it is being asked to second-guess the decisions of members of parliament who have already commented on those decisions of the bureaucrats. I think that it is most unfortunate for a government to deal with the Parliament in this way. I ask the Government to take this matter back and to develop ways and means in which the members of the Parliament-not only the Speaker and the President, the Presiding Officers, but the parliamentary committees-will be the determinants of the views that ought to be taken. The Government should make some observations on it, but it should certainly not ask the bureaucracy to take it over, as I believe has been done in the way in which the Government has responded to the report.

DEBATE.TITLE: SECOND REGIONAL RADIO NETWORK FOR THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I table a policy discussion paper on the second regional radio network for the Australian Broadcasting Commission and seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second regional radio network is a strategic element of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's plan to provide all Australians with three high quality radio services: ABC regional radio, ABC radio national; and the fine music and cultural ABC-FM service. These three services will be available across Australia from 26 January next year via the Aussat domestic satellite system. In addition, the Government gave an election commitment to increase the number of studios and transmitters attached to the ABC's terrestrial regional networks through the introduction of a second regional radio network. We said in 1983 that we would commence the introduction of this network within our first three years of office. We have achieved this goal.

SPEECH.PARA: Already, planning for the second regional radio network is under way. Part of this planning involves the allocation of frequencies to the new network. In many parts of Australia FM radio frequencies will be used. Honourable members will recall that the shortage of FM frequencies was caused by the previous allocation of parts of the FM radio band to television services for channels 3, 4 and 5. This Government has already decided to clear the FM radio band of television services and as this work proceeds there will be more frequencies available for FM radio services including the second regional radio network.
The second regional radio network will benefit over four million people located throughout regional Australia. This initiative will have three results:
1. The employment of some 60 additional staff to generate regional program content.
2. The construction of 16 new regional radio studios and the upgrading of all existing regional studios. New studios are proposed for the following centres:
In New South Wales: Coffs Harbour, Lismore and Dubbo;
In Victoria: Traralgon, Ballarat, Bendigo, Shepparton, Swan Hill, Mildura and Warrnambool;
In Queensland: The Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast and Mount Isa;
In Western Australia: Karratha, Derby and Kununurra.

3. Over the next five years, all this activity will lead to the progressive doubling of the amount of regionally produced programs-programs that will reflect the need for more local news, information and current affairs programs, as well as interviews with local identities.

Honourable members will be aware that this Government has been working to equalise broadcasting services throughout Australia. Honourable members will also be aware that this Government has already addressed the provision of broadcasting services in Australia in three ways:

First, all Australians, no matter how remote, will be able to receive ABC TV and radio, either through terrestrial transmitters, or by satellite through the homestead and community broadcasting satellite service-HACBSS;

Second, over 600,000 people not currently receiving commercial television will be eligible to receive the remote commercial television service RCTS through the Aussat satellite; and third, my Department's forward development unit FDU has reported on options for the provision of three commercial television services to the majority of Australians within the next few years.

Having successfully initiated the equalisation of television services throughout the country, the Government is now turning attention to radio services throughout regional Australia. The ABC's second regional radio network is one aspect of this planning. I commend this policy discussion paper to the House and invite honourable members, broadcasting organisations and other interested parties to provide me with their comments over the next two months. I present the following paper:
Second Regional Radio Network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-Ministerial Statement, 29 November 1985.
Motion (by Mr Holding) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the statement on a second regional radio network for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation made by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). The Opposition welcomes the recommendations presented by the ABC. For many years we have recognised the need and the desirability of having more services to the regions of Australia. As well as that, we have recognised the importance of blending localism with national programs in program planning. I am pleased that the Minister and, above all, the ABC in preparing the booklet just tabled by the Minister have recognised that so that people throughout Australia will be able to get what is now called ABC Radio National and, as well, have a greater localism in the programming and in news presentations as an alternative service over and above the services which the metropolitan areas get through Radio National. It is very important that people throughout Australia will now have access to both channels of ABC radio.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a matter which goes back many years, as indeed the booklet itself recalls. The previous Government recognised the need for this development but also recognised the need to get the ABC's house in order. It set up what is now known as the Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It was this committee which recommended that the provision of a second network of outlets for the ABC radio should continue to have the highest priority in ABC radio development because it is the best means of redressing the imbalance of ABC radio services between metropolitan and regional areas. I am delighted that ABC now feels itself able to be organised in this manner.

I also say that with the Minister's co-operation I have had the opportunity of seeing the physical arrangements of the ABC in several parts of Australia and talking to senior management of the ABC. I have become privy to some of the program, engineering, property, purchasing and development work of the ABC. I believe it is moving in the right direction. I join with the Minister in urging those people who wish to make submissions on the basis of the document, to modify or improve the proposals in the document, to make those submissions to the Minister in the next two months. I do not doubt that the most serious issue arising out of this document will not be its objectives so much but where the programming actually is carried out. I do not doubt that honourable members on both sides of the House will have different views to advance to the Minister over the next few weeks. The timing is unfortunate in one sense that we have the Christmas break coming down. I join with the Minister in urging everyone who has a strong view about this subject to focus on it immediately and get his views in before Christmas. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I table a copy of the internal audit review by Price Waterhouse of the Australian Institute of Sport.

That this House, in accordance with the provisions of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908, authorises the publication of the internal audit review by Price Waterhouse into the Australian Institute of Sport.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATION OF THE AUSTRALIAN INSTITUTE OF SPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I refer honourable members to my comments to the House on 19 November 1985 concerning criticisms made that day in the Daily Telegraph of certain aspects of the administration of the Australian Institute of Sport-AIS. Further news- paper articles have since appeared and I have commented on these in answer to questions in the House. I indicated on 19 November that Price Waterhouse, the contracted internal auditor to the AIS, was to look into the matters raised. The terms of reference for this review, as authorised by the Chairman of the Board of Management, Professor John Bloomfield, were:

SPEECH.PARA: As internal auditors to the Australian Institute of Sport undertake an internal audit examination of:
1. The specific allegations made in newspaper articles appearing in the Daily Telegraph of 19 and 20 November 1985 and any subsequent criticisms which are relevant.
2. The adequacy and efficiency of financial management practices and controls at the Australian Institute of Sport.
A report by close of business on Wednesday 27 November 1985 is desired.

The letter conveying the terms of reference to Price Waterhouse was signed by the Secretary to my Department, who is also a board member of the AIS, on behalf of the Chairman of the Board of Management who lives in Perth. The letter indicated, amongst other things, that:

Whilst it is for the Board to consider the question of priorities in financial terms, your examination might please provide any information you consider appropriate and on which decisions can be made. I will be providing the Minister with advice on this aspect. Of course as internal auditors you have full and open access to all staff and records at the Institute and I give you my assurance that this will occur. Should you, during the course of your examination, wish to discuss aspects with me, please feel free to do so.

Price Waterhouse yesterday provided the Chairman of the Board of Management, Professor John Bloomfield, with an interim report, a copy of which the Chairman has given me. I thank Price Waterhouse for providing this report so quickly. The auditor indicated that due to time constraints a more detailed report on the second term of reference is to be provided at a later date. Further reports will be made to the Board in the course of normal internal audit examinations.

Let me say at the outset that no claim of an illegal act or act of impropriety can be levelled at the AIS. As I suggested to the Parliament last week, and I now reiterate, the Government and the Institute have nothing to fear from this report. The overall expenses of the Chief Executive, Dr John Cheffers, as the report states, were completely justified. This was because of the higher profile the AIS deserved and the excellent return accruing to the AIS from the increased publicity generated from this heightened recognition.

The AIS was established under the Australian Capital Territory Companies Act and this report shows that no act of an illegal nature has been performed by the staff of the AIS which has acted at all times in accordance with the articles under which the AIS was established. Given its company basis honourable members must be aware that the AIS does not operate in the same way as a government department or statutory authority. As I said in the House last week I have implied no criticism of Minister Bob Ellicott, who set up the AIS with the structure of a private company. There was an urgency to get the AIS up and running and I suspect that Minister Ellicott would have preferred some different kind of legislative set-up had time been available to him. Public Service guidelines and structures cannot be readily applied to the Institute which operates with all the autonomy available to a private company, albeit under the control of the management board.

I turn now to the specific allegations in the Daily Telegraph and briefly address the report's basic findings on each point. The Daily Telegraph drew attention to increases in the Institute's expenditure on hospitality and stated:
The auditor indicated that given the increased size of the Institute and the desire to lift its profile, the extra expenditure has been justified in purely commercial terms.
Entertainment of members at the 1985 Tax Summit:
The auditor found that the cost `does not appear excessive given the importance of the occasion and the amount of publicity received'.
Travel by AIS staff Cheffers, Purnell and Bowman to Melbourne and Sydney on the weekend of this year's football grand finals:

The auditor found that individual costs were not unreasonable but considered the broader question as to whether the travel was necessarily a matter for management and the Board. The records show that Dr Cheffers and his colleagues undertook personal appearances, speeches and marketing tasks on these trips. Reference is made in the report to the matter of the `Carbine Club' lunch refuting the allegation that Cheffers lied on this issue.
Cuts in coaching budgets:
The auditor found that there were no cuts made to the budgets allocated to individual sports and for the purpose of providing funds to the Illawarra Institute of Sport.
Purchase of expensive office equipment:

The Auditor noted that the Daily Telegraph had inaccurately over-quoted these costs. Whilst expressing the view that there was `some justification' for this level of expenditure the auditor felt that `the same effect could have been achieved at less expense, particularly in so far as the desk is concerned'.
I am advised that the configuration of this desk is such that it is used also as a conference table. As far as the appointment of Dr Jean Roberts is concerned:
The auditor indicated that `we have been unable to find any evidence of undue influence being exerted by the Executive Director in relation to the appointment of Dr Jean Roberts'.
Higher duties allowances:
The auditor found that `the payment of higher duties allowance to the General Manager was made in accordance with existing Institute policies'.
Spot merit scheme and travel of General Manager's wife:

The auditor indicated that `the payment of a spot merit award to the General Manager appears to be within the guidelines for the scheme approved by the Board but notes that it exceeded the approved limit'.
Employment of Executive Director's family:

I note that the Daily Telegraph article alleges that Dr Cheffers said his son had not worked at the Institute. Dr Cheffers advises me that he was never asked a direct question about his son and in fact had not denied it.
He was asked whether members of his family had worked there and he replied: `Yes, my daughter'. He claims his son's employment as a computer programmer was so brief he did not recall it.
With respect to the payment made to Dr Cheffers' son, the auditor noted that `the consulting fee of $150 per day was reasonable by consulting fee standards'.
The purchase of rowing boats:

The auditor did not find any impropriety and while noting that aspects of the quotation process were rather `clumsy' found the `initial quotation by Sykes was reduced as a result of the Institute adopting the common commercial practice of asking the preferred supplier to ``sharpen their pencil'' '.
The final result was that the AIS procured the best boat at the cheapest possible price. Is this a scandal?

I would like to refer now to a matter which I find personally distasteful; that is, the allegation by the Daily Telegraph that the Executive Director, Dr John Cheffers, used coercive tactics in attempting to influence appointments to the Australian Athletics Union. This allegation has not been substantiated, and I have been advised by Dr Cheffers that the allegations made by `unidentified sources' to the Daily Telegraph are untrue.

Honourable members will see that these allegations have been dealt with comprehensively by the internal auditors, Price Waterhouse, and it becomes clear that they are nothing more than scurrilous and mischievous claims which, when analysed closely, amount to very little-at most an occasional display of lack of judgment at the management level within the Institute. Certainly no instance of illegality, dishonesty, misappropriation or the like has been made by the auditor. In fact, the House should be aware that as recently as 4 November 1985 the Commonwealth Auditor-General wrote to me saying, amongst other things:
Australian Institute of Sport
The audit of the Institute for 1984-85 has been completed and a copy of the financial statements and my report thereon are attached for your information.
The results of the audit of the Institute's accounts and records were satisfactory.
I understand that the Auditor-General will be examining Price Waterhouse's findings in the current review to decide whether his office needs to conduct any further examinations at this stage.

I should also mention that the AIS Articles of Association provide that the business and affairs of the Institute shall be overseen by its Board of Management. The Articles also provide that the Board may delegate to or confer upon the Executive Director any of its powers. Pursuant to these provisions, the Executive Director, under the Board, has been responsible for the day-to-day management of the AIS, exercising substantial powers. The auditor has addressed in a preliminary way the broader question of financial management and controls, and the budget process. The report recognises that steps are being taken to overcome certain weaknesses, and adds:

Given the size of the Institute, particularly now that it has assumed responsibility for the running of the National Sports Centre and all its facilities, we believe the administration and finance sections have performed remarkably well.
However, these increased responsibilities made more urgent a move to statutory authority basis and were the catalyst for these changes I set in train many months ago.

I should like to go on record that I have been mindful of the need to review the basic structure of the AIS for quite some time and as early as April this year I suggested to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) that we initiate a joint review of the Institute's staffing and funding arrangements. This was agreed to in September and I have asked the Board to put it in train.

The auditor indicated that the Board's move to establish a finance committee should be applauded and, in recognition of the need to institute tighter financial controls, the Board of Management has advised me that it has today expanded the role of the finance committee that it established on 29 October 1985 into a more comprehensively-tasked executive committee. This committee of Board members will monitor and oversight the executive and financial management of the AIS. The auditor has identified a potential budget shortfall of $450,000. I am advised that the Board today at its regular scheduled meeting, as a matter of routine business practice, took the necessary action to have a balanced budget for the full financial year. This is exactly the practice followed by companies, private or public, government departments and authorities all over Australia.

As I indicated to the House last week, I have put in place the necessary arrangements to convert the AIS from a company to a statutory authority. Under this arrangement the AIS becomes completely accountable to the Parliament. My action has been in train for months and I will not accept the suggestion that I reacted to baseless newspaper articles in administering my portfolio. This matter of statutory authority basis was considered by the Government on 13 November and endorsed on 18 November before any newspaper report appeared. I am sure honourable members opposite, all Australians, and particularly the Minister who began the Institute, Bob Ellicott, will be extremely concerned at the damage these shallow allegations could cause the AIS.

It is a great pity that the Institute, which was set up by the Opposition and has grown to become the world's greatest sports training institute, should be placed in such a negative light by such doubtful allegations. I am sure all will appreciate that the survival and the success of the Institute depend upon the support of not only sponsors and the Australian sporting community but also all Australians.

A possible allegation that could be levelled at the AIS staff is that they have been too enthusiastic in selling their product. But that has obviously worked as sponsorship and recognition of the AIS have hit high levels. The United States Academy of Sport recently awarded a distinguished service award to me in recognition of the standing, world wide, of the Australian Institute of Sport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you give it to the Institute?

—What does the honourable member think I did with it? The message that the AIS is here, it is the best in the world, and Australia is again on the track to taking on the best, has obviously got across. It was a job that needed to be done and the results will obviously have a great and beneficial effect on national pride and international identity. Overblown articles implying lavish expenditure, which have been discounted in the auditors' report, have done no good for the reputation of the AIS or for sport generally in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope that the Daily Telegraph will rectify the damage its sensationalism has caused in the very near future and publish positive articles on what the AIS is really all about and what its achievements are, because they are considerable and a matter of great pride. I must pause here to pay tribute to the Opposition shadow Minister, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), who throughout the course of this unnecessary business, while pursuing his legitimate inquiries, has shown a genuine concern for the future of the Institute. It is a pity that one small section of the media has not been able to emulate this responsible behaviour.

Let me assure the House that if there are any matters in the future that I consider warrant further action I will have absolutely no hesitation in taking swift and appropriate action at that time. In closing, I want to reiterate my earlier view that exaggerated criticisms of administration, and of style, involving individuals should not be allowed to obscure the magnificent job that has been done in developing the Institute into the finest sports training institute in the world.

The members of the Board under Kevan Gosper, recently retired, and now Professor John Bloomfield, are all highly distinguished Australians. It is a matter of deep regret that these people, giving generously of their time and talents to administer the Institute, have by implication been impugned by the vicious assault made on the management of the Institute and the Executive Director by the Daily Telegraph. Reasonable questions and justified criticisms are the rightful prerogative of the free Press. However, I am sure that all fair-minded commentators would agree that the Daily Telegraph articles were blown out of all proportion. They must however be answered fully and promptly. I hope this statement and the accompanying report have fulfilled my commitment in this regard.

Since its inception in January 1981, the Institute of Sport has made a great contribution to the development of sport. The original proponent, Bob Ellicott, the board members-past and present-successive executive directors and dedicated Institute staff have all contributed greatly to these achievements. While fully recognising the importance of appropriate financial systems and controls, and ensuring that all necessary action is taken to that end, we are determined to avoid diversion of the Institute from its vital course by sensationalised comments on administrative matters.

I hope that the media take a responsible look at that report. There are two or three lines that could be blown up into serious articles, but if the media take a balanced look at that report and particularly the line I quoted earlier-which says that, given the size of the Institute and the responsibilities that it undertakes, the performance of the administration and finance sections has been admirable-they will give at least a balanced reporting. I thank the House for this opportunity to respond properly and fully in order to put the record straight. I present the following paper:
Administration of the Australian Institute of Sport-Ministerial Statement, 28 November 1985.
Motion (by Mr Holding) proposed:
That the House take note of the papers.
Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can assure the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) that the Press is taking note of that report as he wished. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the member for McPherson moving a motion of censure of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism because-
(1) he has misled the House in response to questions, and
(2) of his failure to exercise proper ministerial accountability.

We move this suspension because the Minister has misled this House. He has assured the House that all is well at the Australian Institute of Sport; yet the auditors reported in August and November 1985 that all was far from well. On 19 November the Minister said in this House: `I am not aware of any financial shortcomings either now or in the past'. Yet on 16 August this year and on 7 November, two reports were issued specifically in relation to internal audit matters. They concerned a number of matters-travel and subsistence, procedures relating to the hire of the National Sports Centre, cash handling procedures, the payment system and the operation of souvenir shops.

The Minister has failed to exercise proper control. He admitted in this House on 19 November that he is fully responsible for the Institute. The report tabled today indicates that the Executive Director of the Institute has spent money excessively on entertainment, furniture, travel, the misuse of the spot merit scheme and the employment of his own family. There has, in particular, been a serious injustice in the purchase of rowing boats. The lack of financial management was clearly documented in August, in November and again in the auditors' report today. However, through all this the Minister maintains that all is well.

The Minister is not a fool, but one has to ask: Is he blind; is he careless; does he not care for his own responsibilities; and why does he commend this careless approach by the Institute to the misuse of taxpayers' money? On top of all this, the Minister today made a statement which makes an absolute mockery of his ministerial responsibilities. all the allegations in the Daily Telegraph of some days ago which prompted an investigation have been in part or in whole substantiated-all of them. The allegations, the Minister said at the time and again today, were nothing but grubby journalism. If one picks up the report, one sees page after page after page where the Daily Telegraph allegations are substantiated. How he can come into this House with a whitewash statement and say there is nothing in it is certainly beyond us. He has ignored all the criticism and has used only some of the selective parts of that report. It is not good enough for any Minister. The Minister ignored his responsibilities to put things right at the Institute and he has has ignored his responsibilities to properly manage public funds. I add that $14m worth of public funds is allocated to the Institute this year.

We do not lightly seek to suspend Standing Orders and censure a Minister. If he had taken some note of our request some days ago for a full inquiry, this might have been avoided. Instead, he sought to cover it up with an auditors' report. This is no criticism of the auditors, but it is unfair to ask auditors to check on their own work. We have maintained that someone from outside the Institute and not the internal auditors should have been required to do that investigation. As it is, the auditors have not been able to complete their job and some of the matters raised in the allegations are still to be addressed. The auditors admit that in their report.

This is more than just a financial check, although that in itself is serious enough, because what we are talking about is the complete style and responsibility of the Minister and the management of the Institute of Sport. If there had been a full inquiry, the Minister would not be taking things so casually. It is now clear why he wanted to avoid that full inquiry. This report, which he seeks today to whitewash, in itself is damning enough. It is the Minister's attitude to this auditors' report that causes us to seek this censure. He seeks in his statement to dismiss these serious allegations. If he had addressed them seriously, again a censure motion might have been avoided. His attitude is in line with his lavish spending on his numerous overseas trips and his approval of excessive amounts of money to be spent in his own electorate on sports facilities. The Minister has not attended to his duties. I quote again from the auditors' report which has just been tabled:
There appears to be a lack of understanding of the budget process.
Latest financial reports indicate a potential budget shortfall of approximately $450,000 a situation that is clearly unacceptable.
There is no evidence of the existence of a corporate plan.
The staff budgeting system is poor.
Relations with some Government departments appear to be poor.
There is a considerable amount of dissatisfaction amongst staff and some are highly critical of the financial management of the Institute.
Is it any wonder that we seek to censure this Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member that he should be actually giving reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders, not for the censure.

—Mr Speaker, the Minister should be censured because I believe he knew that things were not right at the Institute. Why else would he have moved this year to change the status of the Institute to that of a statutory corporation? Why has he done this after only two years since he assumed responsibility for the Institute? He is moving to change the status of the Institute to give him more control and at the same time he says: `No, everything is fine'. He cannot have it both ways. We, therefore, Mr Speaker, have moved that Standing Orders be suspended so that we can initiate a censure motion against the Minister.
—Order! Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. This is a matter of very grave concern which involves the administration of the Australian Institute of Sport and the responsibi- lity of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown), to take adequate precautions with taxpayers' money which, as my colleague, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr White), has just told the House runs to some $14m in this financial year alone. I remind the House that on the 19th of this month questions were put to the Minister about what he described as little less than a scurrilous article in the Daily Telegraph. The Minister admitted firstly to my colleague the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) that, yes, he did accept full ministerial responsibility for the activities of the Australian Institute of Sport. Having said that, he then went on to stipulate that he had never received at any stage prior advice before he had read the articles in the Daily Telegraph as to whether there were any matters of concern relating to the internal and the financial administration of the Australian Institute of Sport.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite an extraordinary circumstance that one day before this matter was raised in the Parliament the Minister told us that in fact the full Cabinet had approved the establishment of this organisation as a statutory authority.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Young

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not mind giving the honourable member leave to move his censure motion. If he does, we will be able to deal with this matter directly.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative with an absolute majority.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SPORT, RECREATION AND TOURISM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism be censured by the House for:

(1) His misleading statements in the House on 19 November when he said, `I am not aware of any financial shortcomings at the Australian Institute of Sport. I have not been made aware of any in the past. The only accusations, imputations or rumours that I have detected at any stage are in that rather grubby little article in the Daily Telegraph this morning'.

(2) His failure to act on audit reports dated 16 August and 7 November 1985, the latter drawing attention to weaknesses in the following areas: Travel and subsistence, cash handling procedures and the payments system.
(3) His failure to exercise proper ministerial control of expenditure of taxpayers' money by officers of the Australian Institute of Sport.
(4) His failure to conduct a proper public inquiry into all aspects of the financial administration of the Australian Institute of Sport.
(5) Failure to adequately respond to the conclusion contained in the Auditor's report which said:
`Internal audit work carried out both prior to and during the current exercise causes us to be concerned as to the financial management and financial well-being generally of the Institute'.

Today the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) has engaged in a massive whitewash combined with a fair amount of media kicking. The Minister's statement is grossly inadequate and in attempting to get himself off the hook he has deliberately set out to mislead the Parliament. In today's statement, the Minister said:
As I suggested to Parliament last week, and I now reiterate, the Government and the Institute have nothing to fear from this report.

Today the Minister tried to come in here and whitewash a report that contains damning allegations. He says that the Government has nothing to fear. This merely reflects the gross irresponsibility of the Minister who, when presented with a report of this kind, has effectively decided to ignore it.
On 19 September in this House, the Minister declared his total confidence in the Institute. He said:
I am sure that the affairs of the Institute of Sport . . . have always been handled well . . .
He went further on 20 November, and said:
I am very confident that, when I come back with the report from the internal auditors, everything will be found to be in apple pie order.

The internal audit is quite devastating in its far-reaching criticisms. Today the Minister has attempted to suggest that the only valid criticism of the Institute is that its staff are `too enthusiastic in selling their product'. That is the only criticism he picks up out of the report. Apparently the abuse of financial management in the report does not rate very highly.

The principles of ministerial responsibility in these matters have been clearly laid down by the present Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and others. On 25 August, the Attorney-General said in this House:
Ministerial responsibility, I remind honourable members, does not concern the question of what one knew; it concerns the question of what one ought to have known.
The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) said on 7 September:
Ignorance is no excuse.

The Minister has continuously failed, despite the knowledge that all was not well at the Institute, to address himself to the problems of the Institute. It is in all our interests to make sure that the Institute is properly administered. The report of the auditors which was tabled today is a damning indictment of what is happening at the Institute. However, the Minister made a statement which seeks to ignore everything. There should be no reflection on the job done by the auditor, Price Waterhouse, which did what it could in a few days. The fact is that the auditor should never have been put in the position of having to audit, check and report on its own work. It is the auditor to the Institute. On two occasions the auditor has informed the Institute that all is not well but the Minister failed to act.

On 19 and 20 November 1985, a series of allegations were made in the Daily Telegraph. All of those allegations have been sustained. Let us look in some detail at the allegations and what in fact the auditor's report says, not what the Minister comes in here and tells us the auditor's report says. The report said that hospitality expenditure was not adequately documented and that there was excessive entertaining of staff. The Minister managed to forget to mention these matters. The auditor also made the ironic point that there were too many working lunches in restaurants.

TALK.START.PARA: —There won't be in future.

—No one is more qualified to talk about that subject than the Special Minister of State. The auditor said that there were too many working lunches in restaurants and that there was excessive entertainment of staff. The whole process is not adequately documented. None of these matters gets a mention by the Minister. The Minister comes in and says that the auditor's report says that everything is going well. What a nonsense! I think it is ironic that the auditor says that there are too many working lunches in restaurants at the time when the Government is trying to clamp down on that very thing. The Institute which is the direct responsibility of the Minister is accused by the auditor of spending too much public money, taxpayers' money, on working lunches in restaurants. No wonder the Minister is having trouble getting his proposal for tax deductibility for the Sports Aid Foundation through the Treasurer (Mr Keating).
—Do you think so?

—I would think so. We will look forward to its coming in here. The auditors said that money under the Minister's control is being wasted in restaurants. Let us turn to the entertainment during the Tax Summit. Another allegation is that $3,700 was spent on a party by the Institute to entertain some people who were attending the Tax Summit. This is all in the report; it is just that the Minister chose not to mention it. An amount of $3,700 of taxpayers' money was spent by the Institute of Sport entertaining I do not know who-it does not matter.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not the best of the matter. That was not an initiative of the Institute of Sport. Guess who directed that the money be spent? It was none other than the Minister. That is clearly documented in the auditors' report. Yet the Minister comes into the House and chooses to ignore the matter. It is no wonder that he has a reputation as a big spender when he can say, with a flick of the finger, to the Institute: `Yes, blow $4,000 on a party for the Tax Summit'. The Tax Summit was called for the purpose of trying to get some sense into the tax system in this country and to reduce the burden of taxation on Australian taxpayers. Yet the Minister blows $3,700 on some party at the Institute. This action is certainly in line with his big-spending trips.

Let us turn to the travel to Melbourne by the Executive Director, the Sports Co-ordinator and the Marketing Manager of the Institute. The Executive Director, in a travel requisition, according to the auditors, said that he went to Melbourne-again, this was not mentioned by the Minister-to address the Sportsman Club and the Carbine Club. It is known for a fact, and I understand that the Executive Director has since admitted it, that he did not speak to the Carbine Club. As far as I know, he did not have an invitation to speak to the Carbine Club. Yet he put in a travel requisition saying that he had to go to Melbourne to speak to the Carbine Club. The auditors' report states that they are not prepared to comment on whether the travel was necessary. I am more than prepared to comment that the travel was certainly not necessary and that there was a deliberate falsification of travel documents.

Let us turn to the reduction of coaching bud- gets so that more money could be given to the Illawarra Institute of Sport. In the end no money was given but, again, the report makes it clear that it was intended to take money from the coaching budgets and to give it to that Institute. We did not get that from the Minister when he talked about the report. I now turn to the furniture for the office of the Executive Director. The Executive Director-again this is contained in the auditors' report tabled today-bought himself a chair and a table. For the table he paid not $1,000, $2,000, $3,000, $4,000, $5,000 or $6,000 but $7,000. He paid $1,000 for a chair and he outfitted his office for $19,000 on top of that. I fail to understand why sheer jealousy would not make the Minister take his Executive Director to task.

It is typical of the Department that more and more money is being spent on salaries and equipment and less and less on the delivery of facilities to sport. I do not know how the Minister can approve or support that sort of expenditure when people in this House do not have enough rooms or offices to put their secretaries in. When I first came to the Parliament I had to take the door off a cupboard to put a chair in so that my secretary could come in. Yet the Executive Director of the Institute of Sport can spend over $20,000 of public money on his own office.

I now turn to the question of higher duties allowances. The Institute spent $14m of public money. It does not accept the Public Service guidelines on higher duties allowances; the Executive Director changes the system. We have to ask why the Public Service guidelines are not good enough. The report tabled today says that the system should be changed; the Institute should adopt an acceptable system that abides by the rules.

We did not hear anything of that from the Minister when he came into the House to make a statement on the audit. The list of things that are clearly documented, but which failed to get a mention by the Minister, goes on and on. The spot merit scheme was set up to recognise special achievements by the Institute's employees. What did the Executive Director do? Firstly, he gave $1,500 of public money to the wife of one of the employees to go to Japan. That was not enough so he gave her another $1,300 so that she would not be out of pocket. We are not talking about one of the employees being rewarded for an achievement; we are talking about a wife being sent to Japan. Yet the maximum amount of money that should be taken out of the spot merit scheme is $1,000. The report stated that the scheme is decisive. It should be abandoned and it is a damning condemnation of the management.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister tell us this?

—Of course not. He brought in the goodies. I now turn to the employment of the Executive Director's family. It is not illegal, of course, to employ members of his family at the Institute but we have to ask why, in one newspaper interview, he said that only one member of his family had been employed when he now says that two members were employed at some time. Were the positions advertised and were the beneficiaries qualified? It is up to the Executive Director to use his judgment and I believe that his judgment has been in error. He was the man who had to approve payments to members of his own family. The report stated that it is not appropriate that they be employed. I heartily agree with that.

SPEECH.PARA: I come, finally, to what is probably one of the most serious allegations. Unfortunately, it was not addressed by the investigation, through lack of time. I refer to the purchase of rowing boats by the Institute. A statement was never made that tenders were required to be called. Honourable members opposite should listen and make a judgment as to whether this sort of financial management is fair. I would have thought that it was in the interests of the Minister, the Institute and everyone in the sporting world to make sure that the rowing boats were seen to be purchased on a fair and equitable basis. I think all honourable members would agree. Only two companies were involved. One was given every assistance by some members of the Institute. The other one heard about it by accident when there is fair evidence to indicate that the tenders, so called, had already been closed and only one had been consulted. So Sargent and Burton, the other company that had been ignored, went to Canberra to see Dr Cheffers and pleaded with him to be allowed to tender. Eventually it was allowed to tender, although when it went to get the documents it was told by an official of the Institute that the order had already been placed with the other company. It was allowed to tender eventually, the tender was considered, and Sargent and Burton were written to, to say that its tender was not up to scratch because the boats were experimental. The boats have been in use since 1978; they have won numerous world championships. Yet the Institute wrote back to the firm, having denied it the opportunity to tender, and said `your boats are experimental', even though they had been in use for eight years.

The Executive Director had the grace to admit that he had been wrong, but no attempt was made to redress that wrong. It is important, even if tenders do not have to be called for by regulation, that justice is seen to be done. I hope that Government members who are defending their Minister will at least have the grace to admit that when public moneys are involved justice must be seen to be done. That is a serious allegation that has not been answered by this report. What is more, I quote finally what the report says-again this has been ignored by the Minister-about that particular episode:
Clumsy attempts to set the record straight by having Sykes produce a second quotation letter at a different price were in the circumstances totally unnecessary.
My time has run out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to second the motion of censure against the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). We have brought this motion forward in the House this evening because one of the basic principles upon which this parliamentary system is meant to operate is that Ministers must always tell the truth to the House. If we are to assume that the Minister who is currently subject to this censure motion has told the full truth, as no doubt he will claim he has, the only other reasonable conclusion we can draw is that he is incompetent. If he is incompetent, surely he is unfit to carry out the ministerial responsibilities which have been placed upon him by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: We are aware of the fact that this Government is well known for its incompetence in so many areas. We have been told, for example, by the Minister in this particular situation that there is no act of impropriety. We have seen other examples in recent months involving the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) and his act of impropriety in both the Combe affair and various other matters related to his activities. I will now go to the substance of this matter. The essence of the censure motion is that the Minister has misled the House by the statements he made here on 19 November and on subsequent dates, when he said:

I am not aware of any financial shortcoming at the Australian Institute of Sport. I have not been made aware of any in the past. The only accusations, imputations or rumours that I have detected at any stage are in that rather grubby little article in the Daily Telegraph this morning.

In addition, he has failed to act on audit reports dated as early as 16 August and 7 November this year. It is worth noting for the benefit of the House that the latter report on 7 November drew attention to a number of weaknesses in the following areas of the Australian Institute of Sport-travel and subsistence, cash handling procedures and the payments system. In addition to that, the Minister has failed to exercise proper ministerial control of expenditure of taxpayers' money by the officers of the Australian Institute of Sport. As has already been mentioned in this debate, some $14m this year alone is the budget of that organisation.

The Minister has accused the Opposition of being disloyal and unsportsmanlike when we seek to bring back to the Minister's attention his primary responsibility, which is to look after the public funds of Australian taxpayers. How is the Minister able to stand up and explain this matter to the people and this House on this occasion when two internal audit reports have been brought forward in recent months on the activities of this Institute? In addition to that, the Minister has had evidence from one of the companies that put forward proposals to build boats for the Institute. The Minister ignored that correspondence. He came into the House and told honourable members that he knew nothing about these matters. How otherwise can we conclude that the Minister has failed to conduct a proper public inquiry into all aspects of financial administration in the Australian Institute of Sport?

Let us examine exactly what the Minister did. Under criticism he decided, very much on the spur of the moment as a result of questions on the 19th of this month, that he would get the internal auditors to do yet another inquiry. But when one reads the report of the internal auditors, which is very different from what the Minister has claimed in his statement in this House, one very important point comes out. Firstly, the auditors say they had only a week to do the job. Clearly, therefore there are limitations on the product which has been tabled here tonight. Secondly-and this is the most important thing of all-it was also said that a subsequent report would be made. Those words did not appear in the Minister's statement. He has told this Parliament and the Australian people that somehow or other this initial report is the beginning and end of the matter. I assure the Minister that that is not so.

The Opposition will not allow the Minister to get away with this sort of thing. We demand nothing less than a much higher level of accountability, a level of accountability which the Minister accepted when he became one. The Minister admitted on 19 November that he as Minister would accept responsibility for the activities of the Australian Institute of Sport. Was there any doubt therefore that the Opposition should ask the Minister on that occasion to conduct a full and proper public inquiry into all aspects of the financial adminstration of this Institute, and the Minister refused to do so. I emphasise a point which again the Minister has ignored, or perhaps it is another example, like the Prime Minister with the ABA, of selective amnesia. These are the words of the Minister's internal auditors who gave him the report, which was tabled in this House tonight. I quote:
Internal audit work carried out both prior to and during the current exercise causes us to be concerned as to the financial management and financial well-being generally-
not in the particular but generally-
of the Institute.
They are damning words, and we wait to see how the Minister will explain it. The Minister has misled the House. On 19 November he said:
I am very confident that, when I come back with the report from the internal auditors, everything will be found to be-
and I use those delicate words-
in apple-pie order.

I think the Minister will find that his apple pie is laced with arsenic, because he will have to live with and eat the words he has spoken in this House. How can this Minister make such an assertion when, clearly, if he had an ounce of ministerial responsibility he would have known and obtained knowledge about those auditors' reports of February and November this year which showed so clearly inadequate procedures in storeroom control, a lack of adherence to basic control mechanisms, weaknesses in travel and subsistence, hiring procedures, cash handling and overall payments?

Yet we are told even before they carried out this third report-I emphasise that it was the third report-that everything was in `apple-pie order'. The Minister's continual assertion is that the Daily Telegraph's allegations were nothing more than a `a mere beat-up', and I quote those words. He went on to say: `I am not aware of any financial shortcomings'. Clearly, as I have said, he should have been aware of these financial shortcomings. If he was not, it demonstrates what we in the Opposition have suspected for the last three years of the Minister's period in office-that he has skated over most of his administrative duties. The Minister likes a good headline, he likes everybody to love him, but what he does not like-and he likes good holidays-is to do his job. That is what he is here for. He is not here to come into this place and say: `I have received an award for ``my sportsmanship'' '. My sportsmanship! He admitted that he had to give the award to the Institute and of course the Institute should have had it. He likes going round the world getting awards. How about his staying here and doing some work?
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting, I was emphasising for the benefit of the House the reasons why the Opposition has moved this censure motion on the Minister responsible for the Australian Institute of Sport. It was based on two basic principles. Firstly, it is the responsibility of Ministers to administer authorities within their responsibility, in a competent and far-sighted manner; secondly, at all times they must tell the full truth to the Parliament. I concluded by making the observation that as the Minister had not told the full truth to the Parliament, we can only deduce that he has simply failed in his duties and therefore should not be a Minister. As everybody knows he harbours the ambition of one day being Minister for Defence, one can only say that if he cannot administer $14m he would be hard pressed to administer billions of dollars which would be the case if he administered the Department of Defence.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, the unfortunate fact is that people tend to follow the example set for them by their leaders. The Minister has, over the years, set some excellent examples of extravagance. For example, he is the third most expensively travelled Minister of any portfolio in the present Government and that includes both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). He is even reputed to have spent some $900 on a briefcase for his private secretary. Again this was all taxpayers' money. No wonder senior staff at the Institute of Sport have decided to follow the redoubtable leader who has set such a splendid example of munificence and extravagance in using taxpayers' money. I go back to the point made by the Minister and why he misled the House on 19 November when he said:
I am very confident that, when I come back with the report from the internal auditors, everything will befound to be in apple pie order.

As I said before dinner, this was not the first report; it was the third report that had been brought forward in recent months. This Minister denied to the House that he knew anything about the other two reports. As I have said, we can only conclude from that, that even if his denial is accurate it demonstrates gross incompetence for which this House has no other course but to hold him responsible.

Going on from that, I conclude he should have known about the reports-that is, the reports of February and November-which showed inadequate procedures in storeroom control accounting, lack of adherence to basic control mechanisms, weaknesses in travel and subsistence arrangements, hiring procedures, cash handling, payments and so forth. Yet the Minister saw all of this as nothing more than a `beat-up' by the Sydney Daily Telegraph.

Let us take the detailed claims of the Minister and see how they can be effectively disproved. He claimed that the Institute's finances were in `apple pie order'. Clearly, from the conclusion which is in the audit report, that cannot be the interpretation of any reasonable person. I repeat the quotation for the second time:
Internal audit work carried out both prior to and during the current exercise causes us to be concerned as to the financial management and financial well-being generally of the Institute.

That is the final observation in this report and it is only an interim report; it is not the final report by any means. The Minister went on to suggest that Dr Cheffers, the Chairman, and members of the executive authority are all splendid people. The Opposition does not doubt that but one has to say in all honesty that whether one can use the words `complete confidence', as the Minister has, is something about which the Australian electorate and this Parliament must make their own judgment. Again it is quite clear from the internal audit report that the auditor does not have complete confidence in the manner in which the administration has been carried out; the Administrative Appeals Tribunal did not clear up the issue of tendering. It merely claimed that all available documents at the time had been released under the Freedom of Information Act. Again we have to gather from the comments made by the Minister in this House at Question Time on the 19th of this month that he did not know about the FOI requests for information. If he did not know about them he should have. That is something I have no doubt the Minister will be telling us more about later.

In addition the Auditor-General's Office has informed me that on a number of occasions it would have liked to have conducted an efficiency audit on the affairs of the Australian Institute of Sport.
