However, an efficiency audit under the Audit Act can be carried out only with the specific approval of the Minister. In other words he has to give signed approval for an efficiency audit to be carried out. The Minister has failed to do that. In other words he has not appropriately utilised his responsibilities to ensure that areas under his jurisdiction are subject to the most rigorous investigations. Instead, he hides behind the argument that this is not a statutory authority; it is a private company. It is all the Opposition's and Mr Ellicott's fault because it happened during the previous Administration. We do not deny that.

However, let us look at the facts. For three years the Minister has been in this portfolio. He did nothing about the matter until the day before this issue became public. I find it difficult to believe that he could go to Cabinet to get clearance for a statutory authority one day before a major public scandal is released in the newspapers concerning the incompetence and inefficiency of this administration and the Minister's incompetence as the responsible Minister. In addition, previous inquiries by Price Waterhouse, the internal auditors, have been only on specific matters. Price Waterhouse has never conducted a general internal audit. That is contained in the analysis which has been tabled by the Minister tonight.

I turn to the details mentioned by my colleague earlier about increased Institute spending on hospitality. The auditor said that there was excessive entertaining of staff and they were not convinced as to the need for working lunches in restaurants. In terms of travel to Melbourne and Sydney for grand finals the auditors said:
We do not believe it is appropriate for us to comment on whether the travel was necessary.

They said it was up to the Board to make a decision. It is certainly up to the Minister to have the courage to give us the facts about the situation. Regarding the purchase of expensive office equipment the auditor said that the `same effect could have been achieved at less expense'. The auditor called for re-examination of the possibility of abandoning altogether higher duties allowances in relation to existing Public Service regulations. The auditor seriously suggested that spot merit funding and the travel of the General Manager's wife were potentially divisive. There was some doubt as to why the lady had travelled in the first place and she exceeded the limit by $1,500. Yet this was designed as recognition of special and meritorious achievements by an Institute employee. Since when was the employee's wife a member of the staff of the Institute?

I can continue. There are cases of the director employing his family-both the son and daughter. While it is true that there are no regulations specifically stating that that cannot be done, one has to say-this comes out in the report-that the judgment of the senior officer of the Institute is subject to considerable doubt. But we were told in the House on 19 November and on later occasions by the Minister: `Everything is in apple pie order; don't worry. I have the fullest confidence in these people. They can do what they like, just like me. I travel the world spending taxpayers' money. I expect nothing less from them'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHN BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to answer this censure motion more in pity than in anger. I think that it is a well-known custom--
—Don't patronise the Speaker.
—I heard you in silence, you oaf. Could you give me the honour?
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson and the honourable member for Bradfield were given the courtesy of being heard in silence. The Minister deserves the same silence.
—I take a point of order. It is just not acceptable for Ministers to use a word such as `oaf'.
—If the honourable member finds the word offensive, I ask the Minister to withdraw it.

—I withdraw. As I said earlier, before I was so rudely interrupted, I answer this censure motion more in sorrow than in anger. The dictates of this House and the customs of the parliamentary system are that a censure motion is moved in the gravest of circumstances and is usually moved by a leader-not usually by the newly arrived No. 27 in the batting order.
—Hang on! I resent that.

—Out of respect for the honourable member I withdraw that and substitute No. 28 in the batting order. The motion is seconded by Smiles Cunningly, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I am well--
—I take a point of order. I take exception to the use of so-called nicknames of that nature.
—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield finds the term offensive. I suggest that the Minister withdraw.

—I withdraw. This censure motion is so ludicrous as to be almost laughable. However, out of respect for this institution, I will answer it. I am as conscious as any member of this House of the requirement of all members of this House to tell the truth, especially Ministers. The first item in the censure motion suggests that I misled the House when I said that I was not aware of any financial shortcomings at the Australian Institute of Sport, et cetera. This charge is based on the fact that the Opposition has two stolen documents. I emphasise the word `stolen'. They are internal audit documents dated 16 August 1985 and 7 November 1985.
—So we should not know what is going on.
—Do not talk to me about knowing what is going on in business. The right honourable member should not tell me that, in view of his record.

—Order! I warn the Leader of the National Party. I have already reminded honourable members that the previous two speakers were heard and given a fair go. I think that the Minister should be allowed that courtesy.
—They were not being abusive.
—I do not like answering back from the honourable member for Mackellar. I call the Minister.
—The two documents on which this statement about misleading the House is based are stolen documents.
—I take a point of order. The docu- ments to which the Minister refers were referred to in the audit report which was tabled by the Minister this afternoon in making his statement.
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—Of course the documents are referred to in the report; they exist. But they should not exist in the hands of the Opposition. Given the lack of honesty, a quality which is not inordinately displayed by these characters, I am not surprised to find that they have them. They are two working documents.
—I take a point of order. The Minister has impugned the honesty of all members of the Opposition. Unless the Minister can prove that we have those documents, I ask him to withdraw his remark.
—Order! There is no point of order. The honourable member for Richmond will resume his seat.

—The two documents are internal working documents addressed by the internal auditor, Price Waterhouse, the accounting firm which the honourable member also seemed to impugn, to the Executive Director of the Australian Institute of Sport on one hand and Mr Paul Brettell, the General Manager of the Australian Institute of Sport, on the other. Can the honourable member please explain to me how he got them, if he did not steal them or someone else did not steal them? I did not mislead the House. When I said that I knew of no financial shortcomings at the Australian Institute of Sport, I was doing what I normally do-that is, telling the absolute truth. I had not seen these documents. Why should I have seen them? The honourable member for Bradfield, the former Chairman of the august Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, should know what internal documents of an auditor are; they are the ordinary documents that come by rote from the auditor to the General Manager of the Institute pointing out some shortcomings in the auditing system. They come quite regularly to every department, every company and every statutory authority that exists in Australia. I see nothing sinister about the fact that the Institute had them and did not show them to me. Why should it? It shows them to the Board, not to me. If the honourable member knew anything about the company structure that I inherited, he would know that the Institute of Sport responds to the Board, which responds to me. So by impugning my honesty the honourable member is also impugning the honesty of a very distinguished bunch of Australians. There is no point in the honourable member for Bradfield seeking to dismiss that charge and saying: `We didn't really mean to insult them; we were just doing our duty'. He would not know what duty was.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite are a leaderless, talentless and inefficient bunch, searching around on the second last sitting day of this Parliament to find some dirt to put on this Government. What a puny excuse for a censure motion, coming in here to tell me that the Institute of Sport manager has spent $7,000 on a desk. He did spend too much money on the desk and he has been censured. The big $7,000 desk scandal! How does that line up with the scandals which members of the former Government managed to achieve in their term in government? If we had moved a censure motion on all of their scandals we would have done nothing else. Their ministerial improprieties were: Garland, allegations of bribery; Fraser in 1978; Withers in 1978; Sinclair in 1978-79; Newman in 1979; Webster in 1979; Newman in 1979; Sinclair in 1980; Staley in 1980; Sinclair in 1980-81; Nixon in 1981; Moore, MacKellar, Durack and Howard. Do honourable members opposite want to hear any more? They were absolute scandals involving the personal honesty of Ministers and members and involving their shortcomings as Ministers. They involved scandals of hundreds of millions of dollars. Yet the Opposition comes in here and moves a censure motion on me because the Executive Director of the Institute of Sport bought a $7,000 desk. It is a great big scandal!

Into the bargain, I have a list of the 22 resignations and sackings that occurred in the 6 1/2 years of the Fraser Government. It is a wonderful record of honesty! Members of the Opposition have the hide to come in here on the second last day of this parliamentary sitting and impugn my honesty, impugn the honesty of members of the Board and try to censure this Government on this puny set of allegations that have been refuted by the most credible accounting firm in the world-Price Waterhouse. If honourable members opposite had read the report-if they had half a brain they could read it-they would have seen that every allegation was refuted.

There are certain weaknesses in the company structure that I inherited when I inherited the Institute of Sport. I have been at pains through this shabby little affair not to impugn the Hon. Bob Ellicott and I now refuse to do so. Bob Ellicott set up this organisation with a company structure because he had no other choice. He knows now, as well as I know, that the company structure is not suitable. Early in this year I moved to have this company changed to a stat- utory authority basis. For the honourable member for Bradfield to come in here and suggest that I went to Cabinet the day before these allegations were made and got the Cabinet to agree to a statutory authority basis is an absolute lie. The negotiations about this have been going on since early in the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order-
—Order! The Minister knows that the expression he has used is unparliamentary. I ask him to withdraw.
—I withdraw. It was misleading.
—Mr Speaker, I find that equally offensive. He told this House that he went to the Cabinet the day before, which was Monday, the 18th.
—Order! The suggestion that matters have been misleading are scarcely unparliamentary.

—Let me get to a couple of the specific charges that have been made. Most of them I will forget. There was a claim that Dr Cheffers went to Melbourne excessively and went to the Aussie rules football grand final. The honourable member for Bradfield also made a very strong imputation that he had misled the auditors because he did not go to the Carbine Club, he had never intended to go there and that he had filled in a false document. I have in my hand his invitation to the Carbine Club. It is very interesting. It begins: `Our patron, Sir Brian Murray'. One of the other honourable guests who would be present was the Hon. Jeff Kennett. He subjected himself to the indignity of putting up with Kennett in order to go to the club. But he did go there. I can rest assured, knowing the enthusiasm-
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I said he was going to address the Carbine Club.
—Order! That is not a point of order.
—So that was dismissed-

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I regret to take up the time of the House, but the Minister did say that I referred to the Carbine Club. If he checks my greens he will see that I did not do so.
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—Let us forget the Carbine Club. That is obviously a sore point with the Opposition. Let us turn to the rowing boats. The AIS is a private company. It does not call tenders. It wanted to buy boats for the rowing team that were compatible with the boats that it had inherited from the Australian Rowing Council when we took rowing into the Institute. The boats were made by Sykes. They happened to be the best boats in Australia. Despite the bleatings of the Opposition about how successful the other boats were in world competition, the other boats have not won a medal-and I will not name the manufacturer-since the Olympic Games of 1968. It has been a fair while in the wilderness. Meanwhile, the boats that we bought from Sykes won a silver medal and a gold medal at the recently completed world rowing championship. In regard to the other boats, two of them competed at the world championship and came eighth and ninth. I think our decision was correct.

SPEECH.PARA: The offer was made by Sykes at a certain price and the boats were accepted. The AIS, as is normal company practice-I am sure the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) will suggest that this is the case-said: `Good, we have decided to buy your boats. They are the best and most suitable. Can you do something better with the price'. He reduced the price by $3,000. What a terrible thing the AIS did with public funds! It got the best boats available at the cheapest possible price. I would have thought that that was something to be applauded.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was an unfair tender.

—It was not an unfair tender. That charge was made by Sargent and Burton. All the documents sought under the freedom of information legislation were granted to it. It did not believe that anybody could be honest. It then went to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and had its appeal thrown out. The offer was fair. The Opposition knows that it was fair. The decision was made by the rowing coaches, the Chairman of the Australian Rowing Council and two members of the Board. If honourable members opposite say it is not fair, they are impugning many good, decent people, which is pretty well their form.

SPEECH.PARA: The rest of the charges are hardly worth answering. Let me say this: The Opposition-talentless, leaderless, without any policies, without any shred of respect in the Australian community-has been dredging around, trying to find some dirt. It even encouraged Warden in the gallery this week to write this little article entitled `Opposition gropes around for dirt'. Let us look at how much it found. It found that the Institute of Sport may have bought a desk that was too expensive. That is the only charge that has not been answered.The article reads:

The strain of trying to find something, anything with which to stain the Government sometimes shows in the Opposition's more frantic attempts at scandal-detection and in recent days it has fallen to poor Mr White . . . to pursue what looks like a particularly elusive wild goose around the chamber.

It has fallen to Mr White to do his personal best to get the Minister for Sport Recreation and Tourism . . . to admit that there have been extravagant spendings at the Australian Institute of Sport on junkets, jewel-encrusted javelins, swimming pools filled with asses milk, mink-covered tennis balls . . .

I tell honourable members that they do not exist, any more than these alleged scandals exist. I totally reject any notion that I misled this House. I have never misled this House; I never will. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Mr White's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of Standing Orders, there was before the House the motion: `That the House take note of the papers'. The question is:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had a debate in which the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) had the opportunity to explain to the House exactly what his reasons were for not telling the full story as to why he has failed in Question Time in this House and on other occasions to explain to the House the full background to the extraordinary events concerning the financial affairs of the Australian Institute of Sport. It is a matter of great regret that although he had 20 minutes today to explain himself in the motion of censure before the House, he demonstrated a total inability or unwillingness to do so. One can only conclude from this that the Minister is guilty of the charges which we brought against him. Those charges, put quite succinctly, involved the fact that he did not tell the full truth to Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Young) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled: The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that ``States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to suppress all forms of traffic in women and exploitation of prostitution of women''.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.

Your petitioners therefore pray: That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Chynoweth,Mr Halverson and Mr McArthur.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Private Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sayeth:
That we the undersigned are totally opposed to any taxation change which involves a tax on Health Fund contributions, health charges or benefits;

That we are already required to pay a 1 percent levy to partly finance the Medicare scheme and that we would regard any further taxation of our health insurance arrangements as unfair and unreasonable;
That therefore we urge the Government to ensure that there is no taxation on illness and no special taxation on those who seek to insure themselves against the cost of private health care.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Dobie,Mr Ruddock and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: Military Bases in Australia and Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of citizens of Australia respectfully show:

As a part of the world wide campaign by women in the final year of the United Nations' Decade for Women for `Equality, Development and Peace' (1976-1985) and in view of the grave possibility of nuclear catastrophe, the Union Australian Women calls on the Australian Government to:
intensify its efforts for nuclear disarmament.
remove U.S. bases from Australian soil.
keep the Pacific and Indian Oceans nuclear free.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chynoweth,Mr Kent,Ms McHugh and Mr Allan Morris.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker,Mr McArthur,Mr Reith and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That the overwhelming majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian National Flag.

2. That we are totally opposed to any change in the Australian National Flag as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, unless such proposed change is first voted on by the people of Australia and passed by a majority of voters in a majority of States.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. THAT we are completely dissatisfied with the frequent and substantial increase in the price of petrol and diesel fuel.
2. THAT we are aware that these price increases have an adverse affect on the living standards of the average Australian wage earner.
3. THAT increases in fuel prices adds to farm costs and further reduces the average income per farmer which has already fallen to one-third of national earnings.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government will immediately reduce the price of petrol by three (3) cents per litre in line with the commitment given by the now Prime Minister of Australia during the 1983 election campaign and take all possible action to prevent further increases occurring.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew and Mr Fife.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. That we are completely dissatisfied with the pricing of petrol in this country;
2. That under a Labor Government petrol prices have continued to rise excessively, with recent Government decisions adding over 8c per litre to the price of petrol in some country areas;
3. The proposed consumption tax could lead to a further rise of 6c per litre; and
4. The high cost of petrol discriminates against country residents who rely on their cars for essential communication and transport.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government honour the commitment given by the Prime Minister during the 1983 election campaign to reduce petrol prices by 3c per litre.
Further we strongly urge the Government to adopt a petrol pricing policy which does not cause unnecessary rises in the cost of petrol. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will give speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that they are opposed to the proposals contained in the Government's White Paper for the reform of the Australian Tax System in so far as they relate to the imposition of further capital gains and wealth taxes.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government to reject any proposal to increase the burden of capital gains and wealth taxes on the Australian people.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia, repsectfully showeth:

That the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 will endanger the Federal system in Australia, the State and Federal criminal justice systems, the State and Federal Police Force, the State and Federal education systems, the independance of the churches and religious associations, marriage and the family, children, the unborn and handicapped, the aged and the infirm, employer and employee relationships and Australian society generally.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That your Honourable House defer debate on the Bill for twelve months and circulate the Bill for twelve months for the widest possible debate, scrutiny and discussion, and your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Business
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, including farms, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small enterprises finally sell these assets are not ``windfall gains'', but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business or farm by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into business or farm to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses and farms often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell these assets to sustain them in retirement;

Your Petitioners request that the House of Representative in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes. And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of State Arts Councils
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the current policies of the Community Arts Board of the Australia Council are disadvantaging rural residents with regard to access to the Arts.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Federal Government will allocate sufficient funds to the Australia Council specifically to ensure ongoing funding to State Arts Councils to enable those organisations to maintain access to performing and other arts activities in country areas, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitious and unfair Assets Test. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Anthem
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of certain citizens of Australia show that reference to God should be made in the National Anthem as Australia is considered to be a Christian nation and therefore we believe inclusion of His name is appropriate and desirable.
The suggested request being to alter the last line in each verse to ``In joyful strains then we all sing God bless Australia fair''.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, and the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we being persons connected with and employed in the building industry within Australia deplore the attempts to enforce compulsory unionisation within the architectural profession and in particular do oppose all attempts at compulsory unionisation, particularly by the Association of Draughting, Supervisory and Technical Employees and base such opposition on the conflict with the essence of a professional standing, a conflict with the Architects Acts and a conflict with basic Common Law interests, particularly in respect of the Architect being independent in supporting the interests of his client, and further that if an Architect is directly involved with a Building Industry Union that this would be a conflict of interest in the role of the Architect as a Quasi-Arbitrator between Proprietor and Builder.

Any such proposal to require compulsory unionisation of Architects discriminates against and inhibits progress within the profession and the building industry and curtails employment throughout the Nation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled and the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled reject proposals for compulsory unionisation within the architectural profession and support the profession and the building industry in its independence and standing for the promotion of independent and high standards within the profession and the building industry.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows-

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Enterprise Migrant Hostel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

We are concerned that the closure of the Enterprise Migrant Hostel will be detrimental to the long-term settlement prospects of migrants in Victoria as well as detrimental to Ethnic Communities who have settled in the Springvale area. In addition, the long-term development of commerce and industry in the area will be adversely affected.
We urge the Government to reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Entertainment Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That whereas the Government has abolished the one hundred per cent tax deductability status previously applicable in respect of cost incurred by businesses in entertainment expenses, the actions of the Government in this regard will have significant and negative impact on business and employment in the restaurant industry.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will not proceed with the taxation measures announced on 19 September 1985 affecting the tax deductability status of these entertainment expenses.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraph, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established which will work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all, fulfilling employment, a sustainable society conserving natural resources and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover. By achieving these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world to follow.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will:
1. Create an Australian Ministry For Peace specifically devoted to peace-building and the non-voilent resolution of conflict;
2. Convene a national Summit for Survival to discuss the issues of world disarmament, security and national and international co-operation;
3. Support the United Nations World Disarmament Campaign by allocating the equivalent of at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund peace activities;
4. Actively assist the International Year of Peace in 1986 by initiating programs for peace education, self help development and environmental repair;
5. Develop National Employment Programs to give priority to the planting and growing of forests, food-producing trees and other crops to assist the greening of Australia;

6. Implement National Recycling Programs to reuse water and to compost all presently wasted domestic sewage-sludge and organic garbage with mineral rich gravel dust, a by-product from rock quarries and mines, into hygienic humus, a natural fertiliser, for use in revitalising improverished soils.
7. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Year for Repairing the Earth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That, for our survival, an effective Worldpeace Initiative needs to be established to work towards mutual understanding, world disarmament, economic well-being for all and full employment. This Initiative will help to ensure a sustainable society conserving natural resources, and revitalising soils essential for growing a plentiful and healthy food supply and tree cover for the needs of present and future generations. By working for these objectives, Australia can set an example for the rest of the world.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will:
1. Propose to the United Nations General Assembly that 1989 be declared International Year for Repairing the Earth.
2. Implement action programs leading up to 1989 which will include:
(a) Actively supporting the International Year of Peace in 1986 by reallocating at least 10% of our military expenditure to fund environmental repair programs.

(b) Implementing National Recycling Programs to reuse water, and to compost into hygienic humus all presently wasted organic garbage and sewage-sludge mixed with fine ground powder from mineral-rich gravels and rocks, to use as a natural fertiliser in revitalising impoverished soils.

(c) Developing National Employment Programs giving priority to the planting and growing of healthy forests, food-producing trees and other crops and vegetation including environmentally sound use and reuse of water to assist the greening of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Sutherland Shire respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your Petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia showeth that:
Your petitioners pray that Your Honourable House will reject the proposed Australian Bill of Rights Bill 1985 for the following reasons:

1. We believe as a matter of faith and judgment that the proposed legislation is anti-God and its implementation will result in attacks on the Christian church and the promotion of a State religion based on secular humanism;
2. That there is no need for legislation of this kind since the principles of freedom are already enshrined in Common Law and that it will cause more problems than it seeks to solve.

3. That there is a potential threat to our national security through making treaties of this kind with foreign nations, many of which do not share a common heritage and do not practice many of the principles that they have covenanted to uphold;

4. The methods being used to introduce this legislation are secretive and a blatant misuse of the external affairs powers under Section 51 of the Australian Constitution and that furthermore are contrary to the spirit of the Constitution;

5. That the implementation of the legislation through a process of new educational initiatives will result in the centralised control of education and this will inevitably lead to the destruction of States' rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Downer,Mr Steele Hall,Mr Porter and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has announced its intention to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, currently the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government has no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in this manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but is handing over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australians citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to prevent this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Paramedical Day Care Centre for the Aged
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of certain Citizens of Australia, residents of the Electorate of Isaacs and adjacent areas respectfully draweth to the attention of the House that:
There is no day centre facility offering paramedical services to the aged in the area despite the demonstrated need for such services.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Australian Government provide funding as soon as practicable to establish such a centre within the area.

INTERJECT.PARA: The impact on Australia's future prosperity of the Government's taxes, charges and high interest rate policies.

More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
That Government Business be called on.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise I present the report of the Committee incorporating a dissenting report, together with copies of minutes of proceedings and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Order that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report, which has just been tabled, is the result of three years work by the Standing Committees on Environment and Conservation of the Thirty-second and Thirty-third Parliaments and the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise which was appointed in this Parliament. The elections of 1983 and 1984 and the resulting changes in membership of the committees seriously hampered the inquiry's progress. Notwithstanding these frustrations, I believe the Select Committee on Aircraft Noise has produced a well reasoned and considered report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee visited all major capital city airports, some of the larger secondary and light aircraft airports and three Royal Australian Air Force bases in the course of the inquiry. Because of the constraints and cost factors, it was not possible to visit and take evidence at all airports in Australia which suffer noise or noise related problems. However, I consider that as a broad cross section of aviation facilities was inspected and information was supplied by a large variety of sources, sufficient information has been obtained to formulate meaningful recommendations.

While a minority report is included on two matters, the Committee was able to reach unanimous agreement on most issues. People who regard the only solution to the noise problem as relocating all airports away from residential areas will be disappointed with our report. Of course, there is one possible solution but Commonwealth funds are limited. It would have been naive of the Committee to expect the Government to accept recommendations which would result in the expenditure of many billions of dollars when other priorities such as health, housing and schooling need to be taken into account in allocating limited resources. In my view, however, if the recommendations are implemented they will effectively resolve many of the problems, or, at the very least, ensure that problems related to aircraft operations do not worsen. I also believe that the recommendations will ensure that airports operate as far as possible in a manner compatible with the surrounding communities.

I now turn to some of the major issues in the report. Technological advances in engine design since the introduction of the first jets in Australia have resulted in significant reductions in aircraft noise. As the noisier jets are replaced by quieter new generation jets, the noise environment around airports will continue to improve for approximately 15 years. However, following completion of the fleet replacement of noisy types, no further substantial noise reductions can be expected. Solutions to the noise problems in the long term lie, therefore, in the way airports and aircraft are operated and in land use planning and control.

The Committee took considerable evidence on the effects of aircraft operations on the domestic life of the community. Overseas studies suggest that aircraft operations can lead to a decrease in mental and physical health and increased mortality rates. However, the Commonwealth Department of Health argued that most of these studies can be criticised on methodological grounds and no State government was able to provide evidence to the Committee which suggested a link between health and aircraft fly- over. It is apparent that the Department of Health has serious doubts about the extent of the relationship between aircraft noise and health and believes that the only way to allay anxieties or, perhaps, to confirm apprehensions is to provide objective data by conducting a better series of studies in Australia. The Committee has recommended that such studies be undertaken.

Despite many individual and community submissions claiming that aircraft operations contribute to pollution and property damage, an examination by the Committee of available technical documents and an analysis of pollution samples suggest that pollution from aircraft sources is insignificant and that vibrations from aircraft noise are unlikely to cause damage. Accordingly, the Committee made no recommendations relating to pollution other than that State governments include airports in their general pollution monitoring programs. Whilst it is unlikely that aircraft noise causes property damage, it appears that turbulence from aircraft wing tips may cause damage. The Committee has, accordingly, recommended that in cases where it can be proven that damage to property from turbulence has occurred the Commonwealth should pay for the cost of restoration.

Many witnesses suggested that the solution to the aircraft noise problem is to insulate buildings. Insulation has been adopted by a number of countries as a partial solution to the problem but we were unable to obtain information relating to the effectiveness of these schemes as they relate to homes. Our inspections of schools in New South Wales where noise attenuation measures have been undertaken indicate that at least for some institutions it is an effective measure. We have recommended that the Commonwealth Government assist the States to provide noise attenuation measures in schools and other institutions. More data will be needed, however, before a large scale home insulation scheme can be introduced.

The evidence received on the effect of aircraft and airport operations on property values is confusing and conflicting. The most detailed information relating to the Australian situation was presented by the Queensland Government, which concluded that property values in area studies in Brisbane are diminished because of noise factors with the areas most adversely affected showing the greatest reduction in value-some up to 15 per cent. The Committee believes that the Department of Aviation is too definite in its view that, in the long run, an airport does not have a net depreciative effect on neighbouring house values. We have recommended that further work be undertaken, particularly with the assistance of the Queensland Government.

The question of compensation was given serious consideration by the Committee. The Committee agrees in principle with the Law Reform Commission's report on lands acquisition and compensation. This report argued that there ought to be a general right for owners to recover compensation when the value of their land is diminished resulting from the use of facilities on adjacent Commonwealth land. We also agree with the qualification to that view that compensation should not be retrospective and should relate only to new developments.

I turn now to aircraft operations. By far the greatest number of complaints received by the Committee, in written and oral evidence, related to the number of and variability in flight paths. It is a generally held belief that pilots and air traffic controllers have far too much discretion and that planes fly on routes which have little regard for the effect on airport communities. Many considered that pilots considered only economic factors, such as the saving of fuel. The Department of Aviation advised that pilots fly only where they are directed by air traffic controllers. Whilst the Department is conscious of the economic aspects of aircraft operations, it advised that the primary consideration is the safety of the operations, and in no circumstances are flights varied in a manner which causes adverse noise effects purely for a reduction in costs.

The Committee concludes that whilst most flight paths are devised primarily for operational reasons, with noise abatement considerations being secondary, it noted a number of flight paths which, with minor modifications involving no loss of safety and little additional cost, could enable aircraft to avoid built up areas. We have, accordingly, recommended that the Department of Aviation review arrival and departure routes for noise sensitive airports and devise procedures based on noise considerations and modified only to the extent to make them operationally acceptable. We also believe that it may be possible for aircraft to avoid noise sensitive areas if navigational aids and radar are upgraded. We have recommended that the Department of Aviation investigate the feasibility of installing such additional equipment.

Other operational matters considered in the report concerned ground running, training flights and helicopter operations. I do not have time to discuss these matters but refer honourable members to the relevant sections of the report. I now come to what many people will consider the most sensitive aspect of our report-the existing curfews. Local government and community groups are particularly concerned about night time operations. Many consider that curfew provisions are breached while others express the view that operations which are allowed under the curfew provisions are inappropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did the committee think?

—I will explain that to the honourable member. Major curfews operate at Brisbane, Sydney, Essendon and Adelaide. The curfew restrictions generally apply to jet aircraft operated between 11 p.m. and 6 a.m. There is no restriction on the operations of propeller driven aircraft. The aviation industry argued that the present curfew was irrational in that it banned the operation of most jet aircraft while there was no restriction on propeller driven aircraft which are often noiser than modern low noise jets. The industry argued that runways, rather than airports, should be curfew operated and engine noise, rather than engine type, should be the basis of the curfew.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee concludes that whilst it might be desirable that a total curfew be placed on flying during sleeping hours it accepts that such a proposal would be unacceptable to the Commonwealth Government, the State governments and also to some local councils as well as to the aviation industry. Accordingly, the Committee gives its qualified support to a revised curfew, provided that special flight paths are designed based on noise considerations, irrespective of economic consequences; that only the quietest aircraft be allowed to operate; that special runways only be used except in cases of emergency; and that the curfew be embodied in regulations under the Air Navigation Act. I emphasise here, particularly in view of the irresponsible comments which, I understand, appeared in Sydney newspapers today, that our recommendations will not cause any increase in aircraft noise. On the contrary, there should be a substantial decrease.

Many witnesses have requested the installation of noise and flight path monitoring equipment. It was the general view that such equipment systems were essential to check the variability of flight paths and the perceived non-compliance with noise abatement procedures and to police the curfew. In addition, the equipment could be used for land use planning purposes as it could check existing noise contours and provide data for revised contours which more accurately reflect actual noise levels and aircraft approach and departure routes. The Committee agrees and has recommended that noise and flight path monitoring systems be installed at major Australian airports.

The United States noise exposure forecast system was adopted in Australia in 1970. The noise exposure forecast system, NEF, is a scientific measure which takes account of the noise of aircraft, the frequency of aircraft types and movements on various flight paths and the average daily distribution of aircraft. The index is used in assessing average community response to aircraft noise and for land use planning around airports. The system was criticised by some councils and community groups on the basis that it is a very poor indicator of the response of any one person to aircraft noise and that it is complex and insensitive to changing aircraft patterns and noise levels.

Notwithstanding these criticisms the system has been generally accepted by both State and Commonwealth authorities as the best available. The National Acoustic Laboratories tested some 20 systems and concluded that it was the best system available. The Committee concludes that on the evidence presented to it and despite its limitations the Australian noise exposure forecast system is the most appropriate system for use in Australia.

The previous Select Committee on Aircraft Noise concluded that land use zoning is the key to resolving the conflict between rquirements of modern air transport and the occupiers of nearby land. We agree with that conclusion. With the exception of Tullamarine all major airports were located at their present sites by the mid 1950s. Urban growth has occurred around airports and under flight paths without regard to aircraft movements. Most unsuitable development has taken place in accordance with policies and principles which were compatible with airports at the time of the development. The Committee noted, however, that a considerable number of inappropriate developments were proceeding in many areas it visited. The Committee notes attempts by state and local government authorities to ensure proper land use. However, restrictions can lead to claims for compensation and the decisions of planning authorities are too easily subject to appeal in the courts.

At the beginning of the inquiry the Department of Aviation advised that the Commonwealth had no powers to control land use in areas surrounding airports. Advice given by the Commonwealth Attorney-General's Department indicates otherwise. The Attorney-General's Department advised that the Commonwealth could prohibit uses of adjoining land which are incompatible with the use of the airport even on land which is not owned by the Commonwealth. The majority of the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Government make it clear to the States that if relevant State and local government authorities do not prohibit inappropriate land use in areas surrounding Commonwealth airports the Commonwealth government should legislate to do so. Furthermore, we believe that Commonwealth Government departments and instrumentalities should be bound by the land use compatibility advice which is provided by the departments of Aviation and Defence and which specifies the types of development which should occur within certain noise zones. This would not only include Commonwealth works proposals but would include State grants and special purpose funding such as the funding of child care centres in inappropriate noise zones.

The Committee notes the confusion which arose concerning land use in areas surrounding Tullamarine airport and has recommended that the Commonwealth Government, when acquiring land for new airports, purchase all land necessary to provide an effective noise buffer zone. The Committee believes that a limited acquisition scheme for the worst affected residential areas should be introduced in Australia. Acquisition should be on a voluntary basis and at fair market value. Relocation and re-establishment expenses should be met by the Commonwealth.

It is clear that many people move into an area with no knowledge that it is located under a flight path or is noise affected. While there is substantial information available from the Department of Aviation and other sources relating to aircraft noise, the problem is ensuring that this information is made available to persons proposing to live in areas which may be affected by aircraft noise. The Committee believes that this information should be provided during the conveyancing process; we have recommended that the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services seek the agreement of his State counterparts for documents relating to property transfer within noise affected areas to specify that inquiries be made on behalf of prospective home purchasers concerning aircraft noise.

Many requests were received from State and local governments and airport communities for the relocation of airports and the construction of new airports or the realignment of existing runways to assist in the alleviation of noise. It is clear that many of the proposed works suggested to the Committee will have noise abatement benefits but at huge costs. The Committee was placed in the difficult position of allocating a priority to various capital works programs. Sydney is the only airport where major capital works can be justified on capacity grounds. The Committee believes, after considerable deliberation, that should a capital works program be developed based on noise criteria, the highest priority should be given to those airports where the noise intrusion is greatest as determined by the number of persons within relevant noise contours.

The Committee is also conscious that it has examined the problems associated with airports and aircraft operations quite apart from other government responsibilities. The adverse effects of aircraft operations is just one of the problems faced by urban communities. The Committee is not in a position to determine the priority which should be given to alleviating aircraft noise effects compared with other government priorities such as education, health, housing and other social welfare problems. We do note, however, that aircraft noise and its effects do not figure highly in the Department of Aviation's capital works decision-making process. Noise considerations must be given a higher priority. While we are not suggesting that there has been a deliberate attempt to mislead the community it is our view that ministers for aviation and the Department have not always provided information which fully informs the community. Electoral expediency has sometimes played its part in arousing community expectations which have subsequently been frustrated.

The Committee believes that the Minister and his Department should exercise caution when talking about airport developments. We have examined statements which perhaps unintentionally could lead to all sorts of inappropriate conclusions. Careless statements have led to problems particularly with regard to Sydney, Adelaide and Perth Airports. We support the proposal by the Minister that a broad based committee system be established for each major airport.

We note the Government's proposal to establish the Federal Airports Corporation to manage major capital city airports. There is no doubt that there is a built-in conflict between the objectives of the FAC to run airports on a sound commercial basis and to make airports better neighbours to the communities they serve. We believe that an environmental policy and assessment branch should be established within the Department of Aviation to develop and monitor noise abatement procedures, assess capital works programs and develop environmental policy guidelines. We further believe that the Air Navigation Act should be amended to include environmental matters and that the legislation establishing the Federal Airports Corporation specify consideration of environmental matters in the functioning of the corporation. Our report is critical of some of the attitudes and approaches of the Department of Aviation and in fact my colleague the honourable for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) is quoted in the report as saying:
Public servants have all the technical expertise to come and argue against what any single citizen puts up, and they have the force and numbers of vast departments to put them down.

It would be remiss of me, however, if I did not place on record the Committee's appreciation for the assistance given by the Department during the course of the inquiry. All information requested was provided promptly, and in some instances information was volunteered which was not complimentary to the Department and could have been withheld. I have been Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation for two-and-a-half years and the assistance given by the Department of Aviation was beyond that given by any other Department.

I wish to place on record the Committee's appreciation for the assistance provided by the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. A normal requirement of Hansard is that venues be quiet and suitable for sound recording. The Committee's deliberations involved conducting some of its hearings in buildings under flight paths. Even in these difficult circumstances Hansard staff were able cheerfully to produce accurate records of the hearing.

My thanks also go to the staff members of the Committee Secretariat-to Mr John Cummins, Mr Ian Dundas, Mr Ron Kropp and Ms Judy Parkinson. Often at a moment's notice they provided their assistance cheerfully and enthusiastically. To John Cummins I owe particular thanks in view of the highly technical nature of this particular report. His grasp of the technical data involved, and his patience in ensuring that I, too, understood the intricacies of aircraft operations, has resulted in what I consider to be a most excellent report, which I commend to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The report just tabled is the conclusion of a long and protracted inquiry which began in June 1982, when the then Minister for Aviation requested the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to conduct an inquiry into matters relating to aircraft noise. I have been a member of the investigating committee throughout the course of the inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence has been collected from throughout Australia and overseas. At all times the Committee made every endeavour to ensure that members of the public had the opportunity to express their point of view. To that end, numerous public meetings and discussions with community groups were held. The report should be an invaluable tool for airport planning and for many other matters of inter-relationship between the aviation industry and the general community.

During the inquiry the Aviation Department and other Commonwealth departments, together with the aviation industry, provided invaluable assistance, particularly on technical matters. Local government bodies were also more than willing to assist. However, some State governments, and their departments, were not as helpful as they might have been. While the Department of Aviation was always available to offer assistance, I felt some officers assumed an arrogant and aloof attitude, and their responses provided only the minimum information required. Such attitudes are not helpful to a parliamentary inquiry, and those officers should remember that the taxpayers who pay their wages have a right to expect value for money. I do not extend that comment to the officers of the Aviation Department at Morabbin Airport, who went out of their way to be courteous and helpful.

I was also not impressed by some actions of the Australian Mayoral Aviation Council. The Council can play a useful role in co-ordinating advice, services and planning that will relieve noise pollution in their local communities. However, I am of the view that many of the actions of individual mayors are designed to pursue their own political objectives and assist their re-election prospects, rather than provide relief for the local community. All this is done at substantial cost to the ratepayers, with little benefit being derived.

Land use planning, particularly for residential subdivisions near airports, is a major problem. Local and State governments must be held equally at fault. There is much buck passing between the two levels of government, and neither seems prepared to accept responsibility for some of the reckless approvals for subdivisions that have been granted. On advice from the Attorney-General's Department, the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth assume responsibility from the States for certain land use planning. In a minority report the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Fischer), the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster) and I do not accept that conclusion.

It is clear that the States have failed badly to enact adequate land use planning legislation that provides clear and distinct authority for both local government and State departments. However, I am of the firm view that the failure of the States is not reason enough in itself for the Commonwealth to usurp such a fundamental responsibility from the States. Land use planning has always been a State responsibility. It was inherent in the 1890 Constitutional Conventions that that responsibility should remain with the States. For the Commonwealth to use, or attempt to use, an uncertain head of power to overturn a fundamental tenet of the Constitution must bring into question the future of the Australian Federation. The more obvious solution is for the States to lift their game.

The minority report also recommends the construction of a parallel runway at Mascot Airport. A widely held view in the community is that the construction of a new airport at Sydney will relieve the noise problem at Mascot Airport. The Department of Aviation and the aviation industry point out that even if a new airport is built at Sydeny, there will be very little change to the traffic volume or type of aircraft using Mascot. It follows that noise adjacent to Mascot will not be alleviated by simply building a new airport. The cost of a new airport could be of the order of $600m, while a new runway could be built for something less than $50m and provide adequate capacity for well into the next century.

While it has not been included as part of the minority report, I must oppose the construction of a new runway at Perth Airport. The Department points out that for operational reasons, a new runway is not required and the present runway capacity will be adequate until at least the middle of the next century. The only reason for a new runway is environmental consideration. However, the cost of between $30m and $50m is not justified because a new runway would simply move the noise problem from one group of residents to another.

Local government should do far more in providing information to residents. I cannot recall any evidence from a local council that can provide information on sound insulation or other materials or building techniques designed to minimise noise penetration into homes. Such information is essential to residents and building contractors and should be freely available at all council offices where aircraft noise is a problem. While aircraft movements will continue to increase, much can be done to alleviate the distrubance to people living close to airports. The report makes many such recommendations and should be actioned by the responsible officials.

I would like to congratulate the Committee Chairman, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), for the enthusiastic and dedicated way in which he has led this inquiry. It has been a pleasure to work with him and the other members of the Committee. I would also like to thank Mr John Cummins and other members of the secretariat staff. Their professionalism and dedication are exemplary and set a high standard for other parliamentary officers to emulate.

—I seek leave to make a very short statement in relation to the report.
