SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts I present the 240th report of the Committee relating to the report of the Auditor-General for March 1984. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will be aware that each year the Committee examines recently published reports of the Auditor-General. Following the tabling of the report of the Auditor-General for March 1984, the Committee sought written submissions from 16 departments in respect of 19 items. The Committee took public evidence on two items-National Biological Standards Laboratory-NBSL-and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Biological Standards Laboratory has the responsibility, together with the Therapeutic Division of the Department of Health, for ensuring that safe and effective theraputic goods for both human and veterinary use are available in Australia. The provision of standards for goods and the testing for their compliance with those specifications has traditionally been the method used to regulate their quality. However, there are a number of practical drawbacks in relying entirely on the standards mechanism.

The preparation of standards has been a slow process. The Department of Health stated that so far 11 standards had statutory status and another seven were ready for ministerial approval. The Department elaborated on other mechanisms to supplement the inadequacies of the standards mechanism and these are outlined in the Report.

The Committee was concerned at the progress in implementing the national Register of Therapeutic Goods since the legislation had been amended in 1981 to make the supply of the information by companies obligatory. On testing of therapeutical goods, the Department states that in general, products listed as pharmaceutical benefits are accorded a high priority for testing. For example, antibiotic products are tested at least once a year and other benefit items from yearly to every four years. This is not the case with veterinary antibiotic products where there is no effective regulatory action available to the Commonwealth under the present Act as in the case of pharmaceutical products. Proposals have been made to the States to establish a national system for the regulation of the quality of therapeutic goods for veterinary use.

The Department advised the Committee that inspection at manufacture of pharmaceutical goods is probably the most cost-effective of the mechanisms for the regulation of quality and Australia has suffered because there were not enough inspectors. Additionally, the Department has amalgamated the Therapeutics Division of the Department of Health with the National Biological Standards Laboratory to form a unitary structure organisation. This now parallels agencies which occur in other countries, such as the Food and Drug Administration in the United States of America and the Food and Drug Directorate in Canada.

The Committee was advised that NBSL's major problem is inadequate physical resources. As there is no central laboratory, facilities are in buildings scattered in different suburbs of Canberra and Melbourne. The bacteriology laboratory and the animal house facilities are totally inadequate and the sterility testing is performed in what used to be the kitchen of a restaurant. The Committee is aware that the report of the inquiry into Commonwealth Laboratories-November 1983-noted that the NBSL was working in accommodation which was quite inadequate. The report's recommendations were made on the understanding that the project for a new building to accommodate all Laboratory sections, which was given approval in the 1983-84 Budget, would proceed, approval which was subsequently revoked.

The Committee is very concerned that NBSL's facilities are so inadequate, below standard and scattered that it cannot effectively peform its functions. The Committee concluded that the appropriate legislative or policy changes needed to be implemented and, at the same time, the lack of resources needed to be addressed urgently. The Committee will be monitoring this situation closely.

An audit was conducted in Queensland on the hiring of aircraft within the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Certain aspects concerning the piloting of hired aircraft by a staff member were pursued with the ABC. The Committee was particularly concerned about this item in view of the death of an ABC regional program manager and his three passengers in an aircraft crash in Queensland on 24 October 1983. It would appear to the Committee that the administrative procedures of the ABC for the chartering of aircraft, except in the situation where a member of the Corporation's staff piloted the aircraft, were appropriate. The Committee notes that in the case of chartering and using its own staff as pilots the ABC has refined its procedures and laid down minimum standards.

In its examination of the Department of Social Security's unemployment benefit administration, the Committee was very concerned with weaknesses in the administrative arrangements between the DSS and the Commonwealth Employment Service, and in the associated procedures and controls in operation at the CES. The Committee notes that revised arrangements for the review of unemployment benefit recipients have been on trial and the DSS is currently assessing the results of those trials.

The introduction of new proof of identity guidelines by the DSS was noted in the Committee's 232nd and 233rd reports tabled in May 1985. As stated then, the Committee is most concerned that beneficiaries are properly identified prior to becoming entitled to, or receiving, benefits. The Committee is pleased to note that early indications are that the system is efficient and effective in meeting its objectives of deterring fraud while improving the service provided to genuine needy clients and that it is reducing client-staff tension during the POI procedure.

In his examination of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations, the Auditor-General noted evidence that deficiencies existed in the controls over the charging of trainee salary payments to appropriations of DEIR. The Department of Finance carried out a national survey of salaries charged to the appropriations of DEIR manpower, training programs in late 1982. The survey disclosed that salaries being paid to a significant number of persons were being charged incorrectly to DEIR appropriations, although they were no longer in a training program or had been appointed to a permanent Public Service position. The survey indicated a lack of oversight by DEIR of the charging of salary payments to appropriations under its control. The Committee does not accept that any overpayment of Commonwealth funds is merely a matter of miscoding. All cases detected must be investigated and recovery action instituted.

The Committee examined the Australian Development Assistance Bureau's project of the desiccated coconut factory in Tonga. The Committee concluded that some responsibility for the failure of the factory must be borne by the consultants whom ADAB engaged to design a factory that would achieve the desired level of output, and to supervise its construction. The consultants did not adhere to the original specifications and some of the modifications implemented only exacerbated problem areas.

In its examination of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Committee was concerned that the formal agreements on the adult migrant education program with all States and the Northern Territory had not been concluded more than two years after the Minister sought formal agreement. One State still has to accept the agreement. The Committee sees the finalisation of regulations for the payment of allowances as being necessary and urgent.

Many reports of the Auditor-General-the latest being the April 1985 report-have referred to the potential for overpayments and administrative difficulties and the need for review of the continuing eligibility of pensioners in receipt of telephone rental concessions. The telephone rental concession was introduced on 1 October 1964. The Department of Communications is now co-ordinating the discussions regarding the administration of the telephone rental concessions. The Committee is concerned that this matter continues to be unresolved.

In its examination of the Commonwealth Department of Transport, the Committee is concerned at the serious deficiencies in the Australian National Railways Commission's acquisition and development of computer based systems. The Committee will continue to monitor this item in subsequent Auditor-General's reports and in the response to this report. I commend this report to honourable members.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE GERMAN DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the European parliamentary institutions and the German Democratic Republic. I seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The delegation visited Strasbourg for meetings of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe and the European Parliament. The delegation also spent seven days in the German Democratic Republic. The report which I have tabled draws attention to the activities of the delegation and makes a number of recommendations regarding future delegations and for Australia's relations with Europe.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation was able to meet with the European parliamentary delegation which visited Australia last week. We had discussions with that delegation on a range of issues but, as we note in the report, two issues continue to dominate the discussions; that is, the common agricultural policy and kangaroo culling. I understand that the discussion on these issues continued during the delegation's visit to Australia. In the report the delegation suggests that it may now be the time to widen the issues for discussion to matters of common interest, such as youth unemployment and the new technologies, rather than to continue to let matters on which we disagree dominate the discussions. This is not to suggest that the representations regarding the common agricultural policy or the concern over kangaroos should be neglected; rather they should be put in perspective.

The delegation was regarded by the German Democratic Republic officials as the first Australian delegation to visit that country. The pride of the citizens of the German Democratic Republic in their achievements was obvious to the members of the delegation, as was their concern about peace and disarmament. The delegation was indeed fortunate in being able to meet with the Prime Minister and Foreign Minister of the German Democratic Republic, as well as members of their Volkskammer, or People's Chamber. It also had discussions with the Burgermeisters of the towns of Erfurt, Leipzig and Weimar. In addition to these discussions, it was able to attend the opera and a symphony orchestra performance.

The report gives details of the places visited by the delegation and of the discussions held. It is noted that the format for discussions is rather different from that we are use to in Australia. Commemorative wreaths were laid at the Buchenwald Camp and Stahndorf Cemetery where some 24 Australian World War I soldiers are buried. Statements made by members of the delegation at the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe are included as appendices to the report.

I would thank our hosts for the hospitality extended to the delegation during the visit. I would also pay tribute to the representatives of the Australian Government who assisted the delegation. Ambassador and Mrs Witheford in Berlin were unstinting in their efforts to ensure the success of the delegation's visit. They were ably assisted by Carol Watson. Mr Tony Verner and Mr Andre Morony from the Paris Embassy, together with Mr Geoff Wiseman and David Hawes of the Australian Embassy in Brussels, were of great assistance to the delegation. On behalf of the delegation I would also like to express our gratitude to the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office and in particular to Mr Kerin Schneemann for their care, often during trying times, in making arrangements for the delegation, and also to the staff of the Parliamentary Library for their preparation of a most comprehensive brief for use by members of the delegation. In particular, I pay tribute to the secretary to the delegation, Mr Phil Bergin. His patience, enthusiasm and quiet efficiency were vital ingredients in the delegation's success.

Finally, I express my personal thanks to all members of the delegation for their friendship and forbearance, especially to Senator Robert Ray, who took over as leader on my premature departure and return to this country, and also the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) who served as deputy leader of the delegation during its period overseas. This was a very large delegation. It represented a wide spectrum of political beliefs from all parties from both Houses of the Parliament. The fact that members of the delegation were able to present a united Australian position on each and every question as it arose is evidence not only of their fine personnal qualities as parliamentarians, but also of the wisdom that their respective parties displayed in selecting them to serve on the delegation.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NATIONAL MARITIME MUSEUM, SYDNEY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 and by reason of the urgent nature of the work, it is expedient that the following proposed work be carried out without it having been referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works: Construction of National Maritime Museum, Sydney.

The Government has decided to provide $30m to the New South Wales Government for construction and fitout of stage one of the proposed National Maritime Museum. The museum will be constructed on a site at the entrance to Darling Harbour and will be an integral part of the 1988 bicentennial celebrations. It will provide a focus for the visit to Sydney in 1988 by the tall ships as part of the bicentennial. The museum will exhibit a collection of historic ships, maritime objects, documents and photographs and will provide workshop type facilities which will demonstrate many of the seafarers' skills. The project includes provision of wharves, sea walls, site works and a number of historic vessels relocated to berths at these wharves and at a wharf to be provided by the New South Wales Government under Pyrmont Bridge.

Honourable members will be aware that a major redevelopment of Darling Harbour has been commenced by the New South Wales Government, and I believe the National Maritime Museum will be a major attraction for visitors to the area. The integration of the museum into the Darling Harbour redevelopment is a complex task and the time remaining for construction of the building is very short. It was therefore decided that construction and fitout could be best carried out by using the services of the New South Wales Government and its Darling Harbour Construction Authority. New South Wales has accepted responsibility for all construction and fitout and completion of stage one by January 1988, in time for opening by March 1988.

A Commonwealth statutory authority is to be established to control and operate the Commonwealth owned museum. The Commonwealth is to provide the functional brief and a consultant architect, nominated by the Commonwealth, is to be engaged by the Darling Harbour Authority to design the facility. Timing is so critical that there is insufficient time for the proposal to be referred to the Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report. The construction program requires the Commonwealth to provide its final briefing by mid-December 1985 and for formal commissions to be entered into by the Darling Harbour Authority. Construction will be undertaken by the `fast track' method, where the design and construction phases overlap, and construction is arranged progressively rather than the traditional method of following full design and documentation.
The Public Works Committee has been informed of these decisions and has requested that its formal viewpoint be placed on record. It is as follows:

The proposition for the National Maritime Museum was brought to the attention of the Public Works Committee last September by officers of the Department of Housing and Construction. The Committee was informed that the Commonwealth Government and the New South Wales Government had been involved in discussions on the matter and that it was likely that a final decision would not be reached until close to the end of the year. The Committee was also aware that the project was running to an extremely tight timetable, with a view to making stage one of the development operational by 1 January 1988.
The Committee was able to visit the site of the National Maritime Museum in Darling Harbour on the afternoon of 1 October following its public hearing into the GPO facade earlier that day.

For the visit the Committee was provided with copies of an architectural appreciation of the National Maritime Museum which covered such matters as the concept, location, relationship with Sydney Maritime Museum, staging and timing, commercial aspects, planning controls, pedestrian promenades, site coverage and other planning factors as well as a drawing of the complete Darling Harbour development project.

Prior to the visit to the site itself, the Committee was provided with a full briefing on the proposed development, including a slide presentation by the Design Director of the Darling Harbour Authority. Following a tour of the entire site development area, the Committee then inspected in detail the site for the National Maritime Museum. This comprises 3.3 hectares of land and water areas offered to the Commonwealth by the New South Wales Government. The site, which will be leased by the Commonwealth, is on the western foreshore of Darling Harbour, immediately north of the western end of Pyrmont Bridge.

The Committee recognises the reasons for the urgent nature of the proposed work. In acknowledging this, the Committee is not in a position to state that it agrees with what exactly is proposed as the functional brief has not yet been finalised. Had it been given the opportunity to conduct a public hearing into the proposal and take evidence from all those involved with the proposed National Maritime Museum, the Committee would have been able to respond in a more meaningful way. The situation would, therefore, be best served by permitting the House the opportunity to resolve the issue.

I can understand the view of the Public Works Committee that it would have been desirable to undertake the full consideration and report procedure in the conventional manner. However, my best advice was that if this procedure had been adhered to, there was little or no possibility of the museum opening by early 1988. I have undertaken to provide as much information as possible to the Public Works Committee as the project proceeds. Before asking the House to support the motion, I emphasise to honourable members that the Commonwealth will be retaining full control of the design and construction to its own brief. The museum will be Commonwealth owned and operated. If the House agrees to support this motion, planning and construction can proceed in accordance with the timetable I have outlined. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Millar Mr P.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to speak briefly, as Vice-Chairman of the Standing Committee on Public Works, to the motion. I am mindful that the Committee-notwithstanding the fact that, as the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) quite correctly said, the Committee recognises the circumstances with which the Minister and the Government is confronted-is sensitive to one or two points. I am quite sure that in turn the Minister is sensitive to the attitude of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I am bound to say on behalf of the Committee that it rather senses that there are no problems with work of a routine nature such as post offices and telephone exchanges being referred to the Committee for inquiry and report. However, it also seems that all too frequently, when the work is of a contentious or challenging nature, such as the proposed National Maritime Museum, the Committee seems to be excluded from the opportunity to pursue its ordinary address to the question.

In effect the Committee asks to what extent it has a meaningful role to play. The National Maritime Museum is just such a project that should demand the attention of the Committee. The Committee urges the Government not to treat it with contempt. We do not allege that that is the attitude of the Government, but it is an attitude into which one might fall without an appreciation of the full significance of so doing. As a consequence, the taking of such action could damage the reputation of the Public Works Committee. I reiterate that the Public Works Committee is responsible to Parliament. The Committee has a responsibility in regard to work funded by the Commonwealth. It resists in the strongest terms any deliberate act by any government to bypass the Committee. The Committee does not deny that the National Maritime Museum project has been a matter for both the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments and that it may be a special case being a Bicentennial project.

Nevertheless, questions arise. The Bicentennial program has been around a long time. Why has it been left virtually to the last minute for a decision to be made, even when the functional brief has not yet been finalised? The National Maritime Museum type of project is one that could be fairly described as one that should be watched very closely indeed. The phrase `hasten slowly' certainly would be most appropriate. Some members of the Committee have expressed the point of view that it is virtually impossible to fit such a project into the timetable announced. Also, the Committee, in the course of a public inquiry on the National Maritime Museum, would have sought assurances as to the prudence of fast-track methods which are to be adopted for the project. The Committee, lacking such assurances, is generally uneasy about the whole project.

The Committee, mindful of all these circumstances, is not prompted seriously to challenge the right of the House to resolve the question now before it. The Committee will accept the outcome as an ordinary consequence of the role of the House. I emphasise that the points I have made with regard to the motion to declare the work proposed for the National Maritime Museum an urgent work is the unanimous view of the Public Works Committee.
Debate (on motion by Mr Beale) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FITOUT OF OFFICE SPACE AT CANBERRA NATIONAL CONVENTION CENTRE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Fitout of office space at Canberra National Convention Centre, Canberra City, for Commonwealth use.

The proposal involves a fitout of 42,000 square metres of general office space accommodation in five Commonwealth leased buildings of the Canberra National Convention Centre complex which is currently under construction in the Civic area of Canberra. The office space will be occupied by the Australian Customs Service, the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Department of Territories. The fitout will involve partitions for offices, conference rooms, interview rooms et cetera; alterations to mechanical light and power, telephone, fire and other services to suit specific office layouts, minor alterations to ceilings, walls and floor finishes, joinery to public counters and reception areas; appropriate finishes to executive and staff amenities areas, including necessary services, guard posts, building perimeter security and other security measures and curtain tracks. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $12.3m at August 1985 prices. I thank the Standing Committee on Public Works for its prompt consideration of this proposal. If the House agrees to support this motion planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not object to this motion. I remind the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) of my response to his motion to refer this project to the Standing Committee on Public Works on 9 October this year when the Opposition requested, firstly, that he ensure the maximum involvement of the private sector in the project, secondly, that he recognise the need to contain costs associated with the project and, thirdly, that he request his colleagues who are involved in the consolidation of office facilities to take advantage of the move to streamline and rationalise their departments' operations. Once again we ask the Minister to interest his Department to take notice of our requests.

SPEECH.PARA: In talking to this motion for the fitout of office space at the Canberra National Convention Centre it seems appropriate to refer the Minister to a report issued today entitled `Report of the Auditor-General on an Efficiency Audit: Department of Housing and Construction-Construction Project Management: The National Acoustics Laboratory and Ultrasonics Institute, The Australian Defence Force Academy'. One of the reasons that we seek to ensure, in the case of the Canberra National Convention Centre, that maximum involvement of the private sector arises relates to some of the recommendations of the Auditor-General in the report to which I have referred. I will refer to these. The Auditor-General stated:
. . . Audit did not find on record any assessment of the financial risks associated with the decision taken.
This is in regard to the National Acoustics Laboratory and Ultrasonics Institute. Furthermore, the Auditor-General stated:
Audit could find no authoritative material in the Department that could be used as a reference for officers making decisions in these cases.
Furthermore, in discussing the Canberra National Convention Centre-again dealing with the National Acoustics Laboratory and Ultrasonics Institute-audit suggested:
. . . tighter accountability and more formalised controls over variations should be introduced in the interests of the Department.
The Auditor-General continued:
Audit would prefer to see the judgment of these professional offices being exercised within a framework of authoritative guidelines set by the Department's Central Office.

One of the reasons we reiterate the need for maximum involvement of the private sector in the Canberra National Convention Centre is that the Auditor-General gives a shocking report on the performance of the Department of Housing and Construction. Furthermore, the Auditor-General stated:
. . . considers that improvement and rectification may have been effected more quickly if portion of progress payments had been earlier withheld. Prompt action along these lines is recommended-
The Auditor-General continued:
The Department agreed that there were problems-

This is not the only project on which the Auditor-General had something to say about the performance of the Department of Housing and Construction. If I may reiterate, that is again why we are interested in seeing that the Canberra National Convention Centre has the maximum involvement of the private sector. In regard to the Australian Defence Force Academy the Auditor-General said:

The. . . financial statement to 30 November 1984 showed the then current cost . . . at $65,037,159 with the total forecast cost to completion as $74,267,159. This compares with $49,036,228 when the contract was let in February 1983.
Audit noted that 37 per cent of variations (40 per cent by value) were due to errors and omissions in original design specifications.

Audit was unable to find evidence of the Department having produced guidelines or standards in this regard . . . the Department acknowledged that it does not itself perform a specific check of . . . work completed.
Audit does not accept the Department's contention that the construction manager's staff can be regarded as an extension service to the Department.

These continual reiterations of the Auditor-General on the performance of the Department of Housing and Construction lead us to have great concern about the refurbishment of the Canberra National Convention Centre. The Auditor-General goes on to say in regard to the Australian Defence Force Academy:

Audit recommends that the Department arrange its priorities so as to ensure that work required for the application of proper financial controls is undertaken in a timely manner . . . Audit recommended that the Department develop guidelines for the administration of construction management agreements, basing the material on experience gained to date. In view of the Department's performance in respect of expenditure control, Audit reiterates that recommendation and suggests the Department give it high task priority. The Department does not accept that expenditure control has been inadequate.
We have the extraordinary situation that the Auditor-General is telling the Department that its expenditure control has been inadequate and the Department denies it. To continue:
Audit also recommends that before approving tenders, the Department should itself assess and document the technical and financial capacity of the tenderer. . .

These continued shortfalls in the performance of the Department of Housing and Construction as evidenced by the report of the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit in regard to the National Acoustics Laboratory and Ultrasonics Institute and the Australian Defence Force Academy lead us to conclude that it is imperative that the Minister direct his Department in such a way as to ensure the maximum involvement of the private sector in the refurbishment of the Canberra National Convention Centre.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: TELECOM AUSTRALIA-CONSTRUCTION OF NEW ACCOMMODATION AT RESOURCES MANAGEMENT CENTRE, CLAYTON, VICTORIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Telecom Australia-Construction of new accommodation at Resources Management Centre, Clayton, Victoria.

The proposal is for the construction of the three buildings at the Resources Management Centre, Clayton, to accommodate sophisticated equipment essential to Telecom's operations. The buildings comprise the following: An operations building to house data processing equipment, associated engineering services, staff facilities and amenities; an engineering services building which will accommodate emergency generators, supervisory systems, associated staff amenities, office, store, and workshop facilities; and a support building which will provide general office space for programming and administrative staff and provide appropriate amenities for all staff on site. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $18.3m at July 1985 prices. It is proposed to invite tenders as soon as approval is given with a view to completion of construction to enable the installation of equipment by the third quarter of 1987. I would like to thank the Standing Committee on Public Works for its prompt consideration of this proposal. If the House agrees to support this motion planning can proceed in accordance with the recommendations of the Committee. I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) that in my response on 9 October to his motion to refer this project to the Standing Committee on Public Works I requested that he keep in mind, firstly, the need to contain capital costs and in passing to note that the Opposition is reviewing its attitude to the privatisation of Telecom Australia which may well have resulted in the taxpayer not having to shoulder the burden of this $18m expenditure; and, secondly, the need to ensure the maximum involvement of the private sector in the project. On almost every occasion that I have responded to motions by the Minister for Housing and Construction to refer work to the Public Works Committee or to move for approval of work I have requested him to ensure maximum involvement of the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Auditor-General on an efficiency audit into the National Acoustics Laboratory and Ultrasonics Institute and the Australian Defence Force Academy demonstrates very vividly the inadequacies of the Department. The Opposition believes that a portion of certain of the functions now being carried out by the Minister's Department, such functions as architecture, design, engineering, planning, co-ordination, maintenance and supervision, could be carried out equally well by the private sector. Indeed, all these functions are currently being duplicated by the private sector. When a new project arises the Department decides whether it will use the private sector or its own internal resources. While we in the Opposition recognise that it would be quite inappropriate to ask the private sector to perform all these functions-for example, in matters of national security and maintenance in outback areas-we believe that the Department should be making an effort to reduce its internal work load by selectively transferring the functions mentioned to the private sector. The Opposition does not object to this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the National Party moving that the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The right honourable member will give me the motion in writing.

—I tender in writing the motion to suspend Standing Orders. It is a fact that the hour is now quarter past ten. The House is sitting merely because the Government has not been able to get its act together and the Senate has not passed the legislation. We believe it appropriate that the House should adjourn according to the sessional order which was that the House should adjourn at 10.15. In those circumstances I believe it appropriate that we should suspend so much of the Standing Orders as would prevent me moving a motion to that effect.
—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this motion. The Government has before the House substantial legislation and it is seeking to give an opportunity to honourable members to debate the legislation which is before the Parliament. It may be a source of amusement to the Opposition-having wasted a considerable amount of time with censure motions and other diversions-to seek the adjournment of the House at this particular point, but it is not the Government's intention to support this motion. We oppose the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Sinclair's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address the House on the Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill 1985. I support what was said by the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt) who, as the House is aware, has already put the Opposition's point of view on this Bill. In my opening remarks I must take up some of the comments made by the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) who is, in fact, the only Government member at this stage to have addressed the Government's point of view. I was rather surprised to hear the honourable member say that the Opposition was guilty of simply dreaming up issues and running around looking for homes for them.

SPEECH.PARA: Rarely has there been a Bill before the House on which the Opposition has had to do so little looking for an issue. This Bill simply highlights a gross administrative error on the part of the Government. Over 12 months ago, this Parliament approved a Bill to amend the Quarantine Act. The Minister responsible, then the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), failed to notify the Parliament of changes to the regulations. In spite of that failure the Department of Primary Industry has continued not only to collect but also to impose fees over that period. When we consider the enormity of this administrative bungle; and this lack of administrative skill on the part of the Minister for Health, it is no wonder that he has been relieved of his responsibility for animal and plant quarantine; it is no wonder that he has been relieved of his responsibility for old people's homes; and, given the present state of hospitals in Canberra, we might reasonably expect him shortly to be relieved of his responsibility of Medicare as well.

Today, the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) comes into this House carrying the unwanted child of the Minister for Health because in fact the fees are still being collected illegally by the Department of Primary Industry, thanks to an error on the part of the Minister of Health. What is quite evident from the second reading speech of the Minister for Primary Industry is that responsibility for this administrative bungle rests with the Minister for Health.

The point that I make to the House this evening is that the whole issue of quarantine, quarantine fees and the way in which we administer quarantine in Australia is one of paramount importance. I refer to the 1979 report on quarantine by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. The Committee acknowledged that animal, plant and human quarantine was important and pointed out that we are also endeavouring to keep out of Australia diseases, which do not attract attention. The Committee said this:

Diseases of economic importance to Australia's pastoral industries need not be exotic diseases which cause death and destruction. Diseases which reduce output, increase costs and restrict access to markets are becoming more significant as competition in world markets increases.

If our quarantine facilities and branches are being ineffectively administered, we might well ask ourselves what is happening to the policing of quarantine in Australia. There are few questions as important to Australia's primary producers, many of whom are represented by members on this side of the House. It is significant that Australia is a unique island free from exotic diseases. An area in my own State of South Australia is in fact free from fruit-fly, and ought to remain so, only because of the way in which quarantine regulations are policed.

There is a need for proper policing not only of the fruit and vegetable industries but also of the enormous Australian livestock industries. The fact that Australia is free from endemic livestock diseases has allowed us to exploit markets that would otherwise be denied to us. There are plenty of countries to which we sell our agricultural produce which would gladly, and do gladly, erect non-tariff barriers simply on the grounds of quarantine. There is not a primary producer who is not acutely conscious of the demands that those non-tariff barriers have on his marketing skills. We ought to do all we can to keep livestock areas or plant areas free from diseases so that we can maintain the few markets that are open to us.

The way in which we police quarantine is of paramount importance in this day and age when air travel is regarded by a great number of people as a way of life. In a previous debate in this House today the efficiency of the Australian Customs Service was praised by members on both sides of the House. However, members from both sides of the House should be concerned about the administrative bungling that we are currently addressing ourselves to. We can be satisfied that with nothing short of a 100 per cent effort in regard to the quarantine aspects of animal, plant and human health.

Only last week my attention was drawn to a case in New South Wales where plant quarantine had been much less than adequate. In this instance a passenger arriving from Israel attempted to import a citrus tree. That tree was rightly confiscated. However, astonishingly, it was later released and had to be tracked down and subsequently destroyed by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture. When we talk about quarantine we do not talk simply about diseases that are painfully evident even to the untrained eye. We are talking about viruses that may take weeks, months or even years to evolve. The rest of the world watches the way in which we administer and police our quarantine service and markets are opened and closed to us on the efficiency or inefficiency of that service.

What we have before us tonight is a case of gross administrative inefficiency. If we are not prepared to demand 100 per cent efficiency from our quarantine services, we cannot expect people to stop importing to Australia things that we find less than desirable. I must digress for a moment and point to the threat to the Australian wine industry and Australian health from polluted wines that come into this country from time to time.

I conclude my participation in this debate by referring with a touch of irony to an article in the Canberra Times on 15 November 1985 which said that the Minister for Primary Industry had announced a $75,000 campaign that was being developed by the public relations section of the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service. The article went on to state:
This year the Commonwealth will spend $205,000 on promoting interstate plant quarantine, financing the publicity dollar-for-dollar with the States.
The campaign centres on a cartoon-type character called Border Bandit, patched together out of fruit and vegetables and wearing a hat with dangling imitation fruit flies.
We must ask ourselves, in view of the administrative bungle that has occurred, whether in fact the Minister for Health ought to be known as the Blewett border bandit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the Government and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) for the introduction of the Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill which is yet further evidence of the Government's persistent concern regarding the need for an effective and efficient quarantine service. I also commend the past work of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and his Department in quarantine legislation. The purpose of this Bill is to validate the collection of human, animal and plant quarantine fees. It will also deal with the fee charged for the removal and disposal of waste from overseas aircraft. For a long time a fee was charged for this service which was performed by quarantine authorities but recent examination of the process has shown that there is no legal backing for the charging of such fees and this Bill will validate their collection.

SPEECH.PARA: Travellers who arrive from overseas and food waste on overseas aircraft present a potentially dangerous reservoir of exotic disease. The introduction of, for instance, foot and mouth disease into this country would spell disaster, not only for primary producers but for all Australians. There would be an immediate halt to Australia's export of meat and other animal products such as skins and this would result in the loss of many millions of dollars in export income. It would cause a severe blowout in our trade balance and reduce living standards in rural and even urban areas. For instance, the cost of the recent outbreak of fowl plague in Victoria, which was confined to a small area and eradicated quickly, ran into millions of dollars. An outbreak of foot and mouth disease would be far costlier. It would affect our primary export industries and, if it spread to feral animals, it would be extremely costly to control. Controlling feral animals is likely to be a major obstacle to eradicating some outbreaks of exotic disease. Present plans and techniques are inadequate and co-ordination between agencies responsible for fauna, vertebrate pests and animal health can be greatly improved.

Developing feral animal management strategies has the dual advantages of not only improving exotic disease preparedness but also reducing agricultural and environmental damage by feral animals. It was only when the Hawke Labor Government came to office that recognition was given to the threat of exotic disease spread through feral animal populations. This Government provided Federal funding for the first time for feral animal control in the 1984-85 Budget and increased this by 25 per cent in the 1985-86 Budget. It also took a Labor Government, with its Minister for Primary Industry, to act upon a report presented in the early 1980s by a working party on wildlife and exotic diseases, which recommended the appointment of an officer in the Department of Primary Industry to be specifically responsible for feral animals. This Government has appointed two officers. The appointment in 1984 of Dr George Wilson as senior officer in the new feral animal control section of the Australian agricultural health and quarantine service was very fortunate appointment. Dr Wilson has, in conjunction with the States, drawn up guidelines for a national contingency plan for feral animal control in the event of an exotic disease outbreak. This is part of exotic disease preparedness program. The animal Health Committee of the Standing Committee on Agriculture has prime responsibility for drafting exotic disease contingency plans.

The first drafts of the plan to control feral animals are being prepared by officers of vertebrate pest authorities in collaboration with animal health authorities. The Council of Nature Conservation Ministers, CONCOM, has nominated a contact officer to ensure that native fauna matters are fully considered. Dr Wilson is also very capably co-ordinating State feral animal control exercises that aim to test the plans. It is clearly necessary to get feral animal numbers down before an outbreak of exotic disease and to restrict their movements in key areas, such as Cape York. Foot and mouth disease and rabies are only as far away as Indonesia. Foot and mouth disease virus is known to persist in some products for a very long time-for example, for up to 250 days in sausage casings. Activities on the ground are being developed by the Minister for Primary Industry, Dr Wilson and State governments to achieve a reduction in feral animal numbers and restriction of their movement. The Commonwealth-State feral animal control program is providing funds for these exercises and projects to obtain information for effective control to be incorporated in the plans.

Effective quarantine measures are absolutely essential to the well-being of Australia. The disastrous economic consequences of diseases such as foot and mouth are well known. Rabies would be equally disastrous. In Europe, 23,618 cases of animal rabies were reported in 1984, the highest number since 1977. In Australia, where large areas are sparsely populated and disease carriers, such as foxes, are abundant, rabies would be difficult, if not impossible to control. Current freedom and enjoyment in bush walking and wilderness trekking would be spoilt by the presence of rabies. The importance of a vigilant quarantine service cannot be overemphasised. It delights me that this Government has given so much attention to the prevention and spread of exotic disease outbreak and I congratulate the Minister.

The feral animal control program addresses operational questions and aims to develop practical techniques for controlling potential vectors to exotic diseases. Exercises which have been conducted in Queensland and New South Wales under the program have shown that many areas of control need improving. These include the need for better techniques for contolling feral animals in thick bush, better communications, particularly air-using a helicopter-to ground and improvements in the liaison between veterinary surgeons and vertebrate pest authorities. Mapping of the results of broad scale feral animal surveys is also urgently needed in order to establish key risk areas. These problems will be addressed by the Government.

In addition to funds already provided, workers under the Government's community development program will soon begin to incorporate feral animal data into computerised databased networks developed by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Not long before I came into the House I had notice from the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) that a community employment program, under the Commonwealth component, entitled `Feral Animal and Wildlife Management' has been adopted by the Government. This will involve three people being employed in the production of maps, computerised data and library work for use in managing wildlife and feral animals. They will collect and publish information on wildlife and feral animal control strategies.

A feral animal control task force has been set up in the electorate of Eden-Monaro by community and government interests with two CEP workers to help co-ordinate and develop feral animal control efforts. The taskforce may be the basis-I hope it will be-for a national network of community based feral animal control organisations. For a long time I have advocated the development of a large national community employment program to reduce numbers and restrict the movement of feral animals in key areas. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In beginning my comments tonight on the Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill 1985 I endorse some of the words of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). What he said about feral animals is true. They are an enormous problem, one that most Australians are totally unaware of. They would be the major cause of not being able to contain foot and mouth disease if it ever got into this country. The honourable member may have had a slight problem at the beginning of his speech with his reference to foot and mouth. He nearly had his foot in his mouth when he praised the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) for continuing a practice of collecting fees illegally. I cannot see how the honourable member could praise the Minister when he has been neglecting his duty.

SPEECH.PARA: The primary reason why this Bill comes before the Parliament tonight is to rectify past omissions and oversights by the Minister for Health. Furthermore, when responsibility for plant and animal quarantine was transferred to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in 1984, defective determinations for fees payable for quarantine services continued to be made. The successive failures of two Ministers effectively to discharge their responsibilities under the Quarantine Act must be very embarrassing for this Government. Although complicated legislation may sometimes give rise to defects which remain undetected for some time, there can be no excuses in this case. The Government had already been given notice that there were deficiencies in the Quarantine Act, and that its operation needed to be carefully examined. In fact, the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources into the adequacy of quarantine in Australia gave clear warning of this as early as 1979. I quote from the report:

The effectiveness of Australia's quarantine service depends on its legislative backing. The Quarantine Act is an old Act which has not been updated regularly and there are many deficiencies in the existing legislation.

In fact, the report referred specifically to problems with costing and fees under the Act, and expressed doubts as to the appropriateness of fees charged for quarantine services. Clearly, the Minister should have been put on his guard. Given this, his failure to take care when setting out requirements for determining fees is inexcusable. The Minister's subsequent failure to meet his own requirements is a disgrace. The warnings were there for all to see. One would think that those warnings would have been heeded long before now. One would think they would be of particular interest to Government Ministers with responsibility for overseeing the operation of the legislation. Yet in his second reading speech on this Bill, the Minister for Primary Industry suggested that the Government only recently became aware of defects in the Quarantine Act and of the need for close scrutiny of it, and the Senate report was published in 1979!

Why was this? Why did not either Minister-the Minister for Health or the Minister for Primary Industry-heed the warnings and tread carefully when dealing with quarantine regulations? Was it because they had not even bothered to read the Senate Committee's major report on the subject? Was it because neither of them considered quarantine legislation to be very important? I wish to impress on the Ministers concerned how very important effective quarantine legislation is to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—As my colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) reminds me, it is probably one of the most paramount matters of importance for all the livestock industries in this country. As has been pointed out in the debate tonight, quarantine in Australia has to date been relatively successful. We have not suffered the traumas and economic devastation associated with major outbreaks of pests or diseases. But this does not mean that we can afford to pay scant attention to quarantine legislation. On the contrary, with jet travel commonplace in the modern world Australia has lost any quarantine advantage it once had by virtue of being a relatively isolated continent. Over two and a half million people flew into Australia from overseas countries in 1984 alone. When we consider the massive cost to this country caused by the arrival of the aphid to our shores, the value of vigilantly enforced and regularly updated quarantine laws is brought home even more sharply.

SPEECH.PARA: The spotted alfalfa aphid was first identified in Australia in March 1977. The bluegreen aphid was detected soon after. Between them these two pests cost Australian primary industry some $200m in just two years. This is chickenfeed compared with the potential damage which could be caused if an outbreak of foot and mouth disease should occur in Australia. The meat export industry alone would stand to lose some $1.7 billion a year in exports if such a disease slipped through our quarantine barriers, and that takes no account of the disastrous effects on domestic stock prices. For how many years could export markets remain closed if there were an outbreak of foot and mouth? Obviously, effective quarantine legislation is vital to Australia. Although determination of fees may be a relatively small part of the overall operation of the Quarantine Act, the slack attitudes of the relevant Ministers in relation to this matter is cause for grave concern. If they are so slack about a simple piece of legislation, what about the administration of the Quarantine Act itself?

Finally, it is to be hoped that in the light of this debacle the Minister for Primary Industry will take notice of the reports of the Auditor-General on efficiency audits which have just been released and which call for a complete and thorough examination of animal and plant quarantine fees and costs. With those few words, I will conclude by saying that both Ministers have something to answer for. Now that the oversight has been rectified, I wish to support the amendment proposed by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). It is a commonsense amendment and I hope that the Minister will take it on board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill which the House is in the process of considering has become necessary simply to correct some unintended effects that flowed from the operation and the application of the amendments contained in the quarantine legislation of last year. I have been surprised at some of the statements made by Opposition spokesmen, particularly the position they have adopted on the ridiculous amendment, as I will indicate later, notice of which has been given by the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). There is no great deal about this question. Put simply, what happened was that notices made under the Act as a result of those amendments last year had the effect of revoking the basis on which fees for some quarantine services are charged. Those fees quite correctly have continued to be charged without legislative support. This Bill simply validates those fees. There is nothing exceptional about that. The fees were correctly collected. No one complained about paying them. The people who paid the fees realised that they were paying for a service which they had obtained, which they had sought and which they support. Yet we have heard some ridiculous arguments and claims from Opposition members. There is no argument at all about the legitimacy of these fees or about the legitimacy of having those fees imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, the second thing the Bill does is to validate charges levied on airline operators under the legislation to offset expenses incurred in the removal and disposal of airline waste. I mentioned some of the ridiculous statements that were made by Opposition members. The Deputy Leader of the National Party, in leading for the Opposition, went so far as to refer to the matter in these rather exaggerated terms-and I am sure he will recall these words as obviously they were prepared with great care: `the multi-million dollar bureaucratic blunder'. It rolls from the tongue very well. it obviously took a great deal of time to prepare it, but it is a statement without any substance. As I said, it is no great deal.

The important thing about this legislation is the fact that the Commonwealth now, is taking steps to validate fees which had been charged quite correctly, which have been paid quite freely, and which were designed to offset the cost of services which had been received. It has been mentioned that the total amount involved was $2.5m. That was for the animal and plant quarantine requirements and the human quarantine element of it as well. I think some $630,000 had been collected from the airlines as a result of that arrangement made for the removal of airline waste. I think it was the Deputy Leader of the National Party who also said that the money had been collected illegally. I see the honourable member is nodding his head which means he confirms that. Precisely what that ridiculous statement means escapes me. Because the Deputy Leader of the National Party knows what these issues are all about, I bet the meaning of that statement escapes him as well. It escapes me. I do not know what he means by that. The Deputy Leader of the National Party looked down when I said that. He does not know what it means and he does not know what it means because it does not mean anything. Of course it was legal to collect the fees. Do honourable members think that people would have paid them illegally? Do honourable memers think that the Commonwealth received the money illegally? What we are doing now is going through a simple administrative procedure to validate, in terms of Commonwealth law, those fees which were correctly and legally received.

We should maintain some sort of perspective when we are looking at questions like these. The Opposition has referred to this legislation as some sort of blunder, but some of the newer members on the other side might not know that when their parties were in Government they became notorious for their degree of administrative sloppiness and their managerial incompetence. The number of times we had to come into this Parliament in order to legitimise some shocking examples of administrative incompetence and sloppiness really became legend in Australia. The fact that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin), together with the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), has with great vigilance, identified this deficiency and moved immediately and effectively to overcome those simple administrative deficiencies, speaks very well for his vigilance, the vigilance of his officers, the vigilance of the Minister for Health and the officers of the Minister for Health.

I consider it a great privilege to have the opportunity to participate in a debate about primary industries, rural industries, with the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). What a great advocate.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is so good he has gone to the party.

—He is listening. He assured me before he went that he would listen closely to my contribution and I am absolutely convinced that he is doing precisely that. It is a great privilege for a member of the Government to participate in a debate about rural questions, primary industries and the major issues that confront our great rural industries with a man who is so experienced, so informed, so concerned and a man who is such an outstanding and brilliant advocate for our primary industries, as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro.

SPEECH.PARA: I said that I would draw attention to the very serious deficiencies in the amendment notice of which has been given by the Deputy Leader of the National Party. Those amendments will have the effect of encouraging protests about the payment of legitimate fees where no protests have been made in the past. Why would honourable members want to encourage that sort of thing? The Deputy Leader of the National Party knows that in order to cover some of the expenses of quarantine services it is necessary to impose a fee. The people who paid the fees paid them because they accepted the fees were legitimate. They had received a service. I hope the Opposition withdraws the amendment; it is quite nonsensical and the Deputy Leader of the National Party knows it. If he could get the National Party fellows in their corner and the Liberal Party members to support that amendment what in fact-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable gentlemen, sir; honourable gentlemen!

—Indeed all honourable members opposite are honourable gentlemen except the honourable woman member of the Liberal Party. The honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) pointed out that the proposed amendments would defeat the purpose of the Bill because they would allow a person who has already received a service to avoid payment simply by alleging that the payment had been made under protest. The Deputy Leader of the National Party knows that that would be the effect of the amendments; so how he got it endorsed from members of the National Party I do not know. If it was endorsed in one of its Party meetings honourable members should re-examine the nature of the amendments, their significance and their possible effect and then decide whether they want to persist in the way they apparently do to sabotage very sensible legislation which this Government is introducing at present. I ask the Deputy Leader of the National Party in all seriousness to withdraw the nonsense. He should not persist because people are very concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: Some National Party members have expressed concern. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) referred to the enormous danger which exists for our great rural industries as a result of the possible outbreak of exotic diseases of various kinds. All honourable members know that this matter has always been a bipartisan issue. This is as it should be and it should continue into the future. Honourable members opposite do not have any monopoly-as they know-of concern about our rural industries. Traditionally, they are great industries and this Government, more than any other government including coalition governments, has shown itself to be more than responsive to the particular needs of our rural industries, to encourage their development and to acknowledge openly and willingly the great contribution that they have made to Australia in the past and will continue to make. The Opposition has no monopoly of concern about those things.

As I have said, the question of effective quarantine legislation to establish suitable procedures, regulations and penalties has always been a bipartisan matter. An example of the importance of our rural industries should be seen by the following figures and I am sure they are well known to a number of members of the Opposition. For example, rural commodities of animal and plant origin accounted for over $11,000m of our commodity exports last year-1984-85. That is an amount of very great substance and of very great importance to Australia's trading position as a major trading nation. That figure represented 36 per cent of our total commodity exports. Of course even our manufactured products contained a significant element of rural products as well. So they are extremely important and that fact is acknowledged.
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite should listen to what I tell them. They would not have believed that I know anything about this matter.
—You don't know anything about rural industries.

—I have made a more effective contribution on rural industries in 10 minutes than the honourable member has made in six months and he is supposed to represent rural people. The betrayal by the people who masqueraded as representatives of the rural industry in Australia started when they first changed their name from Country Party to National Country Party. The final betrayal occurred when they chopped out the word `Country' altogether. It is now the National Party. It has completely repudiated any responsibility that it had to the great rural industries of Australia. It became embarrassed to call itself the Country Party. We have never been embarrassed to call ourselves the Australian Labor Party and nor should we. The Labor Party has great traditions; it is the Party with the longest continuing existence and the proudest traditions of any political party in Australia. Some exotic diseases that we have to make sure-
—ACTU domination.

—I was about to talk about foot and mouth disease. The honourable member is suffering from it. He should just settle down and I will tell him something about rural industries that would have never occurred to him before. Some of the better known diseases about which we are concerned-
—He certainly hasn't got laryngotracheitis

—He has not got virulent Newcastle disease either. I bet he has not got African swine fever or the screw worm fly or swine vesicular disease or rinderpest. Those diseases are equally devastating. Some of the better known ones are blue tongue and the one to which I have just referred-foot and mouth disease. The responsibility of the Commonwealth over quarantine regulations is provided for in the Constitution. Placitum (ix) of section 51 gives the Commonwealth, quite clearly, the exclusive responsibility in connection with quarantine. All successive governments in Australia have accepted that responsibility. It is a tribute to them all that we have been able to maintain Australia as free as we have from all of those exotic diseases which would devastate and ravish Australia's primary industries if the diseases were to get a hold of any of our industries.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the cost of providing the quarantine service in Australia in the current year, 1985-86? The Budget provides for $19m to be expended for human quarantine services and provides $26.4m for plant and animal health and quarantine services. The amount of revenue that we receive in return for these services is relatively minor. No one takes exception to that. No one opposes it. We all support it. I have never heard any parliament in Australia or any person in Australia who is involved in any political party offer any opposition to the amount of money that is spent on quarantine services. I hope that there will never be any opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —By gee, you know about this stuff. You are right on the ball.

—Much more than members of the National Party. I sometimes despair at those members of the National Party, which Party purports to represent the rural industries in Australia, when they know so very little about those industries.
—His own Whip has told him to wind up.
—The Whip realises that my contribution has been so devastating that I do not need to go on any longer. I have floored them.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has a coastline of 36,700 kilometres. Australia has $30 billion worth of imports every year. Over two million people come into Australia each year either returning from short term trips overseas or coming to Australia. That gives some idea of the dimensions of the problems that we face in introduction, applying and maintaining effective quarantine provisions and defence in Australia. It is a matter of great importance. No one underestimates it. If the Opposition were serious and if it were prepared to continue the bipartisan approach it has had before, I repeat that the Deputy Leader of the National Party would take advantage of the opporunity that I offer him now to withdraw his proposed amendments. The amendments are a nonsense and he knows it. They are destructive and damage everything the quarantine service in Australia stands for. They do neither him nor his Party nor this Parliament any credit.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 5, page 2, at the end of the clause add
``unless the recipient of a service has paid an amount under protest or has taken legal proceedings to challenge or resist any payment''.
(2) Clause 6, page 3, at the end of the clause add
``unless the amount paid has been paid under protest or complaint''.
(3) Clause 7, page 3, at the end of the clause add
``unless the owner, master or agent of the aircraft has paid the expense under protest or complaint''.

The Opposition is concerned to legitimise the illegitimate actions of the Government. It is necessary for the Quarantine (Validation of Fees) Bill to provide some immunity to those people who may have initiated legal proceedings to challenge or resist payment of these fees since the trouble began last year. It would apply only to people who may have paid their fees under protest. I emphasise that I am not aware of any such proceedings, nor do I suggest that the way the Act has been administered may have provoked such legal action. Yet it would seem grossly unjust to terminate prematurely any legitimate action which could already have been initiated. Amendments to clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Bill are designed to protect the interests of any quarantine service users who may have paid fees under protest or initiated legal action. I remind the Committee that fee collections for services covered by this Bill amounted to more than $3m in the past year.

The Committee will be setting a precedent if it chooses to correct retrospectively an oversight in administration of the Act and in so doing shut out any recourse to complaint or normal legal action. I understand that the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) is of the opinion-I hope that it is based on legal advice that he may have obtained-that the rights of individuals are incorporated in the original Act. Despite this, the Opposition opines that safeguards, as moved, should be incorporated into this Bill to clarify the matter. There is no case for governments to be given preferential treatment at the expense of those using government services. I strongly urge the Committee and the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) to accept these reasonable amendments and to remove any precedent of retrospective action against legal processes.

The Opposition is not opposing the Bill. All we are attempting to do in this Bill to legitimise actions that were taken without proper legal procedures is to ensure that the basic principle which I have outlined is respected and adhered to. I believe that the Parliament has to set some standard. It is here to serve the will and the wishes of the people. It must be immaculate in its handling of laws to ensure that people are not disadvantaged by one Act or another. We have initiated the moving of these amendments not out of any spite but out of respect for precedent. It would be a dreadful state of affairs if governments, through this precedent, felt that they could at some future date act or introduce legislation retrospectively to legalise illegitimate actions that it may have taken. That is the basis of our concern.

Every action that we take in this Parliament ultimately makes a precedent if that action has not been taken before. I do not believe that the Government has attempted to cover up in any way. I believe the Government has been very open about this matter. There has been a bureaucratic bungle or blunder. These sorts of things do happen. All governments have their problems from time to time, particularly when there is a transfer of administrative responsibility from one department to another. A fundamental principle of human rights is involved here. I would have thought that the honourable member for Charlton, who is a great defender of human rights-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a top member, one of the best in the chamber.

—He is not a bad old soak really. I thought that he would have seen the justice of what we are endeavouring to do. I appeal to him to have another little think before he throws overboard what is a thoroughly good idea-protecting the rights of the individual.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I would like to say that I am glad that the Government did not go along with the motion by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) that the House should adjourn. It has been a very stimulating debate. We have all enjoyed it immensely. Members of the Opposition have typified this Bill as being akin to the onset of World War III or something of that ilk. I must point out the nature of the Bill. It all goes back to an issue of the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 1 October 1984. Luckily, I did not become the responsible Minister until 13 December 1984, so I escape on this matter. What I failed to do, of course, once I took over responsibility, was to read all of the back issues of the Commonwealth Gazette. I know that when the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), was Minister for Health he read all of the Commonwealth Gazettes assiduously at night. That is why he did not make any mistakes. But I am told that in regard to the second part of this Bill during the period when the Deputy Leader of the National Party was Minister for Health he was illegally charging for aircraft waste. Not only has the present Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) a bit of a problem; so did the previous Minister for Health. I can understand the Opposition being mortally upset about this. Really, both of them are in the poo and that is what we are trying to fix up.
—Find another word for that.
—In the muck.
—It is a legitimate word-Winnie The Pooh!

—It is. You have a chicken on your side; anything can happen. The purpose of this Bill is to validate the Commonwealth's right to charge fees for the provision of services that it has provided in the performance of its quarantine responsibilities. The honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) set it out beautifully clearly. These fees are designed to offset costs which the Commonwealth has incurred in the provision of those services. The fees which have been collected are for services which have been provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is not attempting to raise fees which are additional to those already paid. We have got the dough. The effect of the legislation would not be to impose a levy, charge or fee retrospectively, nor would it remove the rights of aggrieved parties to challenge the fees paid during the relevant periods. Indeed, if the amendments were to be incorporated in the Bill they would defeat its very purpose by providing an exemption from payment of fees for services which have been provided simply by alleging payment under protest. The effect of the legislation is simply to validate those charges which have in effect been levied. That is why the Government cannot accept the Opposition amendments.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
