SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendments be not made.

It is with some regret that I find that I again stand before you tonight to deal with the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985. As honourable members are well aware, the House has already considered this Bill and passed it without amendment, on Wednesday 13 November 1985. Today the Bill has been before the Senate. Despite assurances to the contrary, the Liberal- National Party Opposition reneged on Opposition undertakings and sided with the Australian Democrats to impose some 16 amendments or requests for amendments on a Bill which has the basic agreement of the major organisations within the veteran community. These 16 changes would add scores of millions of dollars to the appropriation made by this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—I suggest that the shadow Minister who has been disgraced and repudiated by the actions of his colleague in the Senate, would do best in honouring his position by remaining silent. If he had any regard for the feelings of the ex-service community, he would resign. Today the Opposition and the Australian Democrats engaged in one of the greatest exercises in political hypocrisy ever seen in this Parliament. In the guise of a purported concern for the interests of the veterans and the defence community, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats have now brought this Bill to the brink of disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline-the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) knows the implications of this-the consequences if this Parliament fails to pass the Veterans' Entitlements Bill in time to seek royal assent before 5 December 1985; that is, next Thursday, one week from today. Honourable members will be aware that changes to the repatriation legislation following the May economic statement of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) were amended in the Senate to insert a sunset clause which allowed a modified standard of proof to operate for a limited period of six months. That sunset clause will take effect from 6 December; that is, next Friday. This would lead to the reimposition of the old standard of proof provisions which, under the O'Brien interpretation, would lead to the automatic acceptance of virtually all claims for disability pension or war widow's pension. The veteran community has acknowledged that the O'Brien decision went too far in respect of the standard of proof to be applied to a claim for a repatriation pension.

The veteran community, after a great deal of consultation-and I do not beleive any piece of legislation concerning veterans' entitlements has involved so much detailed consideration and so much input from the veteran community-generally supports the changes made to the standard of proof in clause 119 of the Bill. The ex-service community advised the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) that the revised clause 119 was considered to be generally satisfactory, subject to its possible eventual testing in courts of law. Since the Government will not accept the amendments the effect of the attitude taken by the Senate to this Bill is to restore the old standard of proof-a situation regarded as totally unacceptable by the Government, by most of the veteran community and, in fact, if one reads the speech of the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the honourable member for Farrer, by the Opposition. The records are there.

Clearly, the Government cannot allow claims to be determined on the old section 47 of the Repatriation Act. That would be the height of economic irresponsibility. The Government would be forced to bring the repatriation determining system to a halt until this Bill could be passed. I think the Opposition in this House and the shadow Minister appreciate the effect that that would have. Currently there are around 50,000 claims and applications for review in the repatriation system. These would be suspended. The recent long overdue improvements in reducing times to process claims and applications for pensions would be lost. This will result in widespread discontent anxiety and distress within the ex-service community. Let honourable members make no mistake, veterans will know exactly who to blame for this course of events.

I emphasise that the VEB makes many improvements on existing entitlements. That was recognised during the course of the debate in this House. The Senate is prepared to jeopardise those improvements. In fact, the effect of some of the Opposition sponsored amendments will be to take away pension entitlements already granted. Let me just list for honourable members some of the improvements in repatriation benefits that the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are prepared to withhold from eligible veterans and war widows.

The Government has announced that it is prepared to provide that all Australian service personnel who served on full time duty in a declared Vietnam war zone will have access to benefits under the VEB and defence service home loans. As my colleague the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) announced in this House, he had arranged for all those people not allotted to duty in Vietnam to be deemed to be for the puposes of the VEB. The Government finds itself unable to act in this regard until this legislation is in place. Under the VEB the guide to the assessment of rates of veterans' pensions will ensure consistency in the assessment of the rate of pensions payable. It will give veterans the opportunity to understand how the rate of pensions is assessed. This guide will not be able to be introduced if the VEB is not passed.

Under the VEB eligibility for repatriation benefits is extended to Australians who served during World War II with the forces of an allied country if they were domiciled in Australia immediately before the war. Without the VEB there will be no such extension. Under the VEB the domestic allowances, that is $12 a week pension supplement, will be payable to all war widows. Under the present legislation specific criteria for eligibility apply and not all war widows receive the allowance. Under the VEB war widows' pension entitlement is not to cease on remarriage and those widows who have remarried since 29 May 1984 will have their pensions restored. Not to proceed with this proposal will cause distress to a considerable number of war widows. Those widows who had planned to remarry before Christmas and keep their pensions will now find themselves in the heart-rendering position of having to postpone their weddings. Under the VEB a de facto wife of a veteran will be recognised for the purposes of pension eligibility on more liberal terms than those which apply under the present legislation. The de facto wives can thank the Opposition if the VEB is not passed.

Under the VEB a child who is dependent on a veteran at the time of the veteran's death will be eligible for an orphan's pension, even where he or she is not the natural or adopted child of the veteran. Orphans can thank the Senate and thank the irresponsibility of members of the Australian Democrats, the National Party of Australia and the Opposition if this legislation is not passed.

Under the VEB service pension eligibility is to be extended to those who served immediately after World War II in mine clearance and bomb disposal work and who were awarded a British General Service medal with appropriate clasp. These veterans as a result of the political mendacity which has operated in another place are now to be denied their legitimate entitlements. Under the VEB service pension eligibility is to be extended to veterans who served with the Far East Strategic Reserve in Malaya and who were awarded a British General Service medal with the Malaya clasp. Again, repatriation recognition of this group is not a priority for the Opposition. Under the VEB members of Commonwealth and allied forces will not have to be resident in Australia for 10 years in order to qualify for a service pension if they become permanently incapacitated for work while in Australia or during a temporary absence from Australia. The Opposition seems prepared to leave any veterans in this unfortunate position without repatriation entitlements. Frankly I find it hard to believe that that is genuinely a position that members of the Opposition would want to adopt and support. The VEB incorporates a broadened definition of treatment encompassing the capacity to provide various forms of social or domestic assistance that may be required by a frail aged veteran or war widow. Without the VEB there will not be the capacity to provide the broad range of treatment our frail aged require. Will that be a matter of pride for honourable members opposite? I am not surprised that the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest), who has some sensitivity, is leaving the chamber. Under the VEB, treatment for any condition whether war caused or not will extend to all veterans in receipt of a service pension and a disability pension and will be equivalent to not less than 50 per cent of the general rate. Without the VEB, only veterans who served in World War II will qualify. The VEB will authorise the continuation of treatment outside a Repatriation Commission hospital when treatment has commenced in such an institution. Presumably the Opposition is prepared to accept that those patients on renal dialysis should not be able to be treated in their homes. I do not believe that that represents a genuine position of this Opposition. Under the VEB, a document known as the `Treatment Principles' will set out the circumstances in which and the conditions subject to which the Commission will accept responsibility for the provision of treatment.

Let us move to the question of allowances. Under the VEB, eligibility for the funeral benefits entitlement will be extended in respect of the death of a veteran who, with the approval of the Commission, was being cared for at home for a terminal illness rather than being admitted to an institution. Are we seriously asked to believe that members of the Opposition do not believe that a terminally ill veteran in that situation has a right to die in his home? I do not believe that is a position which many members of the Opposition could bear to live with for more than a few minutes. Under the VEB the funeral benefit for service pensions will be extended to all those who receive a service pension, and that is presently not available to Commonwealth and allied veterans. The effect of the Opposition's amendent is to continue the dual entitlement of members of the peacetime defence service to repatriation coverage and Commonwealth employees compensation coverage for personal injury connected with the member's peacetime service.

The Government's position is quite clear. It is proposed in the VEB that for new enlistees to the forces repatriation should be limited to periods when they are undertaking hazardous service or peacekeeping service. In other circumstances the new enlistee will attract Commonwealth employees compensation benefits if injured or killed in circumstances connected with service. The Government's proposal does not take away existing benefits for members of the forces. Present members will continue to have dual repatriation and compensation coverage. The proposal applies only in respect of new enlistees to the defence forces.

As a result of representations from veteran and regular Defence Force communities the Government has undertaken to investigate the feasibility of a separate military compensation scheme for peacetime defence service. This is not an empty promise. The Minister for Defence has indicated that he will report back to the Parliament on the Government's study of the proposal as soon as possible and no later than the autumn sittings in 1987. The Opposition suggests that new enlistees should not be deprived of repatriation cover while this investigation is being undertaken. That was the significant amendment moved by the Opposition in this chamber. All the other amendments which have emerged in the Senate seem to cast a reflection upon the attitude that was expressed in this chamber by the spokesman for the Opposition. This Opposition is in such disarray that I can understand the sense of shame that permeates it. I can understand the honourable gentleman's position. He is entitled when he speaks in this chamber on behalf of the Opposition to put the position of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he does it very well.

—I believe he did it very well. What I find appalling is that having addressed his mind to it with a sincerity, dedication and involvement which understood the attitude of the veteran community, he finds, as a result of the sordid back room deals that are done in the Senate, the positions that he put in this chamber have now been overruled and he is left to carry the bag here for amendments, many of which, quite frankly, I do not think he was even consulted about.
—But did he collaborate?
—I do not believe he did and I do not believe that he would. Let me say that of the honourable gentleman.
—You called for my resignat- ion 10 minutes ago. This is a change.

—That would be a matter for the honourable member's feelings. But given the state of shambles that exists in the Opposition, I can understand why he would not want to do it. But with extraordinary bloody-mindedness the Opposition is prepared to sacrifice the real benefits flowing to veterans and their dependants under the VEB for the sake of some facesaving political exercise in the Senate. That is what it comes down to.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition purported to insert the sunset clause into the Repatriation Legislation Amendment Bill to enable full consultation to take place with the veteran community. Nobody from either side of the House could deny that the fullest consultation that has ever taken place with the veteran community has occurred with this Veterans' Entitlements Bill. Indeed, from the statements made by the Opposition shadow Minister, he was prepared to concede that it was fruitful and positive consultation because agreement was reached on the crucial elements of the Bill, notably on the standard of proof clauses. When he spoke in this House on behalf of the Opposition, time and again he stressed, and properly so, that this was legislation about which there could be a large measure of consensus because both sides of the Parliament had been fully involved in discussions with the veteran community. That was the spirit in which this legislation came into this Parliament.

Now, the Opposition and the Democrats in the Senate want to throw away the results of the very consultation they pretended to promote. Indeed there are parts of the amendments the main ex-service organisations have never sought, have never considered, and certainly never approved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones?

—They are there in detail. What is more, there is the sheer hypocrisy of the Opposition. Opposition members purport to be the great exponents of cutting government expenditure. Hardly a day goes by in the Parliament when we are not told by the Opposition that there have to be cuts in public expenditure. But what happens when the Government, indeed the House, adopt measures to cut future government expenditure? The Opposition in the Senate puts forward amendments which have exactly the opposite effect. That is exactly what the Opposition has done in adopting the amendment to continue eligibility for the service pension for allied veterans who served after September 1957.

SPEECH.PARA: Where is the hard-headed responsible approach of the economic rationalists? Where is the acceptance of the economic rigor of setting priorities and allocating funds accordingly? When the hard decisions have to be taken, the economic Rambos of the Opposition turn into political wimps. The Government has consulted fully and successfully with the ex-service community. We have been generous in extending a wide range of benefits and entitlements. No single piece of legislation has previously come before this Parliament concerning the rights of veterans in which the veteran community was so deeply involved and on which it could be truthfully said, and was said by both sides of the Parliament, that the legislation represented the hopes and the aspirations of the ex-service community. That was the spirit that dominated the debate in this House. What we now see is a series of ill thought through politically contrived amendments which put this legislation in jeopardy.

It is time for the Opposition seriously to think through its position because the thoughtless political extravaganza in which it has been involved in the Senate now poses a very real threat to the rights and the entitlements of the veteran community and to the legitimate process of consultation in which the ex-service community was involved and from which it was entitled to expect, as a result of those consultations and deliberations, the speedy passage through the Parliament of legislation which represented their desires. That has not taken place because of the divisions that exist within the Opposition. It has not taken place because of the political manoeuvring which is a result of those divisions which have been expressed in the Senate. Therefore, the Government rejects all of the requests for amendment made by the Senate and we refer the Bill back to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it very clear to the Committee at the start that it is upon the head of the Government what happens ultimately to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill 1985. The Government is elected to govern. The amendments that the Opposition and others have supported in the Senate go to certain aspects of the Bill. However, let us look at this matter in perspective. The centrepiece of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill is clause 119-standard of proof. I think honourable members on both sides of the chamber would agree with that. Clause 119, in all its substantial provisions, is exactly as the Government wants it passed by the Parliament. However, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) has the hide to come into the chamber at this late hour and with bluster, bravado and brinkmanship say that the Opposition has been anything but responsible on this very important Bill. We have been very responsible.

SPEECH.PARA: At every fundamental stage of the Bill we have done the same thing in this place as we have done in the Senate, with the exception of the provisions associated with Standing Orders, which I am sure the Minister would realise preclude the moving of any specific amendments in the lower House to a denoted money Bill. This was a denoted money Bill. We moved an in-principle amendment which picked up allied veterans, which picked up retrospectivity and which picked up a number of the other matters which were then the subject of further scrutiny in the Senate in accordance with the strategy laid down by the Opposition.

I repeat that it is upon the head of the Government whether it foregoes its perfectly drafted standard of proof clause. That is the provision the Government wants from the Parliament. Clause 119 has now passed the lower House and the upper House and the main thrust of the Bill is available to the Government if it reverses its attitude to these amendments tonight. It would have clause 119 in place, admittedly, with some of the amendments. Those amendments do not affect the substantial provisions of clause 119.

There has been no deal done on this Bill. There has been no double-cross on this Bill. The Minister has decided to take a very negative attitude and reject all amendments out of hand. I must say to the Minister and to his colleague in the upper House that I signified at the very outset, as a matter of courtesy, that there would be a specific in-principle amendment. However, the Government has decided to reject all amendments. The real reason is the legislative time-table. Who is responsible for the time-table of legislation? The Government has left it to the last eight days to look at this Veterans' Entitlements Bill-after a period of six months. The Government decided that time-table. The Minister is back here tonight on bended knee screaming for this Bill because there is only a week to go before the expiry of the sunset clause. I make it very clear that it was that sunset clause that brought about the tremendous breakthroughs and improvements which have been made to the original draft exposure Veterans' Entitlements Bill.

I would like to take the Committee through these maligned amendments which have come back from the Senate. I think the Minister might be embarrassed if he looks at some of the details. Firstly, there is a group of amendments associated with the retention of repatriation cover for new enlistees-that was well and truly signified-until we have a military compensation Act in place or at least a few more details in relation to such an Act.

Some legislation took years to develop. The trade practices legislation took years to unfold. We are being promised that, somehow, we can be assured that there will be a report in 1986 and legislation in 1987, so that by the expiry of the three years-I accept that that is a relevant period-a military compensation Act will be in place to pick up new enlistees, who, in the meantime, will be plucked out of repatriation cover. We have taken a very responsible and consistent attitude in both Houses about the retention of repatriation cover.

Let us turn to the amendments which come under the group associated with allied veterans. The Minister would have us believe that they represent, somehow, some new benefit. It is no new benefit. The legislation was passed through this Parliament in the 1970s to provide service pensions for allied veterans if they served in certain conflicts, including Vietnam, as progressively more would have qualified. In this Bill the Government is cutting out Vietnamese, Koreans, Thais and Americans who have moved to Australia since the Vietnam conflict. It is a very arbitrary line when one considers that New Zealanders, under another provision of the Bill, are still in concerning allied veterans' assistance. So now the Government is creating a racist division between New Zealanders, as one lot of allied veterans who served with us in Vietnam, and Koreans, Thais, Vietnamese and Americans. What a hide the Minister has to play God on the race of people who served in Vietnam.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you raise this in the House? You didn't know about it until it was raised elsewhere.
—I knew about it and I put it in the in-principle amendment in the lower House. Go back and read the Hansard report for Tuesday, 12 November.

SPEECH.PARA: The third group of amendments relate to retrospectivity. They were the subject of some comment before the Senate Standing Committee on the Scrutiny of Bills. They are to make sure that no one will be the subject of the more stringent provisions which have existed since May, when, without consultation, the Government put so much of this Bill into mini-Budget legislation, without proper consultation with the Returned Services League, and slapped it through on to the statute book. The wording of the retrospective amendment ought to be looked at very closely. The aim and objective are there. I accept that there is provision for review, but nevertheless, this area has to be fleshed out further, because there is genuine concern on the part of the RSL, which, in fact, requested an amendment at this stage of the proceedings in relation to the matter of retrospectivity.

The Minister suggested that these amendments are somehow out of kilter with the attitude of the veterans' communities and all their organisations-in particular, the RSL. I can now tell the Committee that two of those groups of amendments were requested by the RSL-confirmed physically in the presence of the National President of the RSL, Sir William Keys, in King's Hall yesterday. The Opposition was reflecting the concern of the RSL on the matter of repatriation cover for new enlistees after December and reflecting its concern on the matter of retrospectivity. So I would not be too sure about the Minister saying that somehow it is now our of kilter. Sure, we all want the central thrust of the Bill. Sure, the Bill confers a lot of benefits. But that does not preclude the right of the Senate or the lower House, the House of Representatives to look closely at this legislation.

The legislation that we are asked to pass tonight is defective on the Government's admission, because it contains drafting errors in respect of hazardous service. The Minister has admitted that. So this august national Parliament is about to pass defective legislation, if the Government has its way. It is a great pity that the amendments necessary to rectify those drafting errors were not ready for the deliberations of both Houses in these closing stages of the Budget session. But I note, accept and appreciate the assurance given now in both Houses that those amendments will be dealt with again in the Senate.

I would now like to deal with the amendments to the Bill that were dealt with by the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. For the information of members on both sides of the Committee, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has a Government member as its chairman and a Government majority. The Committee produced a report which, much to the embarrassment of the Government, reflected on a large number of the provisions of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. There being no other member rising, I again call the honourable member for Farrer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Chairman. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee eventually got it right in respect of one aspect of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. The Committee tabled in the Senate a report which raised a large number of objections to the Bill. The amendments referred to in the Committee's report related mainly to Parliament's right to review certain allowances which are provided for under the Bill and to the very important principle of accountability. There always are administrative difficulties associated with these sorts of considerations. However, the Parliament is elected to review and to play some proper role in these matters. Of course it suits the conveniences of the Repatriation Commission and the Department of Veterans' Affairs to reduce the travel allowance administratively to 11.6c per kilometre on 1 July. Admittedly this is being proposed to pick up some anomalies in some circumstances. However, disadvantages will be created if this proposal is applied across the board to all veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the amendments which relate to acquired immune deficiency syndrome and refer to the indemnity clauses of the Bill. I remind the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) that earlier tonight the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) actually accepted the AIDS amendments moved by the Opposition because he realised that they reflected the approach of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances which, again, has a Government majority. So the truth of the matter is that a number of our amendments are the result of the recommendations of Senate committees which have Government majorities and whose proper role is to review legislation. The Government has now rejected all of the amendments which have been moved in one lot. Of course, the Government will say that additional amendments will be brought forward in the autumn session.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Farrer might bear in mind that the Committee is addressing the requested amendments exclusively.

—I accept that, Mr Chairman. I make passing reference only to the fact that the amendments in the AIDS category flowed from the recommendations of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee and were accepted by the Minister. We are now considering a request to which the Opposition is opposed. I will not delay the Committee by dealing at length with a number of other minor amendments which relate to costing and do not exacerbate greatly the budgetary situation.

—Order! The honourable member still seems to be a little confused. The Committee is addressing the request that the amendments be taken into consideration. We are essentially debating the request, not the amendments. The motion is that the requested amendments be taken into consideration of the Committee of the Whole forthwith.
—I thought we had dealt with that question.
—The question was put and passed. The question now before the Committee of the Whole is that the requested amendments be not made.
—That is correct. We are now debating that those amendments-
—We are dealing with Schedule A, not Schedule B.

—As I understand it, we are very much debating at this point in time that the requests go back to the other chamber as far as Schedule A is concerned, which is a more acceptable clarification. In any event, having tracked through the amendments under both Schedule A and Schedule B because they do lend themselves to some concurrent treatment, I will revert to the general principles associated with this aspect of the debate and say that the final outcome in respect of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill is very much upon the head of this Government. The Minister has adopted a very negative attitude in respect of the amendments in Schedule A, as he has in respect of those in Schedule B, but I will not deal with that in further detail. The Returned Services League and the veteran community specifically requested amendment Nos 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 in Schedule A. Our attitude is a very responsible one and it is linked to the latest position of the RSL on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: In general terms, the Opposition's commitment to veterans' affairs and those who served their country in time of war is to afford the greatest generosity to the veterans that responsible government will allow. We recognise the massive disruption which occurred to their lives and we recognise the need for proper assistance and provisions to be in place. The Veterans' Entitlements Bill which is before the Parliament again at this time, goes a long way towards making those provisions law in Australia. We recognise that the Veterans' Entitlements Bill as passed by the House of Representatives on 13 November and as passed by the Senate today has embraced and adopted the Government's exact position on clause 119, dealing with the standard of proof as far as the substantial provisions are concerned. So it is that we appeal to the Government to think again in relation to what it is throwing away and the benefits it will deny to veterans if it adopts an absolutely negative attitude to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill.

The timetable is part of the problem associated with this Bill. If there were a great deal more time before the expiry of the sunset clause-there is still one full sitting day for both Houses and five working days before that expiry date-the Government might be of a mind to look more closely at some of these amendments because the Minister for Veterans' Affairs did pick up in the Senate and agree to one of those amendments in any case. But because we have this short timetable the Government would have us believe that the Senate ought to be totally denied the right to look at, to review and to deliberate in a proper manner on this legislation. The Opposition will not buy that very negative approach by the Government. At no stage will we accept that there has been a variation of our proper and responsible treatment of the Veterans' Entitlements Bill. I feel most strongly that our course of action and the amendments that have now emerged from the Senate reflect that further responsible approach by the Opposition in relation to the Veterans' Entitlements Bill.

In conclusion as it is a matter of Schedule A as opposed to Schedule B, having dealt with both as it has turned out, we stand very much by amendment No. 1 in Schedule A. Unfortunately and very sadly it might become known as the racist amendment because it is injecting an artifical provision into the categories of allied veterans to differentiate between the Thais, Koreans, Americans and Vietnamese who moved to Australia and the New Zealanders. Under the terms of this legislation, New Zealanders will be allowed certain benefits and Americans, Thais, Koreans and Vietnamese will be disallowed certain benefits. That is what amendment No. 1 in Schedule A deals with precisely, and that is what this Government is sending back to the Senate. If this motion is carried, it will be the law of the land from this day forward.

I reiterate that the other amendments in respect of Schedule A relate to repatriation cover. We have taken an absolutely responsible stand on them. The coalition will represent the veteran in a very comprehensive manner. Its sunset clause brought about the benefits which flow from and are embraced in the revised Veterans' Entitlements Bill. It is now a matter for the Government whether it will throw out those benefits or throw out clause 119, relating to the standard of proof, which it wants to be passed in both Houses of Parliament.
Question put:
That the requested amendments be not made.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

—I wish to speak to the motion that you report.

—The question had been put to the Committee and was carried on the voices. The Chair acknowledges the fact that in the general confusion that normally follows a division the member rising to address the question may have been denied, but the inescapable fact is that the question has been put and resolved. I cannot recognise the honourable member.
—Mr Millar, I accept your ruling. I will speak on the next motion that will be put to the House.

—Mr Speaker, with the greatest of respect--
